My Favorite Installment of the Resident Evil Series. I know a lot of people who would disagree and say that 4 is a lot better, don't get me wrong I love Resident Evil 4, but I prefer 2. A great intro to the game and being able to play as 2 different characters was awesome. Truly terrifying whenever you're walking through RPD and Mr. X walks around the corner of the hallway you're about to enter. Amazing enemies throughout the entire game and a good ending. A perfect game for those new to survival horror.

Quite enjoyable and polished remake of an action/puzzle/horror game which I skipped back in the day, because of how janky it looked. Game story can be can played with either Leon or Claire, the two main characters of the story, but you don't get a full different story for each character, what you get is more like a variation of single story with some different elements. 

The somewhat clunky or intentionally restricted gameplay may put some players off. You can pretty much only walk, run, shoot and perform scripted actions, meanwhile most enemies are really mobile and some are really fast and deadly. Aiming is another thing game relies heavily on, this makes some boss battles really annoying.

I played the game blind, without any guides, and the design choice of using scarcity as game mechanic became obvious a bit too late, this mechanic was something that didn't really work that well, late game became very tedious. Inventory management and navigation/planning with a map are the core parts of the game, and these are actually pretty enjoyable. 

The game offers you the option to complete tasks in any order at first, but as it progresses, it becomes increasingly linear. The middle portion of the game — the sewers, was not my favorite since I felt like I didn't know where to go or what to do on my first run. 

Graphics look good, a lot of attention to detail was put on the characters, the environments, and even for the damage and environment effects. Even though this is a few years old game, it has beautiful modern looking shaders and lighting. Cinematic cutscenes get really old after the first run (skippable), but there is still a lot to see and find, if you are a completionist type of player.

Gripping gameplay, with an atmosphere that fills you with dread. But don't let that put you off. The progression is well balanced, with time to recover and gather resources after each boss. Hardcore mode will have you scrambling for ammo if you're trigger happy. However, manage this well and this is the mode you'll get the best experience. Mr. X is fucking TERRIFYING. whenever i heard him stomping his heavy ass boots, my cheeks would start clenching immediately out of fear.

I feel like most of the game is good so far but I do think that everything moves a bit too fast for people to really take in the actual environment and the atmosphere. The original RE2 wasn't long, but I feel like it built up all of the tension a bit better than the remake. They essentially rely on Birkin and Mr. X to make the game tense, but that doesn't work in the remake because none of the tension is built up and all of the scariness just kinda falters into frustration and annoyance. Top that with characters that aren't very interesting or memorable. Gameplay that's a slog to get through at times due to some weird delay in movement (why would anyone care about realism in a game with zombies?). This remake feels kinda half baked and sort of like they just wanted to push it out as fast as they could. 

They did have a fan remake that looked a lot better and closer in tone to the first RE remake. I really wish that was the game that got released instead.

When [i]Resident Evil 2[/i] released in 1998 I wasn't born, and I never played the original game. I have no nostalgia for it, and I went into this experience completely blind. That being said, this is one of the best games I have ever played. 

[i]Resident Evil 2[/i] is stunning, and extremely fun. When I randomly decided to pick this game up I never would've expected that I would end up beating it two or three times, or that it would become one of my favorite games. However, it is, and that's because everything here is so smooth and well done. The graphics are beautiful, the combat is exciting and extremely tactical, and the puzzles are just enough to provide a short break from the action. Different items are perfectly placed around the environments to keep you moving back and fourth while having to avoid the infected and Mr. X. 

For others who are going into the game blind, [i]Resident Evil 2[/i] is a survival horror game. So, although you'll see zombies walking around the police station, it's important that you pick and choose which you eliminate and which you tactically slide by. Additionally, this isn't an on-rails linear experience; there are multiple puzzles for you to solve around the police station, and you'll need to wander around clearing rooms, finding new key items, and figuring out how they can help you clean up any messes that are halting your progress. 

On the first playthough the scares were thrilling, but never anything crazy. In fact, [i]Resident Evil 2[/i]'s fear factor comes more from the constant tension of Mr. X won't leave you alone and chasing you around than from jump scares. [i]Resident Evil 2[/i] is so fantastic that it doesn't need to be scary to be good. Additionally, there is so much replayability here; you can play through the game as Leon or Claire first; the two have slightly different stories and the difference is certain enough to warrant beating the game as each of them once. Furthermore, once you beat the game for the first time you unlock a second scenario that you can play as either Claire or Leon, so there are really four different playthroughs you can have here as well as different difficulties you can play on. 

Four playthroughs seems like it could become repetitive, however, I will say that my second playthrough only took me four hours, that's nearly four hours faster than my first, and I'm sure it only gets easier the more you play. 

Outside of the main story there is still more content in the form of multiple different short-stories you can play through. These are a fun little addition, and you can challenge yourself to complete them in fast times. Collectible wise, throughout the main story there are little bobble-heads hidden for you to find and destroy- you can't go back to find them, but secondary playthroughs keep your collectible progress from previous runs. Completing harder difficulties and challenges rewards you with new weapons that break the game, allowing you to take your victory lap on this nightmare sittuation.

Honestly this is one of the best games I've ever played. I've never been a horror fan, and I had never played a [i]Resident Evil[/i] game before, but I had an absolute blast with the game. I'd highly recommend it to anyone; it's well worth the price for the amount of content packed in, and it's thrilling from start to finish with amazing incentive to replay countless times. I hope Capcom continues to remake [i]Resident Evil[/i] games in this style, or learns from the successes of this remake and implements them into the newest [i]Resident Evil[/i] titles.

[b]Necessary Play[/b]

Title: "Resident Evil 2 Remake: Survival Horror's Greatest Hits Reimagined"

Review:
If Resident Evil 2 Remake were a movie, it would be the blockbuster hit of the summer – the kind of film you watch with one eye closed and the other peeking through your fingers. Capcom's reimagining of this survival horror classic is like a love letter to fans of the original, with all the thrills, chills, and zombie kills you could ask for.

Let's start with the dynamic duo at the heart of the game: Leon Kennedy and Claire Redfield. These two are like the Batman and Robin of zombie-infested Raccoon City, armed with nothing but their wits and a trusty arsenal of weapons. Watching them navigate the city's twisted streets is like watching a masterclass in zombie survival – if that masterclass also involved a lot of screaming and running for your life.

But the real star of the show is the game's setting: the iconic Raccoon City Police Department. From its dimly lit corridors to its blood-spattered walls, every inch of this haunted house of horrors is dripping with atmosphere. It's like stepping into a nightmare version of your childhood police station – assuming your childhood police station was overrun by the undead and filled with puzzles straight out of a cryptographer's worst nightmare.

And let's not forget about the zombies themselves. These guys are like the Energizer bunnies of the undead world, with an endless supply of energy and a serious case of the munchies. Whether you're blowing their heads off with a shotgun or dodging their outstretched arms like a seasoned matador, there's never a dull moment when you're up against these brain-hungry baddies.

Of course, no Resident Evil game would be complete without its fair share of puzzles, and RE2 Remake doesn't disappoint. From deciphering cryptic codes to hunting down elusive keys, there's always something to keep your brain scratching while your trigger finger gets a workout.

In conclusion, Resident Evil 2 Remake is a spine-tingling thrill ride from start to finish. With its heart-stopping action, hair-raising scares, and enough zombie guts to fill a swimming pool, it's a must-play for any survival horror fan. Just don't forget to pack your courage – you're gonna need it.

Rating: 5/5 Stars – Because surviving the zombie apocalypse has never been so much fun!

[i]Review written in both french and english.[/i]

[h1]Français :[/h1]
Bon, je n'ai pas encore fait la campagne de Claire et, bien que je compte la faire à l'avenir, je pense avoir suffisamment à dire juste avec celle de Leon. Je n'ai également jamais joué à l'original donc je ne pourrais pas faire de comparatif entre les deux versions pour ce qui est du gameplay.

[h3]Points positifs :[/h3]
- Comme pour le remake de Resident Evil 4, les graphismes sont magnifiques, même en qualité lowest.
- Le jeu est bien optimisé malgré quelques lags à certains endroits.
- J'aime beaucoup les designs des personnages même si, pour une raison qui m'échappe, je préfère quand même le visage de Leon dans sa version original.
- Le jeu est ultra généreux avec les munitions de pistolet. En tous cas j'ai réussi à finir la campagne de Leon avec +200 balles restantes dans mon inventaire alors que je me suis amusée à éclater la cervelle de tous les zombies.
- De tous les remakes des Resident Evil jusqu'à présent, c'est probablement le seul qui a choisi de se concentrer sur l'horreur et la survie plutôt que sur l'action (avec les boss pour seules exceptions) et ça fait du bien de voir qu'il est resté fidèle à sa vibe originale.
- Le jeu est relativement assez long pour son prix. La campagne de Leon m'a pris environs 14h à compléter en avançant aussi rapidement qu'une tortue-limace et j'imagine que ça sera à peu près la même chose pour Claire, donc j'estime la durée de vie à une trentaine d'heures au total si vous êtes du genre à prendre votre temps comme je l'ai fait.
- Possibilité de choisir entre l'audio du remake ou l'audio du jeu original.
- Le jeu propose des défis, mais je les trouve ultra chauds à faire.
- Les traductions et le voice acting français sont réussis, même si j'ai quand même eu l'impression que ça ruinait un peu le jeu d'acteur à certains moments.
- On peut jouer à la manette, mais il faudra passer par le gestionnaire de contrôleur Steam pour les adeptes de manette PS4.

[h3]Points négatifs :[/h3]
- J'ai eu quelques chutes de FPS à certains endroits (je suis passée de 60 à 40-45 sans raison), mais ça reste une perte minime et ça ne m'a pas empêchée de finir le jeu pour autant.
- C'est peut-être juste un problème qui me concerne mais les plantes bleues ne m'ont servi à rien du tout. Je n'ai jamais été empoisonnée et, pourtant, je suis une quiche pour esquiver les attaques ennemies.
- Autant le jeu est généreux avec les munitions de pistolet, autant j'ai l'impression que les munition de fusil à pompe et les munitions de magnum étaient quasiment inexistantes, à tel point qu'on se sert pratiquement jamais de ces armes en-dehors des combats de boss. Du coup, ça rend aussi les améliorations du fusil à pompe complètement inutiles, puisqu'on ne peut même pas en profiter pleinement.
- Pareil pour les grenades (et je ne parle pas des grenades assourdissantes), à part pour tuer le groupe de zombies qui sort des cellules, je n'ai eu besoin de m'en servir à aucun autre moment.
- Il y a un système de sauvegarde automatique, mais je le trouve encore plus inutile que les sauvegardes manuelles.
- J'ai eu l'impression que la fin était un peu rushée, mais c'est un avis subjectif.

Le jeu est génial et je me suis quand même bien éclatée à finir la campagne de Leon, c'est juste dommage de voir que certaines mécaniques finissent par devenir si anecdotiques qu'on pourrait limite s'en passer (voir les points négatifs). J'ai également l'impression qu'il y a un gros déséquilibre au niveau des munitions qu'on ramasse et vous pouvez facilement finir le jeu avec plus de 200 balles de pistolet dans votre inventaire alors que le fusil à pompe et le magnum sont... beaucoup trop délaissés à mon goût. Ça reste, malgré tout, un très bon jeu avec une bonne durée de vie et un prix plutôt abordable pour sa qualité.

[hr][/hr]
[h1]English:[/h1]
So, I haven't done Claire's campaign yet and although I plan to do it in the future, I think I have enough to say just with Leon's. I also never played the original game so I can't make a comparison between the two versions in terms of gameplay.

[h3]Positive points:[/h3]
- Just like with the Resident Evil 4 remake, the graphics are magnificent, even in lowest quality.
- The game is well optimized despite some lags in certain places.
- I really like the designs of the characters, even though I still prefer Leon's face in his original version, for some reason.
- The game is very generous with pistol ammo. I managed to finish Leon's campaign with +200 ammo remaining in my inventory, even though I had fun killing every single zombie in the game.
- Out of all the Resident Evil remakes so far, this is probably the only one that has chosen to focus on horror and survival rather than action (bosses being the only exceptions) and it feels good to see it sticked its original vibe.
- The game is relatively long enough for its price. Leon's campaign took me around 14 hours to complete while moving as quickly as a slug-turtle and I imagine that it will be roughly the same for Claire, so I estimate the lifespan at around thirty hours in total if you're the type to take your time like I did.
- Possibility to choose between audio from the remake or audio from the original game.
- The game offers challenges, but I find them really hard to complete.
- You can play with a controller, but you will have to go through the Steam controller manager for if you're using a PS4 controller.

[h3]Negative points:[/h3]
- I had my FPS dropping in certain places (I went from 60 to 40-45 for no reason), but it's a minimal loss and it didn't stop me from finishing the game anyways.
- Maybe it's an issue that only concerns me but the blue plants have been of no use to me. I haven't poisoned once and I'm not even the best at dodging enemy attacks.
- As much as the game is generous with pistol ammo, I have the impression that shotgun ammo and magnum ammo were almost non-existent, to the point that I didn't even use these weapons outside of boss fights. As a result, this also makes the upgrades for the shotgun completely useless, since you don't even have time to take full advantage of them.
- Same goes for grenades (and I'm not talking about flash grenades), apart from killing the group of zombies that come out of the cells, I didn't need to use them at any other time.
- There is an automatic save system, but I find it even more useless than manual saves.
- I felt like the ending was a bit rushed, but that's a subjective opinion.

The game is great and I had a blast finishing Leon's campaign, it's just a shame that to see that some mechanics end up becoming so anecdotal that we could almost do without them (see the negative points for more info). I also have the impression that there is a big imbalance with ammo and you can easily end the game with more than 200 pistol bullets in your inventory while the shotgun and the magnum are... a bit too neglected for my taste. Despite its flaws, it remains a very good game with a good lifespan and a rather affordable price for its quality.

RE2 is a tense, meticulously crafted experience that should probably be experienced by every gamer interested in games. Perhaps its best to understand the game as a "thriller puzzle-lite". Exploration is rewarding and engaging, but not tedious. The combat is punchy but not too difficult. The story is intriguing but not complicated. 

RE2 probably has the best level design for a game of its size, and it is a small game. Most of the game takes place in a police station plus the surrounding area, and the game makes use of every last drop of its setting. The station becomes a character to learn and at the same time its inhabitants aren't going to let you figure it out that easily. 

I appreciate the pacing of the game the most. It's tight and concise, a quality that seems to be lost in the numerous (great) games that have come out in recent years. RE2 is short, but it doesn't waste a single second of your time. 

No cheap jumpscares, just great thrills. Even if you're scared of being scared, the game isn't long enough for it to be a slog. If you find it too much within two hours of playtime you know what you can do.

RE2 Remake:
Plus Points :
1. The story isn't far from the original RE2 on PSX, but it is improved and more impressive.
2. The story still focuses on RPD, Sewer, Vacant Factory, and Laboratory (renamed NEST in the remake).
3. The horror element is retained, the atmosphere in RPD, and the realistic zombies, lickers can evoke nostalgia.
4. The BGM sound can be changed to the original PSX version, enhancing the horror experience, and nostalgia.

Minus Points :
1. The storyline for supporting characters (Ada Wong and Sharry Birkin) is longer, but different from the PSX version.
2. There are many achievements that require certain actions to be done before acquiring them. For example, in Ada Wong's story, there is an achievement that requires not using a handgun, or in Sharry Birkin's part, the achievement is to escape from the room within 5 minutes after being kidnapped. These achievements are not easy to anticipate without reading the guide first.

Overall it's 9/10

Good game. you know how head shots do nothing in this game, ammo is made scarce. so it's actually a challenge surviving. You have to put like 3 head shots in a zombie on normal difficulty to kill them, and even then they might not die, they might get back up, which i thought was dumb, especially when they've made ammo scarce. You really can't waste all your ammo into putting zombies down in this game, you gotta conserve it and save it for when you really need it...it's pretty lame. like this is NOT a zombie-slaying game lol sorry to burst your bubble if you thought it was. if you run out of ammo, you don't always have a knife to rely on cuz like I said, everything is made scarce, they will break. You can't do melee attacks either and even if you used your knife the game is made in a way that you can't just keep slashing zombies with the knife, they will eventually grab you and take a bite out of you (UNLESS YOU'RE REALLY GOOD, I GUESS).

I did like how the game keeps you on your toes as when The Tyrant (Mr. X) comes in, you have to keep playing the game running from him, you can't kill him you have to continue playing the game, solving puzzles all that all the while being chased by him. that was pretty cool and it had me pretty nervous haha

What I didn't like: I hate how the game doesn't give you enough inventory room to hold items, I mean several times I found myself having a full inventory and not being able to hold any more items, so I had to discard some items I was already holding to make room for new items. That's pretty lame man. cmon Capcom. You have to play through the game and unlock more inventory pouches, but that happens as you progress through the game. It's an annoying feature. Should've just given us the extra inventory space from the start instead of making you unlock it. Also, this game is supposed to be played the way the devs intended it to be played leaving little room for any freedom to the player. Like the dev decides for us when to drop used items making room for new items.

They really nailed the "survival" aspect of the game. I mean this is a survival game if you couldn't tell. Everything is made scarce. It's really lame how if you don't have a knife in your inventory, you can't defend against zombies in close quarters. Just f**ng push them away dawg. But naw, you gotta wait and watch the zombie take a bite of meat off my boy Leon.

Unlocking infinite ammo weapons (like rocket launcher and minigun) by beating the game on S ranks was the icing on the cake. Actually makes you want to play the game on a 2nd playthrough for those up to the challenge so you can unlock those things and pwn zombies.

Can the game be improved? if they just added a stealth element that would be cool. guns just draw attention and herds of zombies. So to conserve ammo, let us 1 hit stealth kill zombies with a knife.

I still give a thumbs up because I enjoyed the story.
The replay value of this game is so high.

I've always found the original RE games to be rather overrated and I know a lot of the games' fanbase would crucify me for saying that, but I ended up liking this remake a lot.

My biggest beef in the original REs was that you could never move while shooting.  You'd have to stand still while multiple zombies fly up your rear-end.  Not to mention you had to shoot them in the head about seventeen times before they'd die.  I'm glad the remake actually enables its players to more effectively succeed.

Gameplay is what you would expect.  Lots of zombie killing, things to find, puzzles to solve, etc.  You have 
a pretty useful map that helps you know where you may have missed something.  The dialogue and voice acting is pretty cheap, which is to be expected from Japanese developers, but they usually make up for it in gameplay.  I don't think the plot and storyline are much different from the original, but I can't be 100% sure on that.

So, you can play the story as one of two characters where some parts are different and others remain the same.  Then, there's a whole separate run that can be played with varying differences.  So, there's quite a bit of replay value.

In addition to the story, there are some other game modes that can be played, some of which need to be unlocked first by completing "records", or "challenges" as I would call them.  Completing these "records" can also unlock different items for use in the story.

The 4th Survivor is a survival run-through challenge with limited resources and a crapload of enemies, which is very challenging.  That's not the end of it.  Apparently, beating this unlocks "tofu" characters.  I'm not kidding, you're literally a piece of tofu throughout the whole challenge.  It's incredibly silly.  And there are five different tofu types, each with varying weapons, equipment and silly Japanese one-liners that I didn't understand.  Oh yeah, and the tofu runs have heavy metal music playing in the background, which I really liked.  Finally, the "tofu" runs are egregiously difficult to beat.

Then, there are the Ghost Survivors stories.  You start off with three of them and unlock the fourth.  They are difficult.  You have limited weapons, ammo and consumables, but lots of enemies to work through.  They will test your judgment greatly.

My greatest beef with this game was character slowness.  "Oh, no!  I'm being chased by an invincible tank of a zombie dude and he's quickly gaining on me!  Better keep jogging as casually as I can!"  Seriously, developers can do better than this.

In the end, I'm sure Resident Evil fans would really like this.  Still, people who aren't too much into the franchise, like me, would also like it.

As someone who has never played OG Resident Evil 2 but watched some videos and read articles, this remake is very well made and almost close to perfection and a very well remake of the 1998 masterpiece. The atmosphere, graphics, the vibes, its own essence, enemies, map design, story, sound design is a one in a million. The lickers and Mr. X scared the shit out of me a few times at the point that it made me scream lmao. The feeling of oppression and hopeless in the air of a decaying police station and Raccoon City is something that I barely experienced in a videogame. Puzzles are really well made and makes you think just a little bit but are very nice to do. 

Nevertheless, I gotta say that the 2nd run, in my case was with Claire and some aspects didn't make any kind of sense. For example, how Claire (in my case) needs to do the same puzzles that Leon does in the 1st run. I understand that is obviously a game design thing but cmon. How do you fight the same William Birkin? 

Zombies... bullet sponges, that's it. Even if you shoot them 7 times in the face, there they are, still livin'. No more to say.

Despite all of its flaws, I clearly understand why people call this "The best remake of all time". I thought: "Is this game THAT good?". After I tried it, yes it is. If you want probably the best zombies experience in a game, go and buy this game, even if you don't want a zombie experience but a good game, go, what are you waiting for.

tl:dr          3,5 / 10
Ok, wow, I am probably gonna be one of the few people, that actually just couldnt enjoy this game:
Ill start with the good things:
- The graphics, sounds and asthetics in general are really, really good. Nothing more to say there.
- The story is still pretty cool.
- The progression and enhancing of your weaponry is quite satisfying.

But now, for the bad things:
. Pretty much the entire gameplay
- The bosses

Yup, you read it right. The gameplay in this game has got to be one of the worst things I have ever seen.
 Where do I even start?
1. Leon can do nothing besides shooting, throwing grenades and slashing with knifes. The game offers you no alternate way to get out of sticky situations. No knife parrying like in RE4 Remake, no kicking or punching or dodging, nothing.
Of course you could say: "Just dont get cornered then." Unfortunately, its not that easy. The game has quite linear paths, which makes it prone to getting cornered. I often had to resort to things that the gameplay didnt intend you to do.
2. Lickers dont work. Not only are the lickers just not well designed enemies (in this game, I mean, generally hear-only-enemies are quite cool), the game also gives you absolutely no way of distracting them. The only effective way to deal with them for a short time are flash grenades, which you have limited of. Slowly sneaking past them only works in limited scenarios, mainly because you cant, well, sneak in this game, you just have to walk past them by only tapping your walk button, which doesnt only look and feel stupid, it also barely works as the lickers can still hear it quite often and keep following you.
3. Bosses have way to much health and take way to long. On veteran, I ran out of ammo trying to fight birkin for the first time. And no, I didnt aim bad, I landed my shots pretty good on his weakpoint.
4. Probably the most glaring flaw. Common enemies are bullet sponges. Enemies soak up way to much ammo sometimes without reacting to them in any way. You can put 7-8 handgun bullets into a normal zombie's head and it might not even flinch. Oh yeah, and they might get up again multiple times before they finally die.
5. Quest items take up inventory space. Such a stupid idea. There is no fun in a feature like this, you sometimes have to run to a spot thats far away multiple times, just to grab items you had to leave because your inventory was full.
6. Limited saving is not a good idea in any difficulty mode, it doesnt make the game harder in any way, just more annoying, so I dont get why they put it in

And no, this critiscm is not because I am bad or something. You can argue with me, I ll gladly show you my gameplay, so you understand my point.

In my opinion Resident Evil 2 is the best story mode game in my library and also one of the best resident evil game. I like the game so much because it's almost perfect - The graphics are so realistic, fight with bosses or other enemies is difficult and every boss fight is different, the music is good and it fits with the situations. Also there are more than 1 story in the game which make it longer to play and that's amazing for me and if you love mini games with zombies there are also some extra modes which are fun and telling you more about the game story. And about the story - it is very interesting, there is almost everything - there is love, action and more, but there is some sad moments which were so realistic. I don't think the game has many or big drawbacks - maybe only that when there are enemies behind the doors you can't just get in you need to open the door again and again and try to defeat all the zombies (which is rare situation). So if you love realistic action horror story mode games and like making achivements or try challenging yourself by playing the game on hardcore - I recommend this game to you. I hope you enjoy it, because I really do!!

Game is actually tense,"scary", challenging, looks incredible and some caveats I'll get onto later aside otherwise supports the advertised 21:9 out of the box and runs incredibly well. The acting and writing are actually a bit better than usual low RE standards as a shock with a tone closer to the Resident Evil Remake and RE7. The controls are tight and make it feel like every bad thing to happen to you is your fault and with how they've implemented a third person perspective here I am starting to think the game might not have been as scary with the original camera (even if I would like it as an option). Doors really do invoke tension and without ANY load times it truly immerses you into the world and makes it feel like a real place. Especially because enemies still move and exist even when you are not there. Zombies can even follow you into other rooms and move around when you aren't there. Just when you think you are safe wait until you meet Mr X who will follow you across the entire RPD bar certain puzzle or save rooms who is alerted to you either by seeing you or hearing you or your gunshots.
This was a must play for 2019 and a reminder of what makes Resident Evil good and what makes good games in general.

And again while the story is decent for once I've also found having looked at the original that some of the content the remake emits (not much of the original is better) negatively impacts it like it lacking the "Zapping System" and the fact that Leon's A and Claire's B aren't that different compared to the original. The Ghost Survivors is a nice edition probably inspired by Extreme Battle mode but it's otherwise quite mediocre edition so thank god it's free.

Outside of Mr.X and Hunks new themes I am not impressed by the new music or lack of music. I use the Retro/OG music pack (which costs an additional fee :/ ) which helps but it's a shame there was no middle ground between old and new tune wise.

Worth while and a great way to get newbs into the genre and or series.

I played on Standard difficulty as Claire, then Leon.

This game nails survival horror. It brings back everything that made the first game great and nothing that made the first game bad. The remake looks incredible. The combat is very good. My only complaint about the combat is that it can be awkward to dodge boss attacks. I'm not a big horror fan, although I am slowly getting more into it, and this game has made believe that video games are the best medium for horror. I'm very excited to continue playing through this series.

The rest of this review only concerns the second run (after you beat the game, you can play through it again as the other character).
I'm not usually interested in playing a game a second time immediately after beating it. I only played through RE1 once. After looking online, it seemed like many people believed doing both runs in RE2 is necessary to consider the game "beaten". There are many differences between the runs, and you have to do both to unlock the true ending so I decided to do both for this game. For the most part, I enjoyed the second run. It's mostly the same places but the enemies therein and the path you take are different. The story is also different, but it can feel awkward. At times I can see where Leon's story and Claire's story match up and it feels like they are happening together. At others it's impossible for both stories to be happening together. The true ending is fine, but nothing to write home about. All in all, I would prefer they either committed more to the second run, making it clear that it's a core part of the game and making the plot actually line up with the first run, or just not have the second run and put more content into the first. Luckily the game is good enough that playing it again is still a lot of fun.

"Resident Evil 2" proves that remakes can not only capture the essence of the original but elevate it to new heights. As a longtime fan of the franchise, I was eager to revisit Raccoon City, and the 2019 remake by Capcom left me thoroughly impressed. Kinda wish they remake on RE1 not remastered. Third person camera would be appreciated and ALSO PLEASE RE CODE VERONICA. I AM NEW TO RE FRANCHISE, MY MATES BEEN SAYING RE CV IS RELEVANT TO RE 5.

Pros:

Faithful Recreation: The remake successfully retains the core atmosphere and narrative of the original while enhancing it with modern visuals and gameplay mechanics. It's a nostalgic trip for veterans and a fresh experience for newcomers.

Stunning Visuals: The graphics are nothing short of spectacular. From the detailed character models to the intricately designed environments, every aspect of Raccoon City feels immersive and terrifying. The RE Engine truly shines here.

Terrifying Atmosphere: The game expertly builds tension and fear. The dark corridors, ominous sounds, and unpredictable encounters keep you on the edge of your seat throughout. Capcom nails the survival horror aspect.

Well-Designed Puzzles: The puzzles are challenging without being overly frustrating. They add a layer of complexity to the game, encouraging exploration and critical thinking.

Cons:

Limited Exploration in Certain Areas: While the game generally encourages exploration, there are a few areas that feel slightly restricted. A bit more freedom in these segments would have enhanced the overall experience.

Story Structure Choices: The decision to split the narrative between Leon and Claire's perspectives, while interesting, might leave some players wanting more connection between the two storylines.

Conclusion:

"Resident Evil 2" sets a new standard for video game remakes. Capcom's maybe meticulous attention to detail according to my mates, combined with modern technology, results in an unforgettable experience. Whether you're a veteran of the original or a newcomer to the series, this remake is a must-play. It's a shining example of how to respectfully reimagine a classic while maintaining the core elements that made it a genre-defining title. STALK ME !

[h1] Survival Horror Is Back To Racoon City! [/h1] 
Resident Evil 2 is a 2019 survival horror game developed and published by Capcom. A remake of the 1998 game Resident Evil 2. Players control rookie police officer Leon S. Kennedy and college student Claire Redfield as they attempt to escape Raccoon City during a viral outbreak that transforms the citizens into zombies and other creatures.
 
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]💾Graphics[/td]
        [td]With terrifying hallways of the Racoon City police department, to the laboratory of Umbrella; the lighting and atmosphere is absolutely haunting. Many areas tell a haunting story of struggle and panic. I love the design of every area in this game. It’s so claustrophobic and terrifying. The enemy designs are flawless, actually just perfection! Also the zombies are the scariest I've ever seen in a video game. The UI is also clean and really easy to navigate. The in-game map is so useful. Any item you don’t pick up is marked on the map, so you will never forget where items are. That’s such a welcome addition to any survival game. Also the UI for the map just looks amazing, and user friendly.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎮Gameplay[/td]
        [td]It’s simple survival horror, really easy to get used to. You have to solve puzzles (which are extremely easy), conserve ammo, and fight scary bosses. The zombies (and other enemies) can be bullet spongy and can pull a few surprises on you. You will encounter many item puzzles, for example keys, a handle for a valve, and more. Also many items to help you on your journey. Healing items and finding pouches to increase your space will be a lifesaver! Exploration is everything in this game. So do not rush and take your time. Safe rooms are also a blessing and a returning feature from the original game. The safe room is, well, a safe room. No monsters can come in and hurt you. You will also have an item box to store all your goodies to use for later. Also don’t worry because every item you put into the item box, and connected to every safe room. There are many types of horrible creatures to fight through. Ranging from your normal zombies, dogs, G virus creatures, and much more! There is some content that has been cut from this game that was in the original sadly. I understand that this is a remake, but some content felt unnecessary to cut. Here are some of the content that is not in the game: 
[code][list]
[*]Zapping System
[*]Some puzzles are removed
[*]Removal of the Factory & Marshaling yard
[*]Many enemies that are cut (spiders, moths, crows, roaches, etc)
[/list][/code]
Regardless of the cut content, the game feels incredible and absolutely terrifying. The mechanics and overall gameplay feels incredible and so smooth. It’s the best form of survival horror, so prepare for a great challenge.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]📜Story[/td]
        [td]The story is short, but sweet (well as sweet as it gets in a zombie apocalypse). You play as Leon, or Claire. Each protagonist has different paths and stories for you to experience. The challenges each character goes through is believable and has incredible writing. The voice acting is top tier and really puts you into the experience. This is one of my favorite game stories. It’s horrifying, action packed, and has amazing characters.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🕛Playtime[/td]
        [td]Leon’s playthrough took me around 6 hours to complete. Claire’s playthrough was around 4 hours. You have a total of four different playthroughs in this game so the replayability is there. The good news is that you have challenges and unlockables you can get in this game that adds to the replayability. Also you have different game modes with there own short stories that add a good amount of playtime.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎧Sound[/td]
        [td]Resident Evil 2 has amazing music and sound design. The music score is so incredible and the developers were generous to add the classic 1998 music and UI sound effects. The zombies sound absolutely scary and hearing Mr.X roam around the halls is so haunting. They perfected the sound design and soundtrack for this game![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❗Bugs❗[/td]
        [td]I haven’t really encountered any bugs in this game. Actually I can’t think of one bug I had so far on my playthroughs.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔅Performance[/td]
        [td]Flawless. I can play Ultra settings no problem on this game. I had no stutters or frame drops. I have a mid range computer and it runs so well. The RE engine is so well designed so you should have zero issues on this game.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]✅Pro’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Great story
[*]Amazing graphics
[*]Haunting sound design
[*]Beautiful soundtrack
[*]Top tier voice acting
[*]Incredible enemy design
[*]Scary and haunting atmosphere
[*]Highly detailed and immersive environments
[*]Amazing unlocks (weapons, costumes, concept arts)
[/list][/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❌Con’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Cut Content including enemies, puzzles & locations
[*]Interactions between Leon and Claire are lacking in the Remake
[*]Second playthrough (or Side B) of Leon and Claire feel the same as Side A, but with very minor changes (basically feels rushed and lazy on the Side B Scenario)
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🏆Rating[/td]
        [td]9/10
This game is worth full price, especially for this amazing game! You can get this game on sale usually for around 50% off if you are patient.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔗Conclusion[/td]
        [td]Resident Evil 2 is a near masterpiece for me. I wish they didn’t cut as much content from the original. It’s a shame they did this, but besides that gripe I have; It's still one of the best modern horror games (especially for survival Horror). If you love survival horror, you will absolutely love this game.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

******Review after 100% completion ******

I hadn't played the original RE2 going into this, so my review doesn't have any nostalgic boost attached to it! For a game this highly rated I was disappointed at soundtrack and writing. It's filled with cringy dialogues. I think some of it is straight from the original game, which I'd question if you're improving everything about the game why not improve the script too. I also found the soundtrack rather bland with nothing standout that I'd play in my car on my way to work.

However the gameplay is quite tense and fun, and the graphics are amazing as all the other modern Resident Evil games. That slow paced survival gameplay was the main reason that I still did a couple of playthroughs even after 100% completion, just because how much fun it was and because of all the amazing unlockable weapons and costumes. Not to mention the very cool changes in each playthrough between the two main characters. Also level design is sublime and the interconnected map reminds me a lot of Dark Souls level design philosophy. 

It was quite a fun achievement list as well, most of them including collectibles can be done without a guide. Although the Extra modes was where the fun ended for me. That's where the game forget all about slow paced survival game design, and throws seemingly unending enemies at you. With "No way out" extra mode being the worst offender, where the game puts you in a tight space and throws 100 zombies at you to kill with somewhat limited resources! "Extra modes" aside, overall a very fun achievements which take 50 - 60 hours to complete.

This is a game that does everything nearly perfectly:
     
     The difficulty is just hard enough to create tension with you and your environment, but just easy enough to where the mechanics are easily accessible and allow for a gentle skill curve. There are multiple game modes and story lines the player can follow up on that keeps the stories and their respective progression relatively fresh.
     I find it really impressive how the action, survival, and horror mechanics all click with one another, allowing for a truly unforgettable experience. Each of the two stories between Leon and Claire feel unique to each other, making it worth playing them each thoroughly.
     The controls are very intuitive and responsive, feel both smooth and snappy, which allows for a very satisfying gameplay loop that rarely gets tiring.
     My only con with the game though is that if a new resident evil player comes to play completely blind and finds themselves in a really difficult spot, and has used up a large amount of the finite resources given to them, the difficulty gradually spikes, making it quite frustrating at times. But as long as you think in terms of "what can i afford to use" rather that "whats everything i can use", you'll be perfectly good to go.
     It is very very much worth it to anyone considering getting this...

I played through the game on PS4/5 many times before the PC version. This is a great Resident Evil and a superior remake in some many ways, but also it is a terrible RE2 Remake in many other ways. It should have been homerun, but it really isn't for many that will have fond memories of the original. For a thumbs up this is about to be extremely negative. 

One of the biggest grips is there really is no real "Zapping System" form the original present here, and I feel like the game just isn't a proper remake without. Run A and B are pretty much the same with no interlocking story. Your second run fights the same bosses and many of the same story beats with Leon and Clarie never interacting past one interaction and a couple of letters. While you really had to excuse some concessions in the original, I would have hoped this would have been improved for the remake not negated. The replay value is seriously hurt by this. 

"The Story" is more fleshed out in the original and a continuation of the RE1 but too many details left out in the remake especially that RE1 happened and RE2 is the indirect outcome of RE1. 

"Controls" are infinitely better than the original but also purposely made worst for sake of survival horror. This may or may not bug you. This makes sense in some ways but in others doesn't. Other than RE4 all of the newer Resident Evils whether 1st person or 3rd person the player is somewhat purposely gimped in the controls for the sake of the survival horror. RE2 leaned far heavier in the Action than Horror, and I really would have rather have seen it control more like that. More like RE4 and less purposely made worse. 

"HDR" is a train wreak on PC in the REngine. It seems to have been this way since the Ray tracing update, which broke it in different ways in every Resident Evil game. The best way I could find to make it work more reliably is the turn it off in game and turn on Auto-HDR in Win 11 because the info is already there and just works so much better. Special K can also be used to fix HDR as well if you prefer that. Ray Tracing and HDR effects in REngine are very subtle, but it doesn't change they are a mess on PC. 
HDR is either washed out or busted and in game controls don't offer enough control over brightness to fix it. Many PC monitors don't have enough controls on the monitor itself to fix it so the only way to fix it is by using desktop controls, which usually the in game HDR has a fit if you alt tab.  

One thing I will say is that "Ultrawide" even to the extreme ends of the spectrum with "Super Ultrawide" are fantastic. This game looks glorious @ 7680x2160 (32x9 aspect & dual 4k) with a little DLSS, some settings adjustments, and a beefy enough system you can easily hit 120fps.

Overall I do like the game but some of the most important aspects of RE2 are missing in the Remake unfortunately. This along with busted settings on PC  really make it harder to recommend if you enjoyed or remember the original.

Starting from my negative review of the first Resident Evil Revelations, where I express my concerns over Capcom adding invasive DRM "Enigma" to their backlog, all the reviews I'm going to post will contain the same message - for the same purpose.

To Capcom: I will keep posting negative review for ALL your games, whether or not they now include your invasive DRM, [b]until you remove it[/b] from all of them.

 I want to make it clear, I'm not doing this out of spite, nor does it come easy for me, and that's saying something.
I'm not against use of DRM. I'm against being screwed over, having a company I respect dropping malware into some of my favorite games effectively denying me access to them.

Your crusade to stop others from using weird mods (especially since they won't stop, either way) in your products shouldn't involve people who practically never use them, like me, from playing your games as they are.

Please, do sort out your priorities, CAPCOM. I am [i]not[/i] enjoying this.

I have been a long time fan of the Resident Evil series. RE2 (1998) was the first game in the series that I played as a kid, played so much that I knew this game like the back of my hand. After so many years they finally gave what the fans have been asking for and they did not disappoint. The remake had some changes but they were good ones. Both versions are great and I wouldn't say that one is better than the other, they are both great in their own ways. 

Great for someone new to the series and might even get them to try the OG version.
those vine guys were terrifying. beautiful graphics, fun puzzles, and zombies that just won't die make this game exttremely enjoyable, i finished my first playthrough was finished in just two nights.

Survival Horror at its best. It has everything a Resident Evil game is known for: horror, item management, disempowerment, and some really interesting puzzles. The entire experience is so tight and well-crafted that playing the B-scenarios (which have just few differences) still feels as fresh and frightening as the first run.
Really Enjoying this game. Having played the original then returning to this game I have a deep respect for what they were doing with this game.

Despite cut content and the lame way they handled the zapping system from the original, this game holds up as the modern gold standard for survival horror. I genuinely don't think Capcom has lived up to what they pulled off with this game since, the RE3 remake was plain bad, RE8 was an action horror like RE4, and RE4R is back to linear action horror, and is considerably more janky than this game.

But this game? This game feels like an extension of everything good about 2002's RE1 remake. Resources are scarce and enemies are tough, so getting through the game requires a combination of planning and careful consideration of when and where to use your ammo. The game is fairly challenging, without being too over the top or cheap like RE8's VoS mode or the other bullshit meme difficulties RE games have been adding in recent years (not including RE7 Madhouse, that's actually well made.) Beating the game isn't too hard, but beating it quickly, or achieving challenge runs, will test your map and enemy knowledge, as well as your ability to stay calm and plan a route. Getting that S+ takes raw skill and practice, it feels fair and getting the S+ rewards feels earned, it's just excellent.

The enemy roster is a bit smaller than the original, but every enemy type poses a unique threat relative to the others, and the way they're used in the extra modes really forces you to understand their mechanics. Additionally, as mentioned, the A/B scenarios have been gutted in favor of what is essentially just an arrange mode that's the same for both characters. It's sad to see the system gone, but overall this remake holds up as a solid survival horror game, something other games should be held to as a standard of quality. 

Highly, highly recommend any RE or Survival Horror fan play this at least once.

(H.U.N.K) ːuc_corpsheadː
●Alpha Team leader and possible 1st Squad leader. Nicknamed "Grim Reaper or Mr.Death".Hunk is the code-name of an Umbrella Security Service operator, who was the leader of the ill-fated Alpha Team in the employment of Umbrella. Cold, silent, and devoid of emotion, he is ruthless. He and the U.B.C.S. Sergeant, Nikolai Zinoviev, were considered to be "rivals".

ːre2umbrellaː(U.M.B.R.E.L.L.A)ːre2umbrellaː
●The origins of the Umbrella Corporation lie with the eugenics movements that dominated Europe and North American debate in the early 20th century. Its three most prominent founding members were Dr. Oswell E. Spencer, The Earl Spencer; Dr. Edward Ashford, 5th Earl Ashford, and Dr. James Marcus, who were university classmates, with further early work from Marcus' protégé, Brandon Bailey; the 16th Earl Beardsley and his daughter, Mylène and France's House of Henry, of which Christine and her father belonged. All were virologists with some associations with the eugenics movement either themselves or by association to another prominent figure.Umbrella's immediate pre-history truly begins in 1966, when Dr. Marcus developed a hypothesis that a mythical West African flower known as Stairway of the Sun bestowed powers to its consumers by a mutagenic viral infection. In a trip to the Ndipaya tribal lands, the fabled flower was discovered in an underground garden and a virus discovered within it. However, flowers cultivated in the United States failed to replicate the virus. Requiring significant funding beyond their aristocratic links to bring about their eugenics dream, Spencer formed Umbrella Pharmaceuticals on behalf of Ashford and an indifferent Marcus and established a base in the Ndipaya garden so Progenitor samples could be transported over the Atlantic instead. Requiring more money, the three agreed to a plan later known as the "t-Virus Project", where they would independently develop strains of Progenitor to sell to the US military as a weapon.The umbrella symbol represents protection and safety, but in reality it becomes a symbol of danger and death. The red and white colors represent danger and warning, while the black background represents the darkness.

(U.B.C.S) ːre3ubcsː
●"Umbrella Biohazard Countermeasure Servicewas" a private military force owned by the Umbrella Corporation, specializing in rescue operations during biohazard outbreaks. It was founded by former Soviet Colonel Sergei Vladimir. The U.B.C.S. primarily recruited former soldiers and militiamen who had been incarcerated and, thus, could be offered a new life. At its largest in 1998, this force consisted of at least four platoons, designed Alpha through Delta, making for a compliment of as many as 120 mercenaries. It suffered near total destruction during the operation in Raccoon City.
●Members:
Carlos Oliveira,Nikolai Zinoviev,Mikhail Viktor,Tyrell Patrick,Murphy Seeker,Arnold,Sergei Vladimir

(U.S.S) ːre2umbrellaː
●The Umbrella Security Service (abbreviated "U.S.S.") was a security force under the control of Umbrella HQ. It was one of several paramilitary organisations used by the company, including the Umbrella Biohazard Countermeasure Service, the Undertaker Unit and the Intelligence Division. The U.S.S was an expansive organisation, with branches specially trained and equipped for different situations, ranging from guarding Umbrella facilities to covert operations. It was dissolved in 2003, after Umbrella declared bankruptcy.The first known use of U.S.S. for this method was in 1988 when Dr. James Marcus was assassinated by two guards on the orders of Umbrella CEO Dr. Lord Spencer.[ In 1993, the U.S.S. college was moved to Rockfort Island, under the command of Lord Ashford. Along with a new military training centre, a concentration camp was built for the guarding of Umbrella's enemies.
●Members:
HUNK, J. Martinez, A. Kirkpatrick
●Backup team
Nighthawk , Miguel, GOBLIN 6, Derek ,Luke

(U.I.D) ːre2umbrellaː
●The Umbrella Intelligence Division was an intelligence-gathering organization answering directly to Umbrella Headquarters. In 1998, Alex Wesker was a member of this organization, filing a report on the death of Albert Wesker, who himself had been a member since 1991.
●Members:
Dr. Alex Wesker, Dr. Albert Wesker, Lucy Yen, Daniel Fabron

========================================================

While this remake of Resident Evil 2 might not be the greatest survival horror game of all time (there are some other great contenders for this title that I believe surpass RE2make), it is THE definitive survival horror game for people who are unfamiliar with the genre.

- incredibly beautiful graphics that still hold up a few years later (with ray-tracing and DLSS/FSR support!)
- smooth and precise over-the-shoulder gameplay with resource management that's very easy to grasp but requires the player to keep paying attention at their ammo and such at all times
- simple puzzle solving embedded in some of the most clever level design I've seen in a game of this type
- a completely seamless experience in which you can go from the very starting point all the way to the end without a single loading time
- a lot of replayability thanks to the various playable scenarios
- good scares here and there but nothing that would cause a panic attack either meaning the player can keep focusing on playing the game without fearing for cheap jumpscares and such
- and overall a very faithful yet at the same time modern recreation of every iconic location of the original game.

Add to all this the fact that you absolutely don't need prior knowledge of the Resident Evil franchise to understand the story (though some minor lore bits may fly over non-fans' heads), and you get what I personally consider to be THE absolute perfect game to introduce someone who doesn't play survival horror games to this genre. If you have a friend who's never played that kind of games before, have them play this one and then the RE4 remake as well. And make sure they skip the RE3 remake because this one is a travesty.

I love this game, but:

Warning: Capcom is adding unfamiliar DRM to their back catalogue of games. This corp has repeatedly shown their stance towards mods in their games as well and seem to be taking action. I would caution you against purchasing any capcom product that contains this DRM as it’s unfamiliar, and untrustworthy. For now, if you really want this game, or any capcom game, I would stress that you watch and observe to see what happens in the near-ish future. 

Please note that there is a lot of misinfo circulating about with regards to this situation. Please do your due diligence and research everything and even fact check myself before making a final judgement. I am doing the best I can to sift through the false info and properly inform myself and will update this review accordingly.

DRM is not always a bad thing, if used correctly, it protects initial sales. Then good publishers will remove it later on allowing for better experiences. I am upset when DRM harms performance, which it often does (like Jedi Survivor). I find that inexcusable, poor performance that screws over the paying customer should always be frowned upon. Recently, denuvo was removed from RE8, which is good. But, when it was first added the game suffered many problems which modders had to remedy until its removal. Enigma seems to be capcom’s replacement for denuvo.

Earlier this month, RE Rev was updated and performance was harmed. Shortly after, capcom reversed the update. This is concerning because REV was released almost 11 years ago and the game’s already been cracked (both the pc and 3ds version), as with most older games. This update to add DRM to an old game is incredibly fishy, especially with how it came with no announcement from the publishers themselves. Almost as if somebody was trying to hide it.
Denuvo a very good DRM, since there’s few who know how to crack it, even then it’s tough. Denuvo itself costs ~$5,000 per month for the license, ~$60,000 a year. A game’s sales can’t keep up with the fee forever, and the DRM has to be removed/replaced to salvage income. 

Enigma is $59,920 cheaper. It costs about $400 for initial purchase, and $80 annually for upkeep. Enigma was checked with a virus scanner, and got 34 positive flags, ~%50 of what Virus Total checks for. Scanners can have false positives. The REV .exe will show 1 positive flag (at least for me). This one is easily written off as a false positive. Generally low single digits are fine. When you are getting into double digits, there’s problem. The dev for Enigma has been purported to have a fake address in the US, and the domain name’s been alleged to be bought through a Moscow front (fact check me). This DRM is incredibly sneaky, and according to others, is capable of quietly worming its way through your PC. These factors, even if partially false, are concerning, keep this away from your pc.

On October 25 of 2023, there was a capcom R&D presentation.
“RE:2023 Anti-cheat and Anti-Piracy Measures in PC Games Recommendations for In-House Production”
14:00 – 16:00 ish. The pres states that all mods, unless officially supported, are no different than cheating. Yes, with regards to DRM, all foreign code is considered tampering. But, they go further, and say that mods tarnish the product’s (and corp’s) image as they may be mistaken for legitimate parts of said product. Earlier last July, a tournament competitor in a SF6 match forgot to disable his Chun-Li n*de mod. This is likely what capcom is referencing. But, they’ve taken things further.

Capcom is no newb to “nuking” youtube creators’ channels. They’ve removed content and channels for discussing info that the corp themselves leaked. Capcom has taken action against MH creators, most notably speedrunners. This was because their videos featured mods, some as harmless as to simply aid with running or slightly modify the experience (skins/costumes/fov). Capcom has tried to take down modders’ work as well. Yes, these modders were making n*de mods, but never the less they came after a modder, who’s to stop them from taking things further and coming for everyone else?

Considering the corp’s past and recent actions and statements, it’s safe to say that they are/will be coming after modders. People like to add that Enigma was added to RE5 last year and that no one has had any problems. Even so, ghost updates are sketchy, since there’s no point in copy protecting a long-cracked game. For now, I advise customers to watch, listen, and wait to see what the corp does. We can choose to make it apparent to them that mods are an inevitable factor of PC gaming. I know where my stance is, if I can’t make Leon sound like Kermit then I’ll happily take my money elsewhere.

Thank you if you read this far, I’d be happy if you had any info (legit that is) or comments you’d like to share.

Warning: Pseudo-rant ahead
I have one more speculation (not an allegation or accusation, simply a theory coming straight outa my rear end). I think that modders are beginning to pose a business threat to companies like capcom. 

This corp is known to have a lot of stinker dlcs.
Example:
REV has dlc, 2 fun characters, and 4 more that suck. There’s 2 shoddy weapon reskins and 2 parts packs that boost damage. All of these things are already in the purchased game. This leads to my theory, capcom is scared of modders. We can simply repaint the base G18 and make it look like jessica’s, and have a better gun too. The same goes for parker’s gun dlc. Whip out CE and give yourself the gun parts. For one customer, the corp has lost out of possibly $4. Apply that to a large portion of the consumer base, even more money lost out.

Another, Street Fighter 6. Its dlc has one year character pass costs $30. You get 4 characters..and character colors. Not outfits, colors; and in game currency…which you can earn for free. The same goes for the $50 ultimate dlc, it just adds 2 backgrounds (stages) and some costume colors with a little extra in game currency. You can get so much more for this amount, just look at the steam reviews.

We also see modders making far better outfits for free. The recent Yor update was bad too, just a worthless reskin. So, modders will fix it and make it look better. Both of these scenarios DO harm the their image, it just shows that some dudes in blender can do so much better than a multi-billion dollar corp. 

Their claims about “public order”, I believe, are total bs. I believe this corp recognizes that it churns out dumpster fire (ignoring the rare cases like Separate Ways, which is only $10) and are too afraid to admit that they want money. At least EA is obvious abt it.

The same goes for so many other capcom dlcs.

I love these games, I am a big fan of RE, DD, MH and more. Yes, your writers often suck, but I still love the stories in these games. I love to play them, I have so many happy memories of these wonderful little gems from my childhood. I WANT to support the talented, skillful, and passionate people behind these pieces of digital-art. No not the suits, I mean the programmers, artists, musicians, voice actors, mocap dudes, sound guys etc. But, unfortunately, these people work for a corp who is rapidly growing greedier, and at a scary pace. Soon, they’ll be just another EA, a money vacuum that cares about microtransactions more than making a great experience that keeps people comin back to that game and for more in the future.

Whoever is currently in charge (in my opinion) is out of touch with what customers actually want and will support. I have blacklisted this corp from my steam page, and it will be sometime, if ever, I consider purchasing their products ever again given their recent statements, actions, practices, and routine behavior. 

End of Review.

Btw capcom employee who reads this, this is all one ginormous opinion, not an allegation or accusation, just a giant word vomit from my unintelligent ignoramus brain.

Okay. This is my 3rd review to warn ANYONE AT ALL reading this.
To begin of course, the game that I'm reviewing is none other but a good game that Capcom always delivers. However, this changes things when they've announced about their new DRM that they will eventually add to all of their games, lets talk about that. The DRM (Enigma DRM) isn't at all known or popular throughout the world so far. Though knowing that the company is unknown, its already obvious on whats to be expected, bad things.

Capcom had picked this DRM out of the blue, maybe throughout the recommendations of their employee or something. The main reason they've done this is to suppress modding. Why are they doing this you might ask? if you're out of the loop, go look up the incident on SF6 back in 2023, its probably the reason why they're trying to suppress mods. I'll be real with everyone, I don't mod Capcom games at all because my experiences on Bethesda games have gotten me exhausted to even bother. But I do have respect for modders as they offer a longer lifespan for games. But going back to the DRM, this thing is a literal Malware. For one that has been confirmed by some customers on DRM Supported Capcom games, those customer's device have been infected with at least 34 virus that comes with the DRM. Capcom is putting us all at risk if we want to play their games. 

For now, I haven't heard much of Capcom since they revert the DRM on one of their games. They've been silent for sometime now. But going forward to anyone that reads this, I do not recommend you to get anything from Capcom at this time. I've lost devices to Malwares in the past, which is why this has gotten me worked up. I sincerely hope that you guys don't meet the same fate as i did while convincing you guys from buying a potential Malware as well.

Literally one of the best remakes in videogame history, it's about equal to the RE4 remake, I'd say. Which is extremely high praise. This is the definitive way to experience Resident Evil 2 if you are new to the franchise.

The graphics, sound design, mechanics, all top notch. I will admit that the atmosphere is better in my opinion if you buy the OG soundtrack DLC and use that instead, the new soundtrack is basically unnoticeable and you'll hear no music at all most of the time. It's subjective, in many ways the game is scarier when there is nothing breaking the silence except the groans and limping footsteps of nearby zombies. In other ways, the retro OST establishes a more tense atmosphere.

The replayability is solid, the game requires multiple playthroughs to experience the "true ending" but each one is different. It really doesn't get old and this game is one of the most replayable in the series. I love the atmosphere, and the amazing graphics when maxed out makes this game so easy on the eyes, walking around the RPD is a visual treat.

It's a great game, it overshadows RE3 remake by a lot, still bummed that RE3 didn't live up to the standards set by this game. They didn't fumble this one, and have created a real masterpiece for us to enjoy.

Resident Evil 2 Remake is an absolute blast. It's the kind of game you replay because it's just too much fun. Whether you're a Resident Evil fan or into survival horror, this one's a no-brainer.

The challenging survival horror gameplay and immensely satisfying combat keep drawing me back for more. The intense boss fights and insane attention to animation detail make every part of the gameplay gold!

The atmosphere is awesome, and the level design is smart – the police station is like a maze, and with every playthrough, you discover something new. Taking on the game as Leon and Claire provides two different perspectives, ensuring it never gets old.

The only thing that bugs me a bit is the connection between Leon and Claire's stories. It could be smoother; it feels a bit like they're in parallel universes.

A solid 9/10, this one's a must-play!

I can't in good faith recommend this given Capcom's stance when it comes to modding. I kind of feel like they could have done better with alternate costumes for this. Example, Leon could have had his RE4 coat and Dante as his alternate costumes. In addition, there are some choices that I'm not a fan of. Ivies got a downgrade in terms of their new designs, which is something else modding had fixed and I would have overlooked if they didn't mess this up. 

In addition to some of the stuff that modding could fix, the A and B scenarios feel like they're heavily cut and paste jobs compared to the N64 version, which changed elements depending on who you were playing as first as well as carrying over elements from your actions in the A scenario to the B scenario. Plus there were a number of documents in the N64 game that I feel like should have been included in this game such as the Want Ad.

Capcom has decided to begin rolling out new DRM called Enigma that prevents mods as well as drops performance of all games. They have currently recalled it to fix performance issues. 

However they claim that mods are no different from cheating and also that there are mods that "are offensive to public order and morals." As such not only are they seeking to block all modding but they are copyright striking youtube videos that contain mods.

Some of these users have now had their youtube channels deleted permanently. What I find "offensive to public order and morals" is interfering with, and taking away people's forms of income.  Well, two can play at that game, not only do I not recommend purchasing any Capcom game but I'm sure a lot more people will now move to pirating their single player games as once the DRM is cracked they'll be able to mod again.

It's even crazier that in the past Capcom have officially supported Speedrunning which is a big part of the community, and they often contain mods. 

The real reason they want to remove mods is probably because if you look at Street Fighter 6, they're trying to charge you £15-20 for a costume while modders do it for free. They also probably want to sell their ripoff game-skip purchases.

I waited until Denuvo was removed before purchasing - I did not, however, expect that another DRM would later be added. After the effort Valve have made in getting games to work on Linux and Steam Deck, I sincerely hope that they will try to convince Capcom not to add new DRM to their catalogue of games.

Capcom is adding DRM Enigma Protector to its new and even old games on Steam. This DRM decreases game performance by 15 fps, causes frequent stuttering and blocks modding.

Most of these games were cracked by pirates a long time ago and while pirates who didn't pay for the game play the games without the new DRM damaging the game's performance, those who paid for the game are suffering from the games' performance being impaired thanks to the new DRM. This encourages piracy.

Many Capcom games have problems that have not been officially fixed by the company and there are mods made by the passionate community of fans that fix these problems. Mods greatly improve games, increasing their replayability. Blocking mods is unacceptable.

That's why I'm leaving this negative review. If you were planning on buying this game, don't do it. I recommend buying these games on consoles where your performance is not hampered by DRM.

If Capcom decides to go back and remove this new DRM, I will go back and remove my negative review as well.

Overall a very enjoyable experience. Capcom never ceases to impress. The gun play felt very smooth and I thoroughly enjoyed the puzzles.

A couple of downsides:
1. not being able to pause while being hit for some reason, I might want to load back a save because I'm in a losing fight, why do you stop me from pausing? Should I just watch myself get beat up?
2. the skip button for cut scenes isn't very clear; you need to pause and then press space key to actually skip a cut scene. Why not allow me to skip the cut scene while outside of the pause menu as well? I didn't realise I could actually skip cut scenes until the last final clips of the game because not many games do it like that.
3. the game changed the difficulty automatically for me when I wasn't doing very well, in the end this actually resulted in a better gameplay experience for me however, it was a bit of a blow to my ego to just change the difficulty without even asking, did I really suck that badly? Lol

TL;DR: It's a 4/10 game. It's from the '90s so take it with a grain of salt. It's just kind of there. I don't have massive nostalgia for Resident Evil because I never played it in the '90s on PS1. The graphics are good but the story is meh and split up over multiple playthroughs. You have to play the game FOUR times to get the entire story. The boss fights are stupid. You're probably better off watching a walk-through video on Youtube and buying the newer games.

Longer version: The graphics are good. It's the first thing you'll notice about this game. However, the intro video of the trucker eating the burger is the most disgusting part of the game. I don't need to hear LOUD LIP SMACKS AND CHOMPING right in my ear in the first 30 seconds of a game.

Unfortunately, this is the kind of game that you MUST watch a walk-through in order to play it. Don't bother trying to play it without one because you will just get frustrated. You'll still get frustrated with the walk-through but slightly less so. There's very limited ammunition so you cannot kill every single zombie. You have to know who to fight and who not to. You'll also need to know exactly where everything is since you can't fight everything. Hence the walk-through.

The boss fights are a pain in the rear. There's really only two boss fights and they're back to back right at the end of the game which is weird. You'd think they'd have like a mid-point boss fight and then a finale. The boss fights are bad because there's only one specific way to accomplish them. There's no room for creativity. You have to have the timing perfect to be standing in the right spot at the right time so you don't get hit. It basically requires you to know exactly where the hit boxes are. If you get hit you might as well reload the game because your character will naturally enter a very long, drawn out animation during which you're locked out of control. However, the boss is free to move about and wind up for swing #2. This means that the boss has started swing #2 right about when you're going to gain control of your character again. Swing #2 is a freebie for the boss. You can take about 3 hits max before you're dead and when you die it's a pain in the rear. The death animations are very, very long and drawn out. So much so that you're better off ALT+F4ing to close the game quickly and then open it up again and try again.

You cannot dodge attacks; you can only slowly walk away and hope you don't get hit. Also the controls for secondary attacks are weird. Press and hold space bar, wait for animation, then left click and wait for another animation before you can attack. However, at that point the boss has moved away from where your grenade is going so it was all pointless.

And then to top it all off, if you defeat the boss, guess what you get to do it again because this game has FOUR playthroughs that you  MUST do to get the entire story. What a stupid idea. I'm fine with having it split up between two separate stories. That actually sounds kind of cool. But this is just the same story 95% the same as you already did. What a dumb idea.

With all that being said, get the game if you really want to relive that '90s video-game frustration. If you don't want that then just watch a Youtube video on the story and purchase one of the later games.

Look, I get it, I am a bloody coward. Me and survival horror, being chased? Nah, I just can't.

But this is Resident Evil 2, the remake. I watched probably 2-3 LPs already, I know the story and I agree with the general consensus that this is one of the greatest remakes ever made. I really wanted to buy it and play it and reward the developers for their work. So I started a normal game as Claire and managed about 2 1/2 hours (just before Mr. X turns up), only shitting my pants once thanks to a surprise licker attack. But then I just couldn't continue (until I cheated, see below).

I am 42, man, my heart cannot take this ("anymore?", nah, I could never take this). I played S.T.A.L.K.E.R. and Metro and other games that can scare you with their atmosphere, but there I could always defend myself. I could never play Amnesia or those new fancy survival horror games that are all the rage with the cool kids. I am a bloody coward.

So I got myself a good ol' trainer. Those tools still exist, apparently, and they bloody work. Mr. X? One shot froze him forever (unless he was spawned in by the game at set pieces). I know what most of you are thinking? Mate, you basically destroyed the core concept of the game. And I know. And I am sorry. But that was the only cheat I did, I fought those f'n lickers and those stupid tree monsters and that cunt of a doctor that cared more about work than family (oh and her husband, too, I guess)... and I won those fights fair and square. It doesn't count in the eyes of the hardcore RE heroes, but I am happy that I got to live another day without a heart attack (*knocks on wood*).

RE 2 is a really good game. You don't need my opinion on this, it's already got a good reputation. I am just here to tell everyone who maybe is as scared as I am of being chased by an unbeatable monster, that it is okay if you, like me, resort to bloody cheating to still be able to play this game. It's fun even without a heart attack, I promise.

Now please commence the public flogging because I dared to not be as hardcore as you.
