Amazing game, mixing horror with gore similarly to Dead Space. Actually, there are many other similarities between the two that are cool to spot. I don't really love pure horror games, I find this mix really enjoyable, since you are given a chance to trade blows with the enemy. Both main characters are so likeable and well portrayed even for a short game like this one. Gorgeous to look at, outstanding levels with abundant use of backtracking. I love the setting and the movie-like presentation. Gameplay-wise, it is super interesting and demanding, always keeping you on your toes. Resource-management and strategy are key to make it out alive. Sometimes a fight is not worth the bullets, other times you won't be given a choice. Brutal initial cinematics, was immediately immersed and that is key for players to keep playing a game. Seems obvious, but so many (yes even AAAs) fail at this to this day.

As a [i]Resident Evil[/i] fan since its inception, I was in absolute glee when I finally played this remake. Everything is faithful to the original, from the story to the maps to the environments and even the weapons, just updated for modern hardware and expanded on to better tell the story. I would definitely call this a worthy sequel to the remake of the first game.

My only complaints involve the VAs for Leon and Claire and the decision to make Claire a brunette. I get that having the originals voice these characters again was unlikely but Capcom didn't even try to find sound-alike ones. Also, Claire is very clearly a redhead with auburn hair in every prior game and CGI movie she appears in. I know there are mods to fix that but it still irritates me that Capcom would go the way of Hollywoke and try to cancel real redheads.

Resident Evil 2 Remastered doesn’t just breathe new life into a classic; it turns it into a modern masterpiece. The visual overhaul is nothing short of spectacular, transforming the dark and eerie corridors of Raccoon City into a visually stunning and chilling environment. The attention to detail in character models, environments, and gruesome zombies is commendable, creating an immersive and terrifying experience.

The narrative remains as compelling as ever, with Leon Kennedy and Claire Redfield’s stories beautifully reimagined. The game retains the essence of the original while introducing new elements that add layers to the characters and the overall plot. The atmosphere is palpable, enhanced by a revamped sound design that keeps you on edge throughout your journey.

One of the standout improvements is the refined gameplay mechanics. The controls are more responsive, and the updated camera system adds a modern touch without losing the classic survival horror feel. The balance between action and horror is expertly handled, providing intense and satisfying combat moments while preserving the spine-chilling suspense that Resident Evil is known for.

The pacing is spot-on, ensuring that players are consistently engaged and invested in the unfolding horror. Whether you’re a veteran fan of the series or a newcomer, Resident Evil 2 Remastered is a remarkable achievement. It not only pays homage to the original but sets a new standard for how classic games can be reimagined for a modern audience, offering a truly unforgettable and chilling gaming experience.

Absolutely amazing game. I've beaten it multiple times and had so much fun with it I decided to 100% the game, that's where my one and only problem with the game lies. 

I've gotten almost every achievement in the game until I ran into the "complete No way out (no training mode)". Difficulty wasn't the issue here. I've seen some others with the glitch but in my game once I kill some zombies they refuse to despawn (the zombies in this game mode explode after death allowing the next wave of them to spawn in) thus not allowing me to complete this game mode and not earn the achievement. It sucked after completing the game many times to even get to the point to unlock the game mode. From what I've seen the glitch goes back to 2019 and wasn't fixed even in 2024. 

Besides that it's a really fun game to sink a lot of time into. If you have this glitch like me just don't plan on 100%ing the game, if not it's definitely worth a buy!

My only complaint would be that they really stretched their assets by reusing content over and over. I played Leon's Campaign and then Claire's Campaign, and Claire's was largely the same as Leon's with maybe 20% of it being different. When I beat Claire's and then realized I had to also beat one of the two's Ending B's- a weird re-adventure with slightly different progression and loot layouts- all for the sake of seeing the one-minute final boss and 2 minutes of cutscenes? I just looked that up on youtube and called the game done. I'm good on having to play the exact same maps for a third time in a row.

So if you want to be efficient, when you beat one character's campaign, you should play the next person's Campaign B so that you can get all the content knocked out.

Resident Evil 2 undertakes a complete overhaul of graphics, gameplay dynamics, and narrative, delivering an immersive gaming encounter.

The recreation of Raccoon City's locales is nothing short of extraordinary, boasting breathtaking graphics that establish a compelling atmosphere, intensifying the game's inherent tension and horror. The character redesign for protagonists Leon Kennedy and Claire Redfield is nothing short of stellar, endowing them with a heightened level of realism and intricate detail.

Furthermore, the game preserves the core essence of survival horror, featuring demanding combat mechanics, intricate puzzles, and a strategic approach to resource management encompassing ammunition and restorative items. The sound design plays a pivotal role, significantly enhancing the overall eerie and tense ambiance.

The narrative undergoes an expansive and profound transformation, providing a more enriched experience for both those acquainted with the original storyline and newcomers to the game. The dual perspectives of Leon and Claire's campaigns offer a distinctive outlook on the unfolding events within the zombie-infested city.

"Resident Evil 2 Remake" stands as a masterstroke in the survival horror genre, seamlessly melding nostalgic elements with cutting-edge technology to deliver a captivating and chilling experience that resonates with players.

Resident Evil 2 Remake, released in 2019, stands as a shining example of how to masterfully reimagine a classic. Capcom successfully resurrected the survival horror masterpiece, delivering a haunting and intense experience that pays homage to the original while introducing modern gaming elements.

Visually, Resident Evil 2 Remake is a triumph. The RE (Reach for the Moon) Engine showcases its capabilities, bringing the decaying Raccoon City to life with breathtaking detail. From the eerily dimly lit corridors of the police station to the grotesque designs of the undead, the game's atmosphere is nothing short of captivating. The photorealistic graphics contribute to the overall immersion, enhancing the sense of dread and tension.

The narrative remains faithful to the original, following Leon S. Kennedy and Claire Redfield as they navigate the zombie-infested city. However, Capcom took the opportunity to deepen the story, providing more depth to characters and introducing new narrative elements. This narrative expansion not only serves as a treat for series veterans but also engages newcomers with its compelling and well-paced storytelling.

One of the standout features of Resident Evil 2 Remake is its innovative over-the-shoulder perspective, a departure from the fixed-camera angles of the original. This shift in perspective enhances the player's connection to the characters and intensifies the fear of the unknown. The tight controls and responsive aiming system make combat satisfyingly tense, emphasizing resource management and strategic decision-making.

The revamped gameplay mechanics extend beyond combat. Puzzles are cleverly designed, challenging players to think critically and rewarding them with a sense of accomplishment. The interconnected environment encourages exploration, and the ever-looming threat of the relentless Tyrant (Mr. X) adds an extra layer of tension, transforming the game into a nerve-wracking experience.

Resident Evil 2 Remake excels in the audio department, using haunting ambient sounds and a chilling soundtrack to create an atmosphere that constantly keeps players on edge. The groans of zombies, creaking floorboards, and distant echoes contribute to the overall sense of dread, making each encounter a heart-pounding experience.

The game's replay value is commendable, offering two distinct campaigns for Leon and Claire, each providing a unique perspective on the unfolding catastrophe. Additionally, the multiple difficulty settings and unlockable content provide incentives for players to return to Raccoon City and face its horrors in different ways.

In conclusion, Resident Evil 2 Remake is a masterclass in survival horror, seamlessly blending nostalgic elements with modern design to create an unforgettable experience. It successfully captures the essence of the original while introducing innovative features that elevate it to new heights. Whether you're a long-time fan of the series or a newcomer to survival horror, Resident Evil 2 Remake is an absolute must-play that sets a high standard for the genre.

Another excellent remake on Capcom's part. This is an awesome modern take on the classic 1998 Resident Evil 2. You'll explore the iconic locations such as the Raccoon City Police Department, solve puzzles and defeat bosses with the help of an Over The Shoulder Camera (like RE4) and brought alive by the RE Engine's visual prowess. 

Overall, you're getting a streamlined scenario with the classic gameplay loop of item management, resource management, exploration and puzzle solving that have all made a successful transition to the new camera angle and presentation. You can aim freely but, in exchange the enemies take a lot of hits to go down. The new RPD layout makes A LOT more sense than the original, the Sewers feel creepier with ample use of shadows and lighting, and the Lab has a totally different feel than before. It's also very replayable thanks to multiple difficulties, two characters with two scenarios each, and side content to go along with a runtime that doesn't overstay it's welcome. 

My only gripes are that there's no "Zapping" System (picking up an item as Claire during Scenario A would make it disappear for Leon in his B scenario and vice versa). And that the scenarios don't really fit together well. In this the A scenario of your choosing is what actually happens and you have to imagine what the other character is doing because the B scenario has things that literally can't happen to both. The B scenarios were an afterthought and it shows. 

Even with those flaws, this is an excellent game that's well worth playing whether you're a veteran or newcomer. The Over The Shoulder Camera and movement should feel right at home for newer players or are used to modern games making this an accessible point of entry.

The remake of 'Resident Evil 2' is one of the great games of the last decade. It is an awesome re-imagination of the original game, offering something for everybody - but you have to be able to stomach the horror aspects. This is a gruesome title. There is virtually nothing to complain about: plot and presentation, engaging main and side characters, gameplay and variety - this game has everything you could wish for. With Leon and Claire you get both a male and a female perspective on the plot, and this is a stroke of genius. Handholding is reduced to a minimum, yet it is nowhere as difficult as a Souls-like game. This game is the gold standard for remaking a game, a 9/10 - highly recommended.

I remembered beating the game and unlocking Scenario B, I remembered seeing how fast I could beat the game and seeing if I could do it without saving.
I figured it was all going to come right back to me once I started playing.
  
When I started playing, I quickly realized this was not the same game I remembered. Similar yes, but different.  Aiming is not the same but better, movement is not the same but better, atmosphere is much darker, more terrifying than I remember.  Walking through these halls, and seeing the scratches on the walls… a feeling of dread creeps over me.  Anxiousness begins kicking in, the fear has returned.  
Running through a door to get away from the undead hoard, and the feeling of safety quickly leaves you as the doors come crashing down behind you.  You receive no comfort in the pause menu while you mentally prepare yourself for the next door, as you listen to the constant eerie ambient noise. 

The sound is amazing, eerie, realistic, good voice acting.
Visuals are greatly improved from the past, really added some good cutscenes.
Gameplay is better than I was expecting, same story from the past but slightly twisted.
The controls feel really good, very smooth transitions.  More jump scares than ever. 

Replay value – Is High

Would I recommend this game: Yes!
What do I rate this game: 5/5

As a game: the survival horror triumph!
As a remake: homework done, but missed the spot.

1998 was a fine year to be alive. Hardly knew any English and used to be scared of much harmless things than zombies and only way to play the game through was on easiest difficulty with miniguns and rpgs and still having not a clue what was going on due a language barrier. When I got older I was able to find a guide from the internet in my language (Finnish) how to complete the game and few years after that I completed the whole thing without cheats and understanding the story without lose ends.

Thus I can say that I have wiped both Remake and the Original and their difference is not in their excellence for they both are greater than great. However, while graphically and room dimensionally Remake stands out for its benefit, the original wins in storytelling. Practically things are much the same and small changes work and are refreshing, but thing were Remake doesn't success is to create the immersion of parallel stories between the characters and this does not only affect negatively on the uniqueness of different scenarios, but also for replayability. In the original players were attracted to play the both sections A and B at least twice through by switching the order of the characters between sections, but in Remake this is not the case unfortunately and there is less reasons for replays and they even wiped few moments were player was able to impact some of the assets in Scenario B during Scenario A.

I have recently played few Remakes of old games and people use to complain a lot how their childhood is now ruined and bohoo this and that. Of course I could join the choir and talk about more straightforward puzzles, lighter atmosphere and go to pinpoint that Remake is nothing but a lazy, half arsed game which gots nothing on the classic, but I totally let that slide for Remake is a marvelous game all the way from the beginning til' the end. There is always a bright side of these Remakes and that is that we are once again able to enjoy these relics with a new vision, and just like zombies they won't die but raise up once in a while.

This game is very, very good and if you're into survival horror games you should play it.

Keep in mind the intended way to play this game is Leon / Claire A and then 2nd run on the other character. Don't do both on A and then both on B, it's not worth it.

Two main problems I have with the game.

First is Mr. X. During the police station chase it's less scary and more tedious. Jack from RE7 was a better implementation of the same mechanic in my opinion.

Second is that this remake skipped on a lot of the really cool mechanics to do with the first and second runs that the original had. The original A and B were two sides of the same story. If you fought a boss as Leon you would not have the exact same fight as Claire. If you picked up an item as Claire then it wouldn't be there for Leon. At one point there's a puzzle that requires both characters to have interacted with a panel before it unlocks. The remake ignores these nuances, and although the end result is still very good I can't help but feel it could have been so much better.

Despite that, this is one of those games that you just have to play.

I played this game after finishing the Resident Evil 3 and 4 remakes, and it might honestly be my favorite remake entry in the series so far. [b]TL;DR:[/b] buy it if you like third person horror games!

[h3]Pros[/h3]

- [b]Beautiful graphics and sound design[/b], which really breathe life into the horror aspect despite being played a third-person perspective
- A [b]decent length of play time[/b]; playing a single run is fun, but would highly recommend rounding out the story by using the "2nd run" option for the other player character at least
- [b]Reasonable difficulty curve[/b]; limited ammo can seem daunting at first, but with frequent saving (in non-hardcore mode) and some skilful inventory management, this heightens the challenge instead of feeling like a chore. 
    - You're [b]incentivized to seek out hidden items and areas[/b] to fully experience the game to get more resources, and the map tracker feature marking unexplored rooms as red is very helpful.
    - Keep an eye out for [b]helpful loading screen tips[/b] every time you die!
- Some really fun player [b]customization and mods[/b] available if you're into that!

[h3]Cons[/h3]

- For newcomers to the franchise, the layout of the RPD police station can be [b]labyrinthine and frustrating[/b]. The map addresses a lot of these concerns, though.
    - Even for non-newcomers, the amount of [b]backtracking[/b] involved can be very tedious. The player character's movements can feel a tad slow at times due to the lack of sprint, especially when being actively pursued by monsters.
    - You also [b]can't access the entire map[/b] on any single playthrough: a minor frustration, but can interfere with the OCD of having unexplored regions on the map.
- While I found the difficulty reasonable (as someone who feels they're a casual-average skill level gamer), this game pulls no punches and [b]throws you straight into action[/b] which can be daunting if you're unfamiliar (and taunts you to play the game on easy mode if you keep dying).
- Some of the [b]puzzles[/b] (2nd run chemical lab puzzle was one that comes to mind) can slow down the pace quite a bit amidst heavy action sequences.

The Resident Evil 2 Remake flawlessly recaptures the dread of the PS1 original while updating it for the modern era. Step into the zombie-infested streets of Raccoon City as Leon and Claire once again - this time with gorgeous new graphics.

The familiar police station and sewers have been expanded and improved. Solve new environmental puzzles and watch out for zombified lickers crawling on the ceiling - yikes!

Combat is weighty and satisfying thanks to the over-the-shoulder camera and intuitive controls. Line up clean headshots or blow zombies away up close with the trusty shotgun - feels so good!

The Tyrant Mr. X stalking you adds thrilling tension. Nothing like hearing his ominous footsteps rapidly approaching when you're low on ammo! Escape requires thinking on your feet.

With additional modes like The 4th Survivor, the RE2 Remake retains the challenge of the PlayStation original while modernizing it masterfully. Old and new fans alike owe it to themselves to experience survival horror done right!

Played this and re3 remake when they came out on Playstation 4. Excellent remake of one of my favorite games. It accurately retells the story and although the concept of separate areas and story telling from the original games have been removed, we still get to see all the important scenes that made re2 so iconic. This game perfectly captures the feeling of the original that I experienced back in 1998. With slightly less replay value than the original this game plays the perfect amount of time and doesn't overstay it's welcome to present the whole story. I'm happy that I was able to pick it up and play it on the go with my steamdeck.

This is my first introduction to the Resident Evil series and I must say this was very worth the purchase that was on sale. 

Perfect balance of the horror aspect, just enough to get the adrenaline going if its your first time playing, and not too much where you'd be constantly trying to brace for some scares.
In some other horror games, I personally think that those loud, abrupt jumpscares can be a total turnoff for the faint hearted players alike, but RE2 was definitely much easier to handle, to a point where i'd be itching to continue multiple runs of the game now. Currently progressing through Claire's storyline and im also looking forward to what changes on the 2nd runs of both Leon's and Claire's side.
Puzzles are quite easy to follow along, but can be tedious going around looking for clues and then going back to the puzzle spots.

Originally I would have rated it a 5/5 but the complete, content-rich excellent RE4 remake kinda shows this game up a tad, alongside RE3R which is just a hard not recommended if you're a fan of the PS1 games.

This game still has the best blend of action and horror among the remakes, and even after being spoiled by RE4's sublime combat, I came back to this (having over 1000 hours in just Claire's scenario alone on PS4) and it has aged just fine since 2019.  A solid 4/5 experience. There's cut content and a pretty hard to ignore lazy 2nd scenario mode, and some of the narrative doesn't make sense depending on who you pick to play as, but in terms of raw gameplay, visuals and sound design, this is one of Capcom's best.

Replay value, which is king for me, is also here in droves.

* Knife and grenade has multiple purpose function
* Optional to switch Music back to original
* Included four extra arcade mode (time attack)

💎 COMPARE TO OTHER SIMILAR GENRE:
* Creepy dead bodies
* Very realistic graphic
* Half dead enemies condition just like in the movie
* Normal wound remain on the character
* Each bullet impact on body looks realistic
* Zombie know how to breach a door
* Limited save
* Very helpful map
* Extra reward if capable to complete a higher difficulty
* Model Viewer with animation menu
* Variety downloadable mods (include adult content)

🔊 BUYER MUST KNOW:
* Game world timeline: 1998
* 1st playthrough allow to start as Leon / Claire, but same scenario
* 2nd playthrough can start as Leon / Claire, it is another scenario
* Same puzzle will be different solution in "2nd Run"
* All puzzle will be tougher in "2nd Run"
* Less chance to save game in 2nd Run"
* All the extra mode aren't easy on the easiest difficulty
* Extra modes = Bonus Stages = Unlock after story mode completed
* There are Weekly Challenges on RE.net
* F r e e_to_play_demo available

⚠️ RUMOR CHECKING:
* All the context from original is all gone! ➜ Maybe yes, but doesn't matter
* Game is too short ➜ Yes, if you're speed-runner
* Game is too long because of checking every rooms ➜ This is optional way to play the game
* Chosen different character but same campaign! ➜ Their are not entirely different, but will have different scenario, especially "2nd Run"

Yet, i can't help but cringe at each decision I'm forced to make and it's reason to do so. I always felt that games should reward trying to survive or at least teach something through death, but not this game. Nope, this game is teaching you it's mechanics and forces you to deal with them to progress the game for the most stupid reasons possible. I wanted to love this game, but it's a mess from the point of any and every possible storytelling point. And lastly, my deepest rant, the zombie killing system just makes me scratch my head endlessly.

Resident Evil 2, a game hailed for its survival horror revival, unfortunately falters in the realm of diversity and inclusion, leaving me with a sense of unease beyond the horrors of Raccoon City.

The most noticeable drawback is the lack of diversity in the character lineup. The game's protagonists conform to well-worn stereotypes, neglecting the opportunity to showcase a more varied and realistic representation of humanity in the face of the undead. In a modern gaming landscape that craves diverse narratives, Resident Evil 2 feels like a missed opportunity rather than a progressive step forward.

The narrative, while compelling in its own right, misses the chance to explore themes related to diversity and inclusion. The zombie apocalypse could have served as a backdrop to address the complexities of diverse relationships and perspectives, adding depth to the overall storytelling. Unfortunately, Resident Evil 2 seems content to stick to traditional tropes rather than pushing the envelope.

I originally bought the game a few years ago. I played Standard difficulty and kept getting killed, eventually ran out of ammo and didn't play anymore. 

Fast-forward to this year, and I was determined to give the game another chance. I have since completed all the runs for Standard mode, finished all but the "Tofu" (if you know, you know) extra game modes, and will probably hop on and give hardcore a try. 

The game is a bit tedious in the way that you must backtrack a lot (and often you need to "rehearse" how to clear certain areas), but the original RE2 was like this as well. Once you learn a few standard operating procedures regarding how to approach the gameplay, the game is a lot easier and more enjoyable. 

It definitely is a scary experience, especially the first time around! I highly recommend a play-through, and even if you only want to do the basic stuff, it's still worth the purchase price. I'm considering buying RE4 and RE5 next. I definitely got some adrenaline pumping while playing this game and it makes me want to do some more horror genre!

Resident Evil 2 is an unforgettable experience for survival horror enthusiasts. The game captivates with its impeccably executed atmosphere of horror and distinctive characters. Leon and Claire are true gems, each with their own characteristics and backstory. The graphics and sound immerse players in the fear of zombies, and the gameplay is dynamic and full of tension.

Although the choice of Leon from a gay perspective would be understandable, I must admit that Claire, for me, is a real dream. The choice is like being in a candy store - for some, Leon is a chocolate dream, while for others, Claire is a flavor bomb ready to explode. In the face of the zombie apocalypse, everyone will find their favorite survival companion. After all, love is like survival horror - sometimes you have to face challenges before reaching a happy ending! Resident Evil 2 is a masterpiece of the genre that keeps players on the edge of their seats from start to finish.

A great remake to an already great game. This game is the biggest reason I love Resident Evil. It is the most-classic modern zombie shooter ever made and not only the gameplay, every part of this game is just so good...

The environment is extremely iconic. It is amazing to explore through the RPD and gets even more satisfying after you unlock new parts of it.

The gameplay is amazing. Truly a great way to play Resident Evil, and Although I can tell that the inventory system is different and modern but it also feels incredibly nostalgic to me somehow. I'd say that it is satisfying as well; combining herbs and gun parts, organizing, storing...

The story is deep, truly a goosebump material. It is just a little confusing that there are minor conflicts between two stories, even when you play through it as A > B and not A > A (like intended) but I'm willing to ignore that given how incredible this game overall is. 

What wouldn't I give to play this game for the first time again...

This game a beautiful remake of a beloved game. I have 250+ hours on here and almost 1000 on PS4 doing everything from speed runs, to 100% runs, to challenge runs. Of my nearly 1250 hours I've never been bored or displeased with this game. I bought it with all DLC (on PC, as well as buying the game for PS4) and spent a total of almost 130 dollars on this. If I value my time at a dollar an hour, I've almost had a 10x return on investment with this game, and that's an extreme understatement.
This is not a remaster, or an aesthetic upgrade from the original. There is some minor lore change, the mechanics are entirely new, and is in fact a new game with the same settings and characters.
Personally, this game sits comfortably as my favorite RE game, and solidly in my top 5 games of all time.

It is a masterpiece. When I meet someone who says: "I don't like zombie games." I ask: "Did you tried RE 1 or 2?" If not then what do they know about zombie games, since they haven't played the two best zombie games in known universe. So perhaps that is all that needs to be written to show you what I think about this game. This is how a remastered version of a legendary game should look like. You can feel the care and emotions of developers. It has been some time since I played it, so here is how I remember it even now. 

It starts with a classic selection of characters. Leon or Jill. Then a road A or B. Every option is unique, I can assure you. In option B characters switch places and go via the road the other character did, in option A. There are bigger and smaller differences. I loved it since way back in the 90's. The road B is like a bonus game. Legendary police station is here again and it’s so great. You will be going thru the burning Racoon City. Streets filled with zombies, cars fill the streets, again at one point you need to run thru city bus to get thru blockade. But as all locations in the game, it is modified compared to old. I think I haven’t seen anything that was the same as in old game. As you progress thru the story, you will learn what is happening, why, what caused it. All clicks together pretty well. It makes nice connections to RE 1. Basically they were able to deliver the same game but it looks new, locations, items, some enemies, scripts, few mechanics, all is the same but a bit modified in a way that old fan like me is happy. Even the controls are better. Camera changed, but it is not FPV, it is hybrid that allows for surprises. That does not grant you full awareness and creates a space of horror. But overall I like it more than the old camera. Music sound and voices are great. Visuals and graphics as well. Controls too. 

Some examples of what you will encounter: be assured to experience all joys and stress as advertised. You will be running from zombies trying to conserve ammo. Or you will come to that story item only to learn that you shouldn’t have picked that ammo way back. Because your inventory is limited and now full. Then run zombie slalom to the nearest storage and back again. Jumpscares here and there. Some memorization or puzzle here and there. And other joyful moments. Nemesis is coming. Run. It is good that you can outrun him. In some areas you can even lose him. You will try to kill zombies with a knife, only to learn you need to practice so much for it to work that you rather switch to other weapons. And store the knife for the rest of the game. 

As you obtain better weapons, new enemies will be introduced. New routes will be created. Like some walls destroyed. Keys obtained to open new doors. Locations are so well crafted. They are labyrinths at first and as you are progressing thru story and open new rooms, there will be shortcuts created for you to lift off the need to go long ways. So it won't bore you. There are so many fine tunes in the game. Puzzles are just exact, not too hard, not too easy.
The game is an equilibrium of all the things inside. It makes a symphony with all the instruments it was given. I always loved the modifications to your weapons. They are here again and are great. I think even now they reload your weapon. They removed a few enemies from old and given as few new ones. For me the worst were the sewer enemies. I miss that new Nemesis is not murmuring “STARS” any more. 
Oh man how I love that all side characters are here and it is again done in such a great way. You still get to control them at some points.

This is a must have game for someone who likes Zombie games. And everyone who wants to throw this genre into trash should try 1 and 2 beforehand.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

I wrote an entire essay on this remake only for it to be erased because I clicked the "allow comments" button before hitting save changes. This remake is terrible.

I'm writing this off as a missed opportunity. I don't know if it was rushed development or a desire to preserve nostalgic details, but even while this remake successfully updates the original's graphics and stilted mechanics it declines to give other elements the same treatment. Don't get me wrong, I got past little things like the lack of mouse support in puzzle interfaces, but fundamental shortcomings like random zombie health and stun/res chance (leaving too much of the action and your resources at the mercy of RNG), or the periodic tendency for an absent Nemesis to suddenly appear on top of you, or for that matter his sheer overuse as a convenient tension driver (in contrast to the restrained application of such characters in recent titles), all serve to keep what should be a slick and modern remake back in the gaming bronze age. If the devs wanted legacy players to relive the original challenge they could've added it as an optional mode; as it is, all the rough edges have driven me to stop playing.

8.5/10
This game was pretty fun to play through with all the 'Runs' you can do! I like how you can choose different characters and it'll change how the game plays and your puzzles too. Also the introduction of Leon and Ada to the series, at least to me so that's sweet.

HOWEVER. I have a complaint with this game, and that being how ranks are done. Yes, it's stupid to say, but I really dislike when game give you ranks based on how quick you finish the game instead of other factors like how many zombies you killed or whatever. I'm only mentioning this cause of one thing, Hardcore S+. 

Imagine having to speedrun through the game in less than 2 hours, only allowed to use 3 saves or less AND the only unlock you can use is any pistol you bought with real money or a infinite knife. You don't get much time to get resources and have to REALLY space out your saves, risking being sent all the way back if you get killed. That is the hell of RE 2 S+.
As of writing, I was able to S+ Inferno in RE 3, but not get S+ in hardcore in RE 2....so that gives you a hint of the difficulty then.

Enough ranting however, the game is wonderful and you should pick it up, possibly with the Extra DLC if you feel like giving extra to the developers.

This was my first ever RE game. Did not disappoint. Had some repeating elements in both campaigns, but otherwise a satisfying story. The graphics were incredible, and the ray tracing caused some stutters in my laptop, but otherwise ran very smooth at an average of 70~80 fps. Maybe some people liked it, but wasn't my cup of tea =-(.
classic.

Easily one of the greatest remakes of all time! The original looks like complete garbage with it's outdated and clunky gameplay and awful graphics compared to this masterpiece of a remake. Ada Wong, Claire Redfield, and the other characters look way way better and more realistic and more expressive. The game is much more atmospheric and scary than the original. A more modern over the shoulder perspective third person shooter instead of the dumb fixed camera placements at random locations! The controls are way better and thank God this game does not use the terrible laser dot aiming mechanic but uses cross hairs yes! Please everyone go buy this game you will never regret it! Too bad the remake for it's sequel wasn't nearly as good. Although some of the cutscenes in Leon's portion felt cheesy and somewhat cringe. Claire's story is way better and she's just a better protagonist anyway. The guns sound way too muffled and quiet and don't do nearly enough damage so you'll end up wasting almost multiple magazines shooting into zombies head which seems to be based on an RNG system where I've only used one bullet to blow a hole through a zombie's brain which pisses me off! This game fixes everything that was bad about the original and even vastly improves upon them! The best game in the entire franchise! The remake of Resident Evil 3 was such a disappointment in comparison! Once again I just hate how bullet sponge like the enemies are especially the zombies which takes multiple bullets to the head to kill!

Long time fans and newcomers alike are in for a treat as the Resident Evil 2 remake is an absolutely fantastic game. It’s the best of the RE remakes I've played thus far and wholly outshines my most optimistic expectations. For me, this does supersede the original experience. While retro-purists might say otherwise, this just plays and looks so great that why would I ever go back? It’s an excellent retelling, a wonderful update, and a stellar game to re-experience all over again. A phenomenal remake that does far more than just adding a fresh coat of paint.

That said, Resident Evil 2 retains the vintage video game tension, requiring players to juggle inventory and battle through undead hordes in often difficult to navigate maps. The limited save opportunities has not gone away. Combat still provides a satisfying crunch with every shot - maybe even more so now than ever. And let's not forget TWO FULL CAMPAIGNS are included - which is still a bonkers amount of content. I admittedly only completed with Leon. Eventually, I'll come back to run the second.

Capcom has been killing it these past ~7 years. Ever since RE7 Biohazard, it's been almost nothing but gold. If you enjoy horror games in general, this is a must-play. The only crowd who might be let down are those who really enjoyed the B-movie charm and quality of the original. The voice acting and cut scenes are well done in this remake and lack the campyness that some might have hoped for. Myself? I'm all in on the remake being supreme.

Resident Evil 2 Remastered stands as my absolute favorite among the remastered games in the iconic Resident Evil series. This game is a stellar example of how to revitalize a classic while maintaining the essence that made the original so beloved. One of the most impressive aspects of Resident Evil 2 Remastered is the sheer amount of content it offers. Players have the opportunity to experience the game from two distinct perspectives, depending on which character they choose to play through first. This dual-playthrough approach not only adds depth to the narrative but also significantly enhances replay value, offering new challenges and nuances in each run.

The visuals in Resident Evil 2 Remastered are nothing short of remarkable. The game strikes a perfect balance, boasting modern, high-quality graphics that enhance the experience without overshadowing the classic feel of the original Resident Evil 2. The attention to detail in the game's environment, from the shadowy, foreboding corridors of the police station to the rain-soaked streets of Raccoon City, is truly immersive. The remastered version retains the core gameplay mechanics that I loved about the original, while seamlessly integrating updated controls and more fluid combat. This blend of old and new ensures that the game feels fresh yet familiar, appealing to both longtime fans and newcomers to the series.

RE2 was the coolest game I had ever played when it originally dropped on the PS1. Loved it to death! RE4 is my favorite now and even that REmake was amazing. This remake? Had amazing potential and could have been nearly perfect if not for Mr. X. In the original game the Tyrant would appear at scripted moments and also a few at random and it worked. There were some randomized jump scares but nothing game breaking. Mr. X simply stalks you relentlessly which does not work in an inventory management, back and forth to unlock game, constantly trying to learn your path and figure out the next thing to do type of game. Is he scary? No. Can he be stunned? Not really. Can he be stopped? No. IF this were a linear game, I could see being stalked and having to keep moving ahead as fast as possible but this is a constantly going back to where you started game. You waste so much time trying to dodge him or hide from him until he goes away just to have him show up 2 minutes later because you opened a few doors. Its not difficult, its incredibly annoying and ruins the experience. I'm sitting here in 2023 just as annoyed by ONE single part of the game as I was when I first gave this a try in 2019. Stupid me, Capcom got my money twice, once on PS4 and once on Steam. RE4 Remake and Re3 Remake were playable and enjoyable. RE2 Remake is only playable.

Title: Resident Evil 2 Remake: A Masterpiece of Survival Horror

Resident Evil 2 Remake is a stellar reimagining of the classic survival horror game that not only pays homage to the original but sets a new standard for the genre. From the gripping atmosphere to the heart-pounding encounters, this game is a must-play for both long-time fans and newcomers to the series.

Claire Redfield:
Claire's journey through Raccoon City is nothing short of exceptional. Her character is brought to life with incredible attention to detail, and her unique perspective adds layers to the storyline. From the hair-raising encounters with zombies to the emotionally charged moments, Claire's arc is a testament to the game's narrative excellence.

Leon S. Kennedy:
Leon's tale is equally captivating, offering a different perspective on the unfolding chaos. The character development and voice acting contribute to making Leon a relatable and compelling protagonist. Navigating the dark corridors and facing off against the horrifying creatures of Raccoon City with Leon is an intense and memorable experience.

Gameplay:

Tense Atmosphere: The game nails the eerie atmosphere that Resident Evil is known for. Every creak, groan, and distant sound keeps you on the edge of your seat, heightening the suspense throughout.

Immersive Environments: The attention to detail in the environments is astonishing. From the police station to the sewers, each location feels meticulously crafted, contributing to the overall sense of dread and isolation.

Strategic Combat: The combat mechanics strike a perfect balance between action and survival horror. Limited resources force you to think strategically, making each encounter a pulse-pounding test of skill.

Graphics and Sound:

Visually Stunning: The graphics are top-notch, bringing Raccoon City to life in gruesome detail. Character models, animations, and environmental effects contribute to an incredibly immersive experience.

Eerie Sound Design: The sound design deserves special mention. From the unsettling groans of zombies to the haunting score, every audio element adds to the overall horror experience.

Claire and Leon's Interconnected Stories:

Rich Storytelling: The intertwining narratives of Claire and Leon create a rich tapestry of storytelling. Choices made in one campaign impact the other, encouraging multiple playthroughs to uncover the full narrative.
Conclusion:
Resident Evil 2 Remake is a triumph in the survival horror genre. With its compelling characters, spine-chilling atmosphere, and polished gameplay mechanics, it stands as a shining example of what a remake can achieve when done with passion and respect for the source material. Whether you're a long-time fan or a newcomer, this game is an absolute masterpiece that should not be missed. Claire and Leon's journeys through Raccoon City will linger in your mind long after the credits roll.

8.9/10 Relatively faithful remake although very different from the original in terms of gameplay. Probably one of the best horror games ever made.

If you're new to survival horror games, like me, this is a fantastic first step into the genre. I didn't find the game too scary. A few moments got me, but I had tried playing RE7 prior to this and this was WAAAY more approachable for a horror wuss like me. 

Gameplay feels great, story is great. I played on controller and the aiming and controls felt smooth. Some nice quality of life features in this game to help with inventory management such as showing where items are on your map if you don't have space to pick them up right away. 

No spoilers here, but set your expectations appropriately for the "Second Run" playthrough that is unlocked after you finish the game. The game encourages you to play a "Second Run" playthrough as the other character to see their side of the story.  I thought it was going to be more different than it was, but it was like 95% of the same game. Still worth doing as there were some differences and you get an extended ending, but I just found myself a bit disappointed that it wasn't more different. 

Overall, would definitely recommend to anyone looking for a survival horror game to play. Even if you're not too into the genre, I still think there's a good story here and an enjoyable experience that isn't too long. 9/10.

I can't say I'm a fan of Remake 2, and the "thumbs up" rating here has more to do with its importance to the series and the overall production quality. It's not a bad game at all, and my first playthrough was quite enjoyable.
However, I personally believe that Remake 3 did a much better job a year later than Remake 2 in many ways. Nemesis from Remake 3 as an "immortal enemy type" is far superior to Mr. X, who is very annoying and too mechanical here. The variety of locations in Remake 2 pales in comparison to the levels in Remake 3 too.
And I'm definitely not a fan of the way Remake 2 handled two campaigns from the original, leaving them both too similar and contradictory to each other. What was acceptable in 1998 doesn't look so good in 2019.
So, once again, while I can't argue with the overall quality of Remake 2, I unfortunately can't praise the game either. And I'm a little sad about the criticism that Remake 3 received because I really think it's a much better game than Remake 2.

I don't know why it took me so long to play Resident Evil, but I'm glad I did now! Well, I played Resident Evil 2! I don't know if I want to play Resident Evil 1, but that's okay for me, i already know the lore from the first game! :) 

The story in Resident Evil 2 is magnificent and so catchy! I couldn't stop playing when I first started it honestly. I love that it's not full-on horror and most of it is action. 
It's really cool how you play the story and make some puzzles, then randomly Mester X shows up and chases you around while you do the rest of the story. He wasn't even scary or anything, it was just the fact I was being chased and scared he would catch up to me that was the horror part of the game.

The zombies and other monsters were also well made and placed perfectly random around the map to kinda jumpscare you. 
I loved the cutscenes, gave me a lot of beautiful screenshots! The game looks great :).
I've seen many people say they thought the game was too short, but honestly, I don't think so at all. I wouldn't mind it being longer but I'm happy enough about the 17 hours it took me to finish it!

Capcom's remake of Resident Evil 2 stands as a shining example of how to modernize a classic while staying true to the essence that made the original a genre-defining masterpiece. Released in 2019, Resident Evil 2 Remake takes players back to Raccoon City with stunning visuals, refined gameplay mechanics, and a renewed sense of terror, delivering an unforgettable survival horror experience.

From the outset, the game impresses with its exceptional graphics and attention to detail. The atmospheric lighting, highly detailed character models, and gruesome environments contribute to a visually stunning and immersive reimagining of the iconic locations from the original game. The switch to the over-the-shoulder third-person perspective enhances both the horror and the action elements, creating a more dynamic and engaging experience.

Resident Evil 2 Remake successfully captures the tension and dread that defined the survival horror genre. The revamped audio design, including hauntingly atmospheric music and spine-chilling sound effects, intensifies the sense of unease as players navigate the labyrinthine halls of the Raccoon City Police Department. The pacing is masterfully executed, with moments of quiet exploration building up to heart-pounding encounters with the nightmarish creatures that inhabit the city.

The narrative, while faithful to the core of the original game, benefits from expanded storytelling and character development. Leon S. Kennedy and Claire Redfield are brought to life with convincing performances, and the intertwining campaigns offer players a fresh perspective on the unfolding nightmare. The addition of new subplots and twists adds depth to the overall narrative without losing the essence of the original storyline.

Gameplay mechanics have been modernized to cater to contemporary gaming expectations. The inventory system, puzzle designs, and combat controls have all received thoughtful updates. The strategic use of limited resources, the clever level design, and the relentless pursuit of terrifying enemies contribute to an experience that perfectly balances survival horror with moments of intense action.

The replay value is high, with multiple campaigns, unlockable content, and additional difficulty levels providing incentives for multiple playthroughs. The implementation of the "Raccoon City Incident Report" system encourages players to explore and master the game, offering a rewarding sense of accomplishment.

While Resident Evil 2 Remake is a near-perfect experience, some might argue that certain segments could be more challenging, and the absence of the original's live-action FMV sequences could be missed by nostalgic fans. However, these are minor concerns in the grand scope of an otherwise exceptional game.

In conclusion, Resident Evil 2 Remake is a triumphant reimagining of a survival horror classic. It successfully blends modern gaming technology with the essence of the original, delivering a gripping, atmospheric, and unforgettable experience. Capcom's commitment to honoring the legacy of Resident Evil while pushing the series forward has resulted in a game that stands tall as one of the finest examples of survival horror in the gaming industry.

Resident Evil 2 is a masterful reimagining of a classic, blending nostalgia with modern gaming sensibilities. The story captivates with its intense, suspenseful narrative, earning a solid 8 out of 10. It brilliantly keeps you on the edge of your seat without revealing too much, ensuring a thrilling experience full of surprises.

The gameplay is commendable, meriting a 7 out of 10. It strikes a balance between challenging and accessible, offering enough difficulty to keep veterans engaged while still being welcoming to newcomers. The controls are responsive, and the game mechanics are well thought out, contributing to a satisfying survival horror experience.

Graphically, Resident Evil 2 is a visual feast. The attention to detail in the environments and character models is outstanding, with lighting and textures that create an immersive, eerie atmosphere. It's a significant step up from the original, and I'd rate the graphics a 9 out of 10. The game consistently impresses with its visuals, making every moment in its world both terrifying and beautiful.

Overall, Resident Evil 2 is a remarkable achievement that revives and enhances a beloved classic for the modern era.

2/3 of the game is a fine horror, the part starting from sewers is somewhat ok, a decline point for me. I wish it were slow paced similar to it's original version and not RUSH through all areas because of the fear that you'll be fisted. Implementation with Ada and her super cool gadgets is unnecessary only to show how deeply she cares about being rescued by rookie cop who fell in love with her. To be completely honest i absolutely despise Ada as a character since re4 she is an overrated stereotype, milla jovovich parody, action element cliche. Whole love story plot twist is cheap bs with the same ejaculation in the endgame cinematics. Leon is being a simple guy in this remake and has a degree of intelligence inadequate to cope with anything complex or involving mental effort, when Claire's initial intentions were to find out her brother but ended up with saving privat Ryan. Relationship between Leon and Claire is shallow, banal : "Hi I'm Leon, Hi I'm Claire, where are you going, don't go there, good to see you alive", moreover i was disappointed finding out that their scenarios are absolutely not complementary, differences are other side of police station and a person to rescue out of dumpster. Final battle with William is repetitive and doesn't give any memorable moments, pretty much as Nemesis in re3 remake, to be honest all this wild mutations are pathetic, tired of shooting at that exact G spot. First mrX on my аss, then William, i came to the point that i got so exhausted of this neverending persuasion, even outlast wasn't so energy consuming. Zombies are extremly irritating to deal with, slow annoying biting animations, rubber bullets, constant ammo absence, yeah that is what RE series about, to feel no secure. Extra modes are dull and straightforward - overflown with enemies runs from A to B, you can't kill anyone or kick their butts, there is no point in this, mainly because of low ammo supplies, all you need to do is avoid damage till you make it, which is idiotic and deeply anxious, a 100x multiplied ultimate re2 experience. The 4th survivor ruined because of this stingy gameplay, i should've studied economics in order to manage this crаp inventory and items placement. I do appreciate environment, mood, animations, models, sound, cinematics, some parts of physics, small details, many things that Capcom done right to make this game shine, it's great for new era generation, i do understand ratings, direction taken, but i'm feeling odd about the game at the same time. In my opinion the conceptual peak of resident evil was "RE: Outbreak and it's file#2" right before they took progressive ultra action re4 direction which is implemented in this game in a bit subdued way. 20 years old game has more complex approach rather than we have here, with mechanics way too far ahead of it's time perfectly suitable for RE series, but who needs that forsaken s*hit, we got suspence, we got mrX and suspence from him, we have W.Birkin with more persuasive suspence and UNDYING ZOMBIE PLANTS wow, can you imagine how cool is that ?! Also RE engine, and another ace in the sleeve - ADA WONG and her gadgets. What we get - half baked remake with a lot of missing content compare to original game. If play this game without considering it's legacy - i guess it's alright then, at least Capcom does things, and not being Konami with thousands great games being held in hostage.

There's still plenty of people out there who have yet played [i][b]Resident Evil 2[/b][/i] and for those of a squeamish disposition, it may have been a conscious decision - after all. [i][b]Resident Evil 2[/b][/i] is a gory game.

The far-fetched plot, about Leon Scott Kennedy and Claire Redfield, who together discover a city full of zombies, is kept down to earth by clever scripting and gritty storytelling. [spoiler]It starts with your character surrounded by zombies - and all you have to defend yourself with is a gun and a small amount of bullets.[/spoiler] Afterwards, the story twists and turns, the monsters get meaner and more gruesome, and the movie atmosphere digs in deeper.

You can play [i][b]Resident Evil 2[/b][/i] as either Leon or Claire, and then, when completed you can play through it again as the other character. They have their own agenda, weapons and path through the story, albeit in a completely different way, all of which is set up in the impressive introductory sequence.

Graphically, [i][b]Resident Evil 2[/b][/i] is light years ahead of its predecessor - especially the animated zombies, which seem to proliferate in every darkened corner of the game and as if your blood pressure wasn't high enough, a sprinkling of deliriously scary set - pieces have been dropped into strategically positioned portions of the game. The overall presentation looks exceptionally good, particularly the visual effects that give a tense atmosphere and feeling of isolation. Special note must also be made of the eerie music and subtle sound effects, both of which add much to the mise-en-scène.

[i][b]Capcom[/b][/i] has created the computer gaming equivalent of the [i][b]George A. Romero[/b][/i] horror movie classic, [i][b]Day Of The Dead[/b][/i] - a concoction of dead-end scares and flesh-chewing shocks.

8/10. This RE2 remake is a good story and a solid game. I loved the cinematics and overall art style direction. Unlocking a new area, key, or defeating a boss always feels fresh in this game. The designers of the game had an appreciation for beauty especially in the statues, art, and details that went into this. The aesthetics are a kind of heightened Americana type that I wish the US was more like (consistently). The characters are attractive, especially the women such as Ada, which is something that Western games are not doing as well with lately. The story telling left me with nothing else to be desired. The romance was hot. The boss fights are enjoyable. The game has a bit too many puzzles imo, but those can also be rewarding to solve. I have criticisms of many of the puzzles however, especially because some are so convoluted and tedious to figure out on your own that it will have you relying on online sources. Nevertheless, it is a charming survival horror game. I thought it kind of like Dead Space game but in a contemporary setting, but of course, RE inspired that. It was difficult for me given the limited health, ammo, and time-consuming inventory management, so I bought the DLC because it's more fun to have an MP5 with infinite ammo. Would still suggest that route. The dark environments, jump scares, and powerful enemies still frightened me. I considered it scary so that's good horror in my book. If you're a trophy hunter, most of the trophies are fair and not too obscure. You can finish the game in under 10 hours, so it is a short game, but it does have decent replayability as another character. All in all, I would certainly suggest it.

What an excellent game, the vibe this game gives is something I haven't experienced in my previous Resident Evil games (4 & 5). This is a brilliant example of a game that creates uneasiness not through jump scares, but through giving you limited resources, having to be smart and adapting to the fact you can't just shoot every zombie (because you'll run out of ammo when you need it) really added to the tension. There were certainly moments where the game really gives you an adrenaline rush (many moments), this game masterfully sets the tone and continues it throughout the game. The sound design is also amazing, I couldn't play this game at full volume and fully immerse as I'm a whimp.

I absolutely loved the layout in this game, the way that exploration and a keen eye is rewarded is second to none. There are many things that you can unlock throughout the game that give you additional weapons, bag slots, ammo and medication for survival, but only if you add pieces of a puzzle together when you pick items up, and go into other rooms in the police station and work out what those items relate to. It is completely worth exploring everything you can and working out each puzzle as the rewards are worth it almost every time (and advance the story/narrative throughout). 

I really enjoyed the story and the characters, it is well fleshed out and the moral forces involved are interesting to think about. Not to mention some of the other tragic themes. The game length & pacing for me was just about perfect, it was enough to give a cohesive story, and not make you just wonder when the game will finally end, it ends exactly when it should and is a thrilling experience.

Last but not least, the graphics, oh the graphics. They're amazing. Almost every enemy in this game is terrifying, and the use of darkness and your limited area covering flashlight just adds the cherry on the top. This game is a magnificent accomplishment by CAPCOM. Buy this game.

An excellent survival-horror/action-adventure game by itself and also a dream come true as a remake of the 1998's original title, wherefrom developers masterfully repurposed every aspect. Graphics, soundtrack and voice acting, amongst others, reflect the game's high production value. RE2 feels almost like a movie about a zombie apocalypse, with references to science fiction classics such as Terminator, The Fly and Aliens. Both characters offer interesting and distinctive playthroughs while mini games add to its replay value. Leon though is probably the established protagonist, with his reserved but dutiful personality wrapped in Alain Delon-like charisma, alongside Ada Wong, an iconic femme fatale. 
This game is value for money-highly recommended.

As a fan of the original, this remake is... acceptable. The gameplay and graphics are obviously modernized, and puzzles are honestly better than they were, but pretty much everything plot, character, and music related is a huge drop down.

The game gets the gameplay right which is what makes it worth playing. Hardcore is pleasantly difficult and tense your first couple times through. Exploring the map is fun, backtracking is never a chore.

The one thing that was ripe for improvement were the differences between the scenarios and making you feel as if the other character is somewhere on the map having their own adventure that also affects you. Instead, the story (within the same "timeline") both contradicts itself and repeats endlessly with absolutely nothing one character does affecting the other. There's enough material here for one and a half scenarios, not four. 

The writing is straight up bad. That's all I'll say about that because I don't want to go on a novel long series of tangents.

One of the best games in the series and in the genre. Great for newcomers and veterans of Resident Evil and horror in general. Graphics are about as high quality as it gets. Gameplay is phenomenal and the story is just so much fun. Only two complaints are that the enemies are practically unkillable even on the easiest difficulty settings and the movement, which is kind of important for dodging these unkillable enemies, is extremely quirky. Your character walks about as slow as a grandma on a walker even when a massive monster is trying to kill you and that can be extremely frustrating when you're trying your hardest not to get hit but your character just doesn't seem to care or want to move. Other than that, this game is so full of interesting moments, cool puzzles, great characters, great set-pieces and damn near perfect pacing. It is so much fun to play and even when you finish the game you're going to want to play it again almost immediately. It's that good.

[h3][b]General Info[/b][/h3]
This is a Resident Evil 2 REmake which features a graphical rebuild and changing of certain story elements to streamline game play. There are basically two "stories" that you can choose from, though the basic premise of the story is roughly the same: You can play as Leon Kennedy through the first day on the job of the Raccoon Police Department, or as Claire Redfield as she searches for her brother.

[h3][b]My Thoughts[/b][/h3]
This game has a very different vibe to the original Resident Evil 2, that's not necessarily a bad thing since even though the original was extremely well made, the controls, pacing, and fixed camera are not for everyone. This REmake does an exceptional job of bringing the game into the more modern era of gaming. I personally would have loved a dodge in the game, but that's just me being a little picky. 

The game looks beautiful, has some fun puzzle elements (though nothing quite like the first Resident Evil game with the bizarrely constructed manor), and introduces game play elements and features that provide a lot of quality of life improvement (being able to expand your inventory blessedly being one of them).

[h3][b]Recommendation[/b][/h3]
If you are a fan of the Resident Evil series for it's story telling, and you do not mind a shift in game play style to something that would be considered more action oriented, then this is a game that you will likely have a lot of fun playing. If you prefer the puzzle elements, tension, controls, and pacing of the original games then the changes they have made to modernize the game may not necessarily sit well with you. In my personal opinion, I think they game is amazing and definitely worth playing through. If price is a consideration, wait for the Steam sales that occur pretty often to pick it up, but the value for the money spent is there.

I played as Leon A and Claire B. Both story lines had similar core elements but each with their own differences, enough to make it worth playing both.

I'll say that I have had very limited exposure to RE except for RE4 on the Wii, which I remember being a fun experience (and the classic merchant quote, 'What are ya buying???') but not much else. I wanted a horror game for Halloween and came away with something much greater than I expected!

Really my only complaint is that sometimes the puzzles feel a little gratuitous, and it may have been more horror-fitting if the enemies could still move around while you solved puzzles. However, I highly recommend this game and I am planning on working my way through the whole RE franchise now.

Welcome to Raccoon City, the Capital of Fear

The short story of the "Resident Evil 2" Remake revolves around the struggle of young police officer Leon S. Kennedy and Chris Redfield's missing sister Claire Redfield during the zombie outbreak in Raccoon City. The duo fights the horrific virus of the Umbrella Corporation, uncovering the city's terrifying secrets. In their struggle for survival, they try to unravel the mysteries.

"Resident Evil 2 Remake" stands out as one of the most memorable survival-horror games in the gaming world. The game skillfully reimagines the classic masterpiece of the original "Resident Evil 2" with modern gaming technology, setting a new standard in the horror game genre and remake games. While being a remake, the production team has managed to add intricate details to the game, successfully maintaining the excitement and tension of the original game while implementing modern gaming standards. Players find themselves immersed in an unforgettable experience that never loses its tempo from beginning to end, enveloped in a deep atmosphere of fear and suspense. It has made significant contributions to revitalizing the horror game genre, increasing interest in the world of horror gaming.

Visually and atmospherically, the game's detailed graphics and meticulously designed environments draw players into Raccoon City's menacing and dark world. Claustrophobic corridors, dark rooms, and intricate spaces make players feel the tension at every step. Additionally, character and creature designs play a significant role in creating a realistic, frightening, and suspenseful atmosphere.

The gameplay mechanics are effectively designed to strengthen the game's elements of horror, suspense, and survival. Players must grapple with limited resources, solve puzzles, and confront zombies. This balance ensures that players are constantly in a state of tension while maintaining the game's fluidity, suspense, and excitement.

The rich and deep storytelling is full of in-depth character development and unexpected plot twists. As players are drawn into the game, they witness the emotional experiences of the characters, which strengthens the emotional connection of the game.

In conclusion, "Resident Evil 2 Remake" emerges as an impressive game that offers an unforgettable experience in the horror and survival game genre. With its detailed graphics, atmosphere, and gameplay mechanics, it provides gamers with moments of fear and suspense while delivering an unforgettable story, captivating players. It is a masterpiece that every fan of horror and survival games should definitely play.
How remakes should be made.

Pretty great experience. This was my introduction to survival horror, and with no prior experience, the necessary strategy to get through it felt very different from other shooter games - having to be very frugal with ammunition, having no base melee weapon, deciding which enemies to kill and which to just avoid, etc. Was not as terrifying as I expected, but it did provide me with some scares here and there, which made for a good balance of keeping me on my feet sometimes while allowing me some peace of mind to calmly and confidently proceed. I felt like this game doesn`t break its own rules - for example, zombies will never follow you into a different room, and if you blow their heads off, they`re gone for good (which might I add, was a relief, because it allows you to clear some safe paths). Combat feels good, especially when using the shotgun, but the main character does not provide you with tight handling, forcing you to either clear your way beforehand or risk getting hurt if you try to evade the enemies, which I feel plays into the survival horror aspect. Took me around 10 hours to finish my first run. Liked the characters and environments.

TL;DR: Exciting but not that scary, well designed for its genre, would recommend.

"Resident Evil 2 Remake" is a masterful reimagining of the 1998 horror classic, offering a deep and engaging experience that pays homage to the original while refining and expanding upon it for a modern audience. Here's an extensive review of why this game is a must-play.

Visual Overhaul and Atmosphere:
The most immediately noticeable improvement in the "Resident Evil 2 Remake" is the visual upgrade. Utilizing the RE Engine, the game presents a darkly beautiful and terrifyingly realistic Raccoon City, with detailed environments, atmospheric lighting, and grotesquely lifelike zombies. The police station, the game's primary locale, is a character in itself, with its intricate architecture now fully realized in stunning high-definition, making the exploration both awe-inspiring and horrifying.

Gameplay Enhancements:
The remake abandons the original's fixed camera angles for a modern over-the-shoulder perspective, significantly updating the game's playability without sacrificing the claustrophobic feel that fans loved. This change, coupled with refined shooting mechanics, makes combat more engaging, and the need to conserve ammunition adds a strategic layer to every encounter.

Sound Design:
Sound plays a crucial role in establishing the game's chilling atmosphere. The moans of zombies, the echo of distant gunfire, and the character's footsteps reverberating through the halls create an immersive and nerve-wracking audio experience. The game's soundtrack is carefully used to enhance key moments, adding to the tension and release during gameplay.

Narrative and Dual Campaigns:
"Resident Evil 2 Remake" features two parallel campaigns with protagonists Leon S. Kennedy and Claire Redfield, each offering a distinct storyline and unique gameplay experiences. This dual approach not only provides different perspectives on the outbreak but also increases replayability, as players uncover the full story by playing through both characters' eyes.

Survival Horror Elements:
True to the series' roots, the game emphasizes survival horror elements. Resource management is critical, with limited inventory space and scarce supplies forcing players to make tough decisions about what to carry. The puzzles, a staple of the original, return with a fresh twist, requiring players to explore and interact with their environment thoughtfully.

Enemy Variety and AI:
The zombies in "Resident Evil 2 Remake" are not the only threat. The game introduces a variety of enemies, each with unique behaviors and weaknesses, including the iconic and relentless Tyrant, known as Mr. X. The AI is unpredictable, making each playthrough a unique challenge.

Character Development:
The characters in the "Resident Evil 2 Remake" are more developed, with expanded backstories and motivations. Leon and Claire are more fleshed out, making players more invested in their survival and journey. The supporting cast also benefits from this attention to detail, adding depth to the game's narrative.

Modernized Controls and Interface:
The controls have been modernized, making the game more accessible to newcomers while remaining challenging enough for veterans. The user interface is sleek and intuitive, ensuring that players spend less time wrestling with menus and more time enjoying the gameplay.

Replayability:
Beyond the dual campaigns, "Resident Evil 2 Remake" offers unlockable modes, secrets, and difficulty levels that encourage multiple playthroughs. The game rewards exploration and mastery, enticing players to return to Raccoon City again and again.

In conclusion, the "Resident Evil 2 Remake" is a triumphant revival of a classic game. It captures the essence of the original while improving upon it in every way, from graphics to gameplay to story. The game manages to be both nostalgic and fresh, providing an experience that is accessible to newcomers and deeply satisfying for long-time fans. Whether you're looking for a terrifying horror experience, a challenging survival game, or simply a well-crafted story, "Resident Evil 2 Remake" delivers on all fronts and stands as a benchmark for how to do a video game remake right.

The A story for this game is amazing. The art museum turned RPD is one of, if not the best location in gaming history, and although the later locations like the parking lot, sewers and laboratory are weaker, they're still fun. But goddamn it, I just couldn't get myself to enjoy the B stories.

It's not even the fact that they're super similar to the A stories like most people have a problem with. It's a specific thing they have set up in the B story that messes it up.

I like that fact that you start in a different, more difficult location with more difficult enemy placements and how you slowly open rooms in the RPD in a different order compared to the A story, but what completely messes it up is the early introduction of Mr. X.

In the A story, Mr. X is introduced at the perfect time and enhances the gameplay. He's introduced at a point where you're familiar with all the rooms in the RPD and have most of the RPD opened up, so whenever Mr. X does chase you, you have a lot of different paths you can take so that you can loop or lose Mr. X, or find the nearest safe room. It's fun because it's satisfying to remember your surroundings and come up with a plan on the fly that'll get this monster off of your tail.

In the B story, sure, you still remember the layout because of the A playthrough, but because Mr. X is introduced so early in the B story, you're at a point where you don't have a lot of rooms open, and therefore don't have any places to go to lose him. On top of this, because there's barely anywhere to go, Mr. X has a smaller search area to patrol, so he's gonna be finding you a lot more often. This usually leads to you leaving a safe room, trying to get to the room with the key item you need, finding Mr. X in your way, and because most rooms are locked up, you can't lose him, so you're forced to take a straight line backwards to the safe room you just left. You sit in the safe room until you can't hear his foot steps, you leave the safe room and try to get to the key item room again, but he finds you again, and it's back to the same safe room. Over. And over. And over again.

I get what they were going for. Introducing Mr. X earlier makes the game harder, and it makes sense to make the game harder because this is the B run, but this feels like, to me, artificial difficultly. It's not challenging, it's just plain frustrating. Maybe this isn't a problem with the game. Maybe I've just been super unlucky with how Mr. X patrols, but it doesn't feel that way to me.

I'm still gonna recommend the game because the A story is so good. Just know that most of the B story will be very frustrating to get through.
