RE2 Remake is an excellently crafted survival horror game with superb atmosphere. It is absolutely worth playing if you are into survival horror and are in the mood for an incredibly tense experience.

From the deafening silence that permeates every area of the game to the sudden thrashing of a zombie as they bash a door open to pursue you, the sound design does a spectacular job of immersing you in the environment, especially if you're using headphones with the proper settings enabled (Headphones mode + Binaural Audio). I seriously doubt that the game would've been as tense as it was if the sound design wasn't this well-done.

There are some parts of the game that could be improved further in future installments, namely the 2nd Run portion of the game that I found to be somewhat disappointing in terms of potential. Another nitpick would be that the boss battles can feel bullet spongy and a little tedious at times, which I guess is to be expected by playing on Hardcore.

Other than that however, this game excels in pretty much every area you'd expect a survival horror game to excel in. Note that since I haven't played the original, I can't really speak for how this remake compares. Despite that, I can definitely say that on its own, it's probably up there with the best that the modern survival horror genre can offer.

I would recommend playing on the Hardcore difficulty for a blind first playthrough, especially if you know you are capable of handling the changes it introduces. It's an experience that just can't be matched by a second playthrough on Hardcore, because like with Soulsborne games which rely on player knowledge for some of its difficulty, the first playthrough will almost always be where the most fun is had.

Gameplay-wise, it is extremely fun to play, even upon replays. Highly recommended, however there're a few things to note:

1. While there are enough differences between Leon [1st run] & Claire [2nd run] that you should play both, there aren't enough differences to justify playing Claire [1st run] & Leon [2nd run] on top of that, or vise versa. So if you're not keen on replaying the game, just choose 1 set & ignore the other. That being said, I did all versions of the scenarios multiple times over as I enjoy the gameplay.

2. Only buy the deluxe edition if you're interested in the costumes it provides or the soundtrack swap, the additional weapon is not worth it. The soundtrack swap in particular is a setting that must be toggled manually, otherwise it won't be present during your playthrough. Music comparisons are all subjective in nature, but there are some tracks that the remake does better (countdown sequences for both characters, 4th survivor), while some that better in the original, or in some cases only present in the original (Main hall, save rooms, library). As the ghost survivors are entirely native to this remake, there is no original version soundtrack swap in those scenarios.

11/10

What I liked:
- Graphics. Really great, and performance is amazing.
- Env. design - no need to tell anything, this is what Capcom always does great.
- Plot, dialogues (Capcom always does it great)
- Claire
- Ada
What I didn't like:
- Map design. Pretty complicated for non-hardcore players, you need to go back to old locations a lot of times, there are a lot of non-obvious quests to unlock something and in combination with lack of ammo and re-spawning enemies is makes player stress a lot
- No close combat opportunities (like knife parry in RE4 and melee finishers in RE4). In combination with very limited ammo it is painful.
- Gameplay idea is that you can't and shouldn't kill most of enemies and this might be a good thing for hardcore players but it is pretty painful for players like me that struggle to orient on the map and like to slowly go and explore everything.

Overall - of course I recommend this game, if you are casual player I might recommend you to get the infinite ammo DLC and with that you can equip Gatling gun and kind of relax :)

Resident Evil 4 Remake made me revisit this game again, but I like this more than RE 4. Not because the RE 4 remake is not good, but because RE 2 is the remake of classic Resident Evil games.

Since RE 4, the franchise has turned to more action with linear paths, but in classic ones, you circle around a mansion and solve puzzles. In classic ones, there are no shops to buy or upgrade weapons; there are no boxes to break them and get loot; enemies won't drop loot items either, so there is no benefit to killing them, and you better run away as long as you can. There are no melee attacks, and you need to focus on saving ammunition, etc.

So, I'm more of a fan of classic Resident Evil style, but still, both remakes are awesome.

[h1]Resident Evil 2: A Remake Fans Have Been Asking For[/h1]

[b]Resident Evil 2[/b] is a remake of the 1998 classic that was released on the PlayStation. Fans had long been clamoring for a remake because while the original game was still enjoyable, both its graphics and gameplay had become outdated. The remake aimed to offer a fresh experience to both new and old fans of the Resident Evil franchise. Utilizing the same engine as Resident Evil 7, [b]Resident Evil 2[/b] attempted to recapture the essence of the original while providing modern visuals and maintaining its roots in survival horror.

In this game, players take on the roles of either Leon S. Kennedy on his first day as a police officer or Claire Redfield in search of her brother, both set within the Raccoon Police Station. [b]Resident Evil 2[/b] features two scenarios, denoted as A and B scenarios, which can be played by two different characters, resulting in a total of four campaigns that can be completed. While the story doesn't differ significantly based on the character you choose, the narrative is closely tied to the scenarios. It's enjoyable to see the different perspectives and interactions of the characters with their environment, and the canon story can be interpreted by the player, as the final outcome doesn't hold much bearing on the overarching story.

With [b]Resident Evil 2[/b], after venturing into more action-oriented gameplay in Resident Evil 4 and returning to old-school horror in Resident Evil 7, Capcom successfully recaptured the essence of what made the Resident Evil franchise memorable. The remake intensifies the experience compared to the original, especially with the introduction of Mr. X (T-00), a towering and relentless pursuer who chases you for a significant portion of the game, whereas in the original, he only appears in B scenarios. The zombies were also redesigned to be more in line with the original Resident Evil 2. Since Resident Evil 4, shooting zombies in the head has been the most effective method to eliminate them, and that still holds true in modern Resident Evil games. However, the remake adopts the classic approach from the original Resident Evil games where zombies are not easily dispatched, and headshots may lead to critical hits and instant kills, but occurs very rarely. It's often preferred to conserve ammo and avoiding unnecessary combat, particularly because Resident Evil 2 doesn't provide generous supplies like more recent entries. The horror element is maintained by the constant threat of Mr. X, zombies that are difficult to kill, and a scarcity of resources that require careful management.

[b]Resident Evil 2[/b] also incorporates puzzles and hidden items that players can discover. Solving these puzzles and finding hidden items provides valuable rewards, such as weapon upgrades or entirely new weapons. It's worth the effort to solve these puzzles since it allows you to experiment with different weapons. Notably, Leon and Claire have different sets of weapons, which prevents the game from becoming repetitive. Resources found in the environment often come in raw materials, allowing you to craft your preferred type of ammo or healing items. The return of the item box, a staple in the Resident Evil series, plays a crucial role in resource management, as you must save and conserve your limited supplies.

A noteworthy addition to combat in [b]Resident Evil 2[/b] is the use of the knife. While the knife has been an important weapon in various Resident Evil games, it plays a critical role in [b]Resident Evil 2[/b], particularly when dealing with zombie bites. The knife can be used to avoid damage and push zombies away, but it has limited durability and is quite rare to find. Once used, it can only be recovered by defeating the zombie that has it, which may require using additional ammo. This creates a balance between protecting yourself from zombie bites and conserving precious ammunition.

To the best of my recollection, [b]Resident Evil 2[/b] does not have any significant downsides. While Mr. X's presence can become more of an annoyance than a true threat as you become familiar with the game, he can also be avoided. The game may start to feel repetitive if you play it multiple times to complete both scenarios with different characters without taking breaks. At times, [b]Resident Evil 2[/b] might feel too similar to the original, to the point where it could be seen as a cash grab with minimal changes, but it's a well-deserved remake.

In summary, [b]Resident Evil 2[/b] is a solid remake of the original Resident Evil 2 (1998) that remains faithful to its roots. Players who are more accustomed to modern Resident Evil titles might struggle to adapt to the gameplay mechanics of [b]Resident Evil 2[/b], but it serves as a great entry point for understanding what made the Resident Evil series great in its early days.

I'm a coward.  It took me literally years to actually muster the nerve to play through this game (partially, technically, as I haven't done the B scenarios yet).  That being said, after finally finishing the first playthroughs, this might be one of my favorite games of all time.  It was, at least, an incredible first impression of the survival horror genre to me.

Everything about the atmosphere, the music, the gameplay loop of scrounging for and preserving ammo and healing items is so freakin' immersive and just...fun.  Starting the B scenarios of each character with some background knowledge of the map layouts, it's a ton of fun to plan out routes for where to go and maximize what you're getting out of each trip out into the station.

Despite the fact that RE3R has a less than stellar reputation among fans, I'm looking forward to finally getting into the rest of this series now that I've got a toe dipped in.

Whether this is your first RE game or you're a series veteran I highly recommend RE2 Remake. Being new to the franchise I didn't know exactly what to expect and ended up enjoying my 60+ hours so much that I actually decided to go back and play the series in chronological order. While very different from its namesake, RE2R is a fun homage to the source material and definitely worthy of your time (especially on sale). I think my biggest gripe with the game is its near complete absence of a soundtrack, especially when the OSTs for the classic games are so beloved. After that it'd be that the A and B campaigns are clearly tacked-on afterthoughts that should've been left out, but hey, whatever. It's a fun game.

Ladies and Gentlemen, I present to you a review of Resident Evil 2, written by a woman who has been dead for quite some time. Now, don't ask me how that's possible. Just go with it.

Resident Evil 2, my dear friends, is not just a game. It's an adrenaline shot straight to the heart, akin to a heroin rush for the thrill-seekers among us. It's like riding a rollercoaster that's on fire while juggling chainsaws and reciting Shakespeare backwards. It's intense, it's terrifying, and it's absolutely bloody brilliant!

The game is so good, it makes you question the very fabric of reality. You'll find yourself sitting in your underwear at 3 am, eyes bloodshot, heart pounding like a drum solo at a rock concert, screaming at zombies on your screen. And you'll love every second of it.

The graphics? Top-notch. The storyline? Engrossing. The characters? Well-developed. The zombies? Absolutely terrifying. The adrenaline rush? Constant and unyielding. It's like the game developers found a way to bottle pure excitement and inject it directly into your veins.

Now, I don't usually beg, but in this case, I'll make an exception. Give me all the awards! All of them! I want trophies, medals, certificates, ribbons! I want my name engraved on plaques! I want a parade in my honor! Why? Because I survived Resident Evil 2 and lived to tell the tale!

In conclusion, Resident Evil 2 is not just a game. It's an experience. It's a wild ride that will leave you breathless and begging for more. So strap in, hold on tight, and prepare for the ride of your life!

P.S.: If you find any typos in this review, remember: I've been dead for a while. Cut me some slack.

Pros:
- Good atmosphere
- Decent voice work
- Zombies and other enemies are good
- Puzzles aren't too easy or too hard and require a bit of thought
- Survival horror elements work as they should
- Game can get genuinely scary 
- Bonus content is good
- Layout of the RPD and other areas are nice
- New perspective is implemented well

Cons:
- Mr. X is scary at first, but eventually becomes a gigantic annoyance and pain in the ass
- 2nd run is implemented in the most lazy way possible and is a huge downgrade from the original
- The soundtrack from the original game is locked behind a paywall
- Music isn't as memorable, but does have the occasional track I remember from time to time
- Some scenes remain the same regardless of the character you pick on the 2nd run

Overall: While it does have some issues it still is a good remake and worth checking out.

It lives up to its rating. RE2 is a masterpiece, fun to watch and fun to play. With utterly spectacular graphics powered by the best engine of the last decade (also see DMC5 and SF6), RE2 delivers a compact and replayable loop of terror, tension, action and exhilaration. You pick between the male and the female protagonists, and try to survive in the spooky police precinct of the infested Raccoon City of 1998.

Perfected after two decades of practice, the Resident Evil formula delivers to the max. The plot is mercifully simple, the protagonist good-looking, and the action tense. Most of all, the atmosphere is one of gorgeous pervasive oppression and brooding menace. Best played in the dark, RE2 can genuinely get to you.

From a technical perspective, the RE engine never ceases to amaze. It runs great, loads fast, and the models and the lighting look terrific.

In terms of gameplay, you are back to basics polished to the max. You explore a tight space room by room, solving simple puzzles and shuddering before turning every corner.

Each of the two characters has two slightly tweaked scenarios. And if you complete all four versions of the game, you can try to beat the hardcore difficulty, or to get the "S" rating by speed-running. RE2 has something for everyone, from the casuals to the pros.

10/10 - a genuine masterpiece, highlighting both the cinematic potential of gaming as an art, and the sheer fun of carefully calibrated gameplay. If you had to play only one Resident Evil, this is probably the one. But keep in mind that the other RE-engine RE titles are also excellent; some of them close to or on par with RE2...

[h1]FILET MIGNON, MANGLED INTO A CHARRED BURGER AND SERVED WITH PROCESSED "CHEESE"[/h1]
This is the most painful thing I've ever had to write.
A Resident Evil 2 for the modern generation. Besides catering to modern gamers, and including the characters from the original game, I in no way see how this is supposed to be tailored to  long time fans. 
For clarification, the original Resident Evil 2 on PlayStation 1 is one of my favourite games of all time. I originally rented it and kept walking into the fire, or immediately getting eaten. I was ready to return it and chalk it up as garbage. But, I persisted, and soon, I was in the gun shop. I don't remember how far I got in the time I rented it, but a few months later, my dad bought me the game as a reward for finishing grade 8. I was now a bit more experienced with the game, and could basically make it to the police station without even firing a shot. I was immersed in finding all the secrets, and played through the "entire" game in one sitting (Leon mode A + Claire mode B). I was hooked. I played it so much that I even managed to beat the bonus modes with Hunk and Tofu. I still have a copy on my PS3 and play it from time to time.
When I heard it was getting a remake that was supposed to be like a love letter to the fans of the original, I even shed a tear of joy watching the original announcement trailer. Now after playing it, I feel like an idiot for that. I realise now that I would simply be far happier with a remastered version of Resident Evil 2 with some updated graphics. Resident Evil 2 Remake isn't what I asked for, nor is it something that I ever wanted.
I hate it so much that I haven't even played the remake of one of my other favourite games, Final Fantasy 7, because I'm horrified of what they may have done to it (the amount of attention to detail about Cloud being in a dress already tells me enough).
This game is Resident Evil 2 in the characters and story only. Saying you've played Resident Evil 2 and have never played the original is like saying you've eaten a hamburger, so you know what steak tastes like.
I'm not just saying this is a bad remake. I'm saying this is a bad game.
- The moment that I really began to despise this game is in the police station when, after walking through a wide open shutter into the main hall area, several zombies refused to follow me, merely losing interest and turning around before wandering off in the other direction. This is the kind of asinine disregard for detail that completely breaks immersion, and would have never cut it in the original. Resident Evil 2 may have had chunky graphics and tank controls, but it made up with it in originality and  paying extreme attention to details, like never doing stupid shit such as this.
And those terrifying Lickers? Stand in a doorway. Open the door, shoot them, back up. Door closes, Licker leaves. Repeat. Ohhh, so fucking scary. Fucking horse shit is what it actually is. Of course you could retreat through a door in the original, but you knew when you immediately went through again, those enemies were generally there waiting for you. In this pos the Licker retreats to his default position every single time seconds after it breaks line of sight with you. I get that you're supposed to sneak past them, but this rarely works, and it's stupid.
 - No game mode B. The single greatest part of Resident Evil 2 for me was beating the game and then knowing it wasn't over. You now got to see the entire game from the perspective the other character would have seen it from - and then could repeat the entire process by playing the discs in the other order, meaning to REALLY beat the game, you had to complete it four times, and it was unique each time. This was an amazing idea and that attention to detail is what made the game great to me. It was unique, something RE2 Remake can't claim in any way, shape or form. Besides looking good, RE2 Remake borrows elements from every existing game imaginable, and refuses to do anything unique or groundbreaking. Hell, it refuses to even pay homage to the game play of the originals. It just wants to be it's own thing, which seems to be great for lots of people, but I hate it. I at least had hopes that they would add this mode as a dlc or something, but they clearly have no intention of doing that.
- I hate defensive items and you're constantly forced to micro-manage defensive items. I don't even bother with the knives or barricades, they just take up inventory space and are more annoying than useful. Because, you know, it makes perfect sense that a knife or a 9 v. battery should take up the same amount of space as, say, a SHOTGUN or a PILE OF FUCKING 2x4s!!
- Zombies magically re-spawn in sealed rooms with no explanation or possible way they could have gotten in there. This is compounded by the fact that, even though a "normal" zombie (in theory) should drop from one head shot, apparently everyone in Raccoon City has steel fucking plates in their heads, because they take upwards of 7+ shots to the face and still get back up. This bs, with the defensive objects, makes going through every area annoying as fucking hell, because if you use up all of your consumables, you've basically locked your game and need to restart. 
- I played through this originally until I got to Ada and her hacking tool, and I just couldn't do it any more after that. I decided to restart the game and give it another chance because people won't shut up about how good it is, plus I put aside all of my expectations for it to even hold a tribute candle to the original, but no, it still sucks.
From the goofy trash that was "Welcome to Raccoon City" to this, my fond childhood memories of Resident Evil are now heavily tarnished. I'm extremely happy that I at least own the Resident Evil 2 board game and all of the expansions because they are a far greater homage to Resident Evil 2 than Resident Evil 2 Remake is.
Like most things these days, all of the emphasis and importance is placed on aesthetic glitz and flash, and hardly any substance. More time was spent figuring out how to monetise outfits then was actually used making sure that hardcore fans would be happy.
Damn shame.

I did NOT expect to like this game so much. I don't really play horror games, but this game was so fun to play I could not put it down. The atmosphere inside that police station is so immersive and was really well-done. The game-play is tight, a bit crammed and clunky to give you that sense of unease. An awesome experience. Survival horror games are generally not in my wheelhouse, but this remake of Resident Evil 2 seems to hit all the right notes. It’s tense, it’s atmospheric, it’s at-times stressful, but everything comes together in a great package to deliver a fantastic time. 

You have two characters to choose from, both with two scenarios, multiple added scenarios with different characters to see other perspectives in Raccoon City during the outbreak, a couple of goofy things to try like playing as a piece of tofu, and a good amount of content to unlock like a model viewer and concept art. 

The assisted mode is also nice for total wimps like me who just want to kill everything to clear out the horror side of things and make it more of an exploration game, so outside of the threat of Mr. X, I got to experience RE2 in a way that I had a lot of fun with.

If you don’t know who Mr. X is – he’s an invincible stalker wearing a fedora and a trenchoat who follows you around menacingly, and somehow he’s a mixture of scary and amusing. I think it’s because big monsters wearing fedoras just look goofy more than anything else, but then he catches you and slams his fist straight into your dome… but then you run into a safe room and he just stares at you before shrugging and walking away.

I absolutely loved the remake! It's a true masterpiece that brilliantly captures the essence of the original while delivering modern graphics and gameplay. The developers have done a fantastic job in preserving the nostalgia while bringing the game into the present. The attention to detail is remarkable, from the updated visuals to the improved mechanics. It's clear that a lot of passion and dedication went into making this remake, and it shows in every aspect of the game. As a long-time fan of the original, I was thrilled to revisit this classic in a whole new light. It's a perfect blend of old and new, and I couldn't be happier with the result. This remake is a must-play for both veterans of the series and newcomers.

I've been an avid Resident Evil fan for awhile now and this game is already one of my favorites in the franchise. THIS is how you do a remake, plain and simple. When you want to remake a game, this is the new gold standard. I can't believe how utterly impressed I was after 100%ing this masterpiece in just under a month. It was a game I just couldn't bring myself to put down. Amazing. 

Pros:

- Main story feels way more fleshed out.
- Character designs were all great. Personal favorite was Leon's new look.
- New engine gives the game an absolutely stunning look.
- The enemies are more difficult, which I like. It adds an element of mindfulness when it comes to ammo conservation.
- One of the best things about this game is how they remade Mr. X. He adds a perfect mix of suspense and energy to the game. I can still hear his intimidating footsteps ringing through my ears.

Cons:

- Only thing I can criticize is the odd A/B scenarios which make it hard to map out what is canon.

Overall, it is a gorgeous game with not many flaws. Will definitely be replaying for years to come. Great job CAPCOM. --- [b][i]9.7/10 (and imo, 2019 GOTY)[/i][/b]

This game fucking rules. If you love scary games, you're gonna love this. I first played this on PS4 when it released and had a blast. Despite playing games for so long, this is the first time I actually got to play and complete a title from the RE series. I did not expect it to be challenging and thrilling if not terrifying. I found the puzzles interesting with how it plays into the overall experience.

The music, the atmosphere, it all feels too immersive, and sometimes a little too much -- sorry to all of my friends' ears who've heard me scream out of nowhere.

The RE series is an odd one for me, I have played them out of order originally played RE5 when it came out skipped 6 tried 7 (I really struggle with first person horror) and haven't attempted RE8. So, I was interested in the remakes of RE 2 & 3 and got them on a good deal. I had such a "fun" time playing RE2, I say fun, but I was scared for quite a bit of it at the being. but once the scare factor wore off it is an amazing looking 3rd person survival horror. The story is pretty average and services the game well enough to keep it moving forward.
Graphics in this game are gorgeous to look at, the RE engine does wonders and really makes the game feel so lived in and realistic with character models and the environments. 
Gameplay is pretty good, and I think they did a really good job modernising the feel of the game.  
For and steam sale of $12 including RE3 this is a no brainier. Well worth the time and money I would recommend this to anyone who loves horror and hasn't played a Resident evil game before.

RESIDENT EVIL 2 REmake is great.
I am writing this review after completing Leon Kennedy's Story, and it is great.

This game is unusually short compared to the other 3 games I've played (RE7, VILLAGE, RE1) but it doesn't suffer from it. Resident Evil games aren't known to be crazy long, but always have lots of detail & polish in them, and RE2 is no different. The environments & the detail within them are all great! I have my own personal favorite & least favorite areas in the game, but I won't be naming them to not spoil any of them for you. All of them are good though, I didn't hate any of the areas!

I've never personally played the original Resident Evil 2. I'm actually a newcomer to the series, & this was my 4th game in my "Resident Evil Journey"! So, I don't exactly have any comparisons between REmake & original. I've heard that the REmake is very faithful to the original though, but cannot confirm or deny.

Resident Evil 2's main 2 characters are very good. I played as Leon in my playthrough, & he is great! This game really makes you love him. Claire Redfield doesn't appear very much in Leon's story, so I can't speak much of her, but from the little she is in, she is cool as well!
No matter which character you choose to play in your first run, I highly recommend you either play a second run as the other character, or watch a playthrough of the other characters story. I personally am watching one as I am trying to continue my RE journey quickly (mainly to be done before RESIDENT EVIL 4 REmake is out!) so I want to play RESIDENT EVIL 3 ASAP, but I will most likely be returning to this game later on to play as Claire myself.

Overall, RE2 REmake is a great game, the shorter playtime is more than made up for with the great environments & the detail within them, and also the fact that there is 2 different stories to play through means that the game is twice as long as it first is, even if your second playthrough is most of the same areas.
Unfortunately I am unable to compare this game to it's original iteration from all those years ago, but I have heard it is faithful to the original, so I would hope that is true.

Next up is RE3!

This game is the gold standard with which remakes can be measured.  Just as fun as the original.  I know as I own the game.

A terrifying atmospheric remake of one of (if not the) greatest survival horror games of all time.

Though I never played the original RE2, I have heard this kept the spirit of the game alive while bringing it up to the modern standards of a survival horror game. The over the shoulder view, atmosphere, sound design, and set pieces make this a truly terrifying experience. It's not even the "jump scare" moments but the anxiety you get waiting for something to happen. It kept me on my toes the entire time. This game kept the puzzles alive as well, which was fun and a nice break from the action. The enemies felt for more varied than the first two games (RE1 and RE0), which was nice. The boss fights were not overly complicated and changed up the mechanics each time which was nice. It kept things feeling fresh. The overall combat just felt really good. Ammo, while not completely scarce, was limited and made you think about how to tackle each encounter which I really enjoyed. 

I played entirely on Steam Deck and it played flawlessly. I had it set to high/medium mix graphics, and locked it to 40fps and 40hz refresh rate. It took me a little under 12.5 hours to complete.

Overall, my favorite in the franchise so far. I unfortunately never played the original, but if it is anything close to this I'm sure it is fantastic. Highly recommend for anyone wanting to get into the RE world. Enjoyed it every step of the way.

Impossible to recommend this game and others with RE engine for the Deck users.

Fantastic game. It's my personal favorite Resident Evil, and one of my favorite games to replay as a whole

Graphics

This game has some of the best real-time cutscenes I've ever seen, and some insane detail. The gore is very graphic too. One minor complaint though: the use of screen-space reflections. Turn those off

Gameplay

Gameplay feels like an improved version of Resident Evil 4, with updated controls. I enjoy the mechanic of zombies being nearly impossible to kill, and having to learn to exploit i-frames to beat them. G-Mutants and Ivies are also cool. Lickers are cool if they aren't alone, but if they are, they feel trivial to beat. Mr. X is awesome with how he pursues you unscripted, but sadly he can be easily cheesed. The interconnectedness is another great mechanic, allowing you to explore for optional loot. Bossfights are the biggest highlight, my favorite probably being the Super Tyrant. It feels awesome to dodge or stun him by the skin of my teeth 

Audio

The audio is nice, each enemy has a distinct battle-cry, so you always know how to approach a situation. All the characters have great voice acting. The soundtrack is somewhat lacking, but the highs are high. Mr X's theme feels like that of impending doom. And the lab escape theme (for both Leon and Claire) is also pretty intense. The Super Tyrant theme is the best in my opinion, helping make the boss feel like an epic battle. The credits song is also really good, feeling faithful to 90s grunge

Downsides

There is a severe lack of variety between Leon and Claire and the A and B scenarios. There's some change at the police station in the B scenarios, but then it falls flat. Also, the ending feels out of place? Like Sherry saw both her parents die, and then goes on about getting adopted and buying pets. Weird. There was also no buildup to Code Veronica or RE4 either. Not sure if the former is going to get remade, but the latter was. Anyways, these issues still aren't the end of the world, just a bummer

RE2 follows Leon S Kennedy who is in for a hell of a first day as a police officer, and Claire Redfield who is looking for her brother Chris (A main character in RE1) who has gone missing, now they must survive and escape the city. The game features an A and B scenario where you can complete the game with both characters to get the true ending (though the scenarios aren't that different). Gameplay in RE2 is classic survival horror where you need to explore the map and get key items to progress all the while trying to conserve the limited supplies you have. Probably the best game to get into the resident evil series with (considering the stories of 1 and 2 are only loosely intertwined and the RE1 remaster's controls are a bit obtuse). 10/10 something you'll at least want to experience

man, i wasn't going to do review for re2r, but after playing re3r, i feel like i need to point out that capcom did't screw over this remake too because honestly if i had played re3r and heard about this i wouldn't invest in it, so allow me point out that this game was not ruined like re3 was. first of all the story. the story for this was amazing, i've seen re2 playthoughs on youtube so know what happens there and honestly the writing here  really saves the story. character motivations are much better spelled out, ada doesn't just appear out of nowhere and do nothing for the story anymore and also doesn't just disappear randomly either, thank god, same applies to sherry. you also get to see what happens to the semi driver who hits the car, very nice touch. moving onto the game maps and wow. they rebuilt the whole or re2's areas from the ground up, they also connect very well and have a lot more depth over the original (they also included every import area in the game and replaced boring areas with completely new sections, more specifically for sherry and ada. unlike re3r did) now onto the two main guys you deal with in the game. starting with berkin, his fights are a lot more involved and instead of having random cutscene encounters he's actually shown to be a threat, you also get to see more of what he's capable of, on top of that all of his fights have been vasty improved on. mr x also got a very big upgrade compared to how he was in re2 classic. mr x can now follow you into other rooms and is not easily shaken, he's also been remade to look a lot more intimidating, his boss fight is also a lot better. now onto my compaints. for the record, none of these complaints are enough to make me dislike the game in the slightest way, they all amount to " this shouldn't have been cut". the a and b scenarios are pretty similar, only a few changes and they aren't much, still enough to matter tho. claire and leon also fight most of the same encounters, all but the final boss are the same. the heart and club keys also lead into the same areas, just through a different door, although both characters have different paths they take and differnt characters they encounter as well as different interactions with characters that appear in both stories, which is a nice touch but more differences between scenarios would've been nice. on top of that theres also no interaction between a and b scenarios, but honestly it only ever amounted to "you closed the shutters in scenario a so in b there's no zombies there" so it's not a huge a loss. 
so if you're on the fence about getting i'd say just get it. i've gotten a lot of enjoyment out of it so far and am trying for all of the records, which is saying something because i don't often do that. i hope you enjoy this game as much as i have.

update: so oh boy have i logged a lot more hours. i was loving the game at the time of my original review just replaying it over and over. since then i have tried modding (so much fun), and then i took a massive leap into an area i had never gone before. i started playing the game faster and faster, i was chasing an S+ rank. normally i dont give a damn about rankings in games but something about RE2R has me going crazy to fill out that rank table, i already was loving the game a lot and mods were making me come back to it but holy hell doing such a demanding run of a game like this is not only rewarding but incredibly addicting, getting my first S+ was awesome the second was just as good. finally turned to hardcore so i could do it again there and oh boy was i surprised. they made hardcore  a genuine challenge, saving is not an issue at all but man they properly balanced it to be hard, it's not just the usual "enemies have more health and do more damage", they actually changed item spawns a bit and even took away some items (devious but fun). also yes i got an S+ on hardcore, planning to do it again, and again, and so many more times after. polishing up an already good run is an itch that this game both causes in me and scratches all at once. never before have i cared about ranks but this game changed that. if you've already played it a bit go for an S+ run or try hardcore, the major differences to how you can play the game almost makes it the definitive way to play

My first review was extremely brief so I figured I'd do this game a solid and review it with utmost detail.  I know Resident Evil games have been done-to-death.  There have been many sequels, prequels, spin-offs, movies, TV series, VR simulators, and walking simulators of it over the years (Resident Evil: Survivor).  And it's easy for one to think "stupid Capcom doesn't need any more money- it's all the same crap". That IS true for some Resident Evil sequels- some of them ARE crap part 5 for example.  You're in Africa and you play as Chris Redfield: The Lamest Protagonist Ever.  Sheva is surprisingly more interesting.  "Chris are you okay?  You gotta be careful!" "Chris are you okay?  You gotta be careful!" God Sheva SHUT UP.  Where are the zombies?  I'm fighting mutated tribesman?  The final boss is Albert Wesker?  This game did not age well.  (Part 5 remake is gonna suck a**)

But in 2018 when Capcom announced that a Resident Evil 2 remake was in the works I was f****** STOKED.  

It's been out for 4 years now and I still play this like once a week.  Now that's re-playability.

The roadmap for this remake was already laid out for the developers (the 1998 game was a masterpiece).  Guns, chicks, rookie cops, zombies, viruses, mutants, resource management, the london symphony orchestra- all a blueprint for what could be the greatest remake in the history of remakes.  All they had to do was pull it off.

At a time when games are abysmally woke, unfinished, buggy, pay-to-win, and straight up greedy, here comes Resident Evil 2 remake to PULL DOWN THEIR PANTS AND S*** ON ALL OF THEM!

First off, it's extremely well-balanced.  The game is generous enough to give you exactly what you need, but not so much that it's boring because it will IMMEDIATELY challenge you with those said items.  Some kind of built-in AI that actively adjusts the difficulty by analyzing what you have.  This dynamically changes your run, and will force you to adapt.  And when it sees you're getting too much help- it throws you a curveball.

Playthrough after playthrough I've found that every interaction is different.  Sure monsters may appear in the same room as last time, but no two interactions are the same.  Repetitive but not tedious.  Difficult but not impossible.  

Resident Evil 2 differs from other survival horrors in that it actively changes.  It's also fair- it only punishes you when you do something stupid.  It doesn't punish you for no f****** reason like the Amnesia series games.

Maybe you'll play the classic 1st Scenario: all guns all items readily available and playthrough is reminiscent of your memories of the game as a kid, instinctively running down those corridors trying to remember what you did back then.

Maybe you want to go asymmetrical and play the 2nd Scenario: all item locations have been juxtaposed and Mr X keeps the adrenaline pumping as you literally have no time to manage your inventory.  GET OUT OF THE DAMN WAY!  I love it.

The story stays true to the original, it's exactly the same.  I mean EXACTLY like it even takes place in 1998.  That's good: I hate when they try to modernize the media to appeal to a younger audience. The younger audience is stupid.  The younger audience plays GTA V.  The younger audience doesn't know their a** from a hole in the ground.  But developers ALWAYS cave and thus ALWAYS butcher the legacy game to appeal to the younger audience, because they know these youngsters will throw money at it if it features Ariana Grande as the soundtrack.  If the in-game characters use TikTok.  If the main protagonist has a vag***.  (Hey I'm all for female protagonists don't get me wrong- I love me some ladies.  But it become extremely tiresome though because the women are always social justice warriors).  Claire is not a social justice warrior (thank God), she's just a lost chick trying to find her brother. 

The problem is when you modernize the remake too much it doesn't stay true to the original media.  It becomes a different animal.  You end up with a sh**y movie called "The Departed" where all the gangsters have cell phones and whack eachother in-between phone calls.  Maybe I'm rambling but you can't always expect a franchise to change their core product just to appeal to the stupid minority.

And fortunately, that's NOT the case with this installment.  

The only thing that HAS changed, and for the better I'm sure most players would agree, is the fixed camera angles.  They completely ditched the fixed camera angles and went full-on Dead Space 3rd-person perspective.  For it's time the fixed camera angles worked- but it's not appropriate for the 2019 remake.  With better tech comes the potential for better gameplay.  They saw an opportunity and they took it.  So the fixed-camera angles were layed to rest.

Some would argue "it's not the same game then".  True, but tell me this: have you played Resident Evil 1 remake?  It's boring as f*** am I right?  They kept the fixed camera angles in that game and it completely ruined it!  Slowed the entire pace of the game, those door animations are so tedious to watch OMFG just kill me now.  I'm falling asleep over here.

They've also added "Challenge Modes" that weren't in the original game: Reach the end of the map playing as various NPC's from the base game.  It's basically an obstacle course.  Super difficult.  Complete these missions and you unlock rewards like infinite ammo and character accessories. 

I could go on for days but to keep it brief Resident Evil 2 remake is a schematic for everything a good remake SHOULD be.  They covered all the bases.  Left nothing to be desired.  This game has everything.  It leaves you feeling full.  Like you just ate a steak dinner with a glass of fine wine.

Buy it at full price or sale price it doesn't matter.

[h1]Short, sweet and well worth your time[/h1]

Honestly I don't have much to say other than if you're at all interested in this series or just want a relatively good survival horror game, this is a pretty good pick.

The environments are gorgeous, and level designs is pretty solid overall, especially with how it encourages backtracking, the 2nd Story/NG+ approach actually made me want to replay the game even if it didn't change too much.

[h1]Really the only thing I'll complain about here are the bosses[/h1]
These devolve into boring matches where you just start kiting them around.
They're repetitive, annoying and overall I just didn't have much fun with them.

[h1]Besides that, it's pretty good[/h1]
The Story, while not winning any awards, does it job and it a notable improvement from RE1, as Leon and Claire have very different stories.
The remade gameplay feels pretty nice and the environments look great, very easy recommend.

Leon and Claire still have separate stories, but it’s not like in the original.
Still a solid 9/10 for me and one of my favorite Games.

Resident Evil 2 is the prime exampel of what remakes should be all about. In general i don't specially appreciate remakes of old games i much more prefer remastering old games. Because that is to give a something old a new coat of paint while retaining the original aesthetics, gameplay and in general how people remembered it. While a remake can easily become a whole different game but in the case of Capcom remaking Resident Evil 2 i approve of the result. 

The game has great story that step-by-step lures to into the horror of Raccoon City. It delivers a horrifying atmosphere that are worthy of all my praise. The very first encounter with Mr. X is something i found very scary and intimidating. Ammo scarcity, crafting, sneaky zombies lurking in the dark adds so much to the overall feeling of this survival horror masterpiece. Aesthetics, atmosphere, gameplay, graphics and sound are masterfully put together which combined creates a modern classic that will be an benchmark if you want to remake a game.

The game play & story was phenomena and very memorable.

"Resident Evil 2" invites players into an unforgettable journey for those who revel in the horror and suspense genres. This game blends a classic story and characters with contemporary gameplay, representing the pinnacle of survival horror.

Players take control of iconic characters, Leon S. Kennedy and Claire Redfield, as they navigate the horrors of Raccoon City's zombie infestation. In this oppressive atmosphere, players must solve cleverly designed puzzles and engage in harrowing battles against terrifying creatures to survive and uncover the mysteries.

"Resident Evil 2" draws players in with stunning visuals and immersive sound design. With danger lurking around every corner, the game's atmosphere will keep you on the edge of your seat. Well-placed jump-scares and tense moments ensure that the game constantly keeps you on edge.

Additionally, the game offers different story paths and gameplay options, enhancing replayability. You can start with either character and experience different endings, adding layers to the narrative.

"Resident Evil 2" is a masterpiece that reimagines a classic horror game in a modern light, delivering a chilling experience for fans of the genre. As you follow in the footsteps of these characters and struggle to survive, it stands as a significant milestone in the history of horror gaming. This game is an absolute must-play for anyone who appreciates horror and suspense.

[h3]Preface[/h3]
Before sharing my opinion on the game, I feel like it is imperative for me to share that I have never played any Resident Evil game before. Basically Resident Evil 2 Remake is my first time playing a Resident Evil series and to be honest it made me quite interested in the series. The game follows the story of Leon & Claire in Raccoon City after the city has been engulfed by a deadly virus which turns most residents into zombies. 

[h3]The Positive[/h3]
The gameplay is generally quite linear which isn't to say that it isn't hard but it depends on the difficulty you play on. Hardcore will be harder as it name implies with harder hitting enemy and lesser resources to be found. Mr. X or Tyrant depending on how you refer him will also chase faster. Now, I really like Mr. X, it adds another layer to the game as you can't linger on an area for too long as he will come looking for you. He is a menace, he will still find you wherever you are and especially if you are Leon. During my gameplay for both Leon & Claire, I can feel that he chases Claire less often. Is this some sexism from Mr. X? Glad it's 1998 and not 2023, otherwise he would already be cancelled. Jokes aside, I really liked him. The puzzles aren't overly complicated nor is it overly simplified. For me it's just as balance as it can get. Honestly, the story is pretty normal but it isn't bad by any means and I had fun playing the game. The overall gameplay is relatively short and most of my time is spend running or hiding from Señor X. There's also bonus content which you can play after you have completed the main game, I think the additional content is definitely worth checking out. Throughout my gameplay, I didn't really have anything bad to say about it. I really find it enjoyable.

[h3]The Game Design[/h3]
Despite the game being almost 5 years old, the graphics still holds up quite good. From modelling all the way to it's environment and texture, it really is remarkable how well it looked. I really appreciate that they redesigned Claire's outfit, I think this new looks definitely fits her better. The graphic isn't as demanding as it's newer releases and honestly I think it will work great even with a 6GB card unless you are the type of person that cranks every settings to ultra. The addition of Ray Tracing honestly did little to nothing to enhance the graphic. I for one believe it looks good as it is. On to the voice acting and environment sounds, I believe the team did a great job. For the music, there's really nothing much to be add, it fits well and overall I really liked it.

[h3]Overall[/h3]
To conclude, I definitely enjoy the game as a whole. Rarely if ever encountered any bugs and the game works really well. I think Capcom did a fantastic job with this remake, hope we'll get to see more from them. Honestly, I think the game is definitely worth the asking price if you are a fan of Resident Evil game and even if you aren't, I think this will be a good game to start from.

The first three entries of Resident Evil were among my favorite games for PS1. They were scary and brutal, and I loved them for that. When I saw that Capcom is releasing a remake of RE2, I knew I'll just have to buy it.
Resident Evil 2 offers the player a choice between two characters at the beginning of the game. Both characters (Leon and Claire) have a similar campaign, but there are some differences which make the game worth completing twice. The story takes place in zombie-infested Raccoon City, shortly after the events from the first Resident Evil game. Like in any true survival horror, your main goal is to survive while struggling to make every bullet count.
It's quite obvious right from the bat that this is a remake of the highest quality. The graphics and visual effects are truly outstanding and every movement seems natural and smooth. I don't think I've ever seen more "realistic" zombies in any game or even a movie. The music and sound effects are also impressive, on par with the graphics. Despite using dynamic camera, the game still manages to capture the characteristic creepy atmosphere from the original. Some new mechanics have been introduced (like the ability to board up the windows) and they blend in pretty nicely. Although you can find a variety of weapons and ways to upgrade them, you'll always be short on ammunition. This creates a feeling of constant dread in the player and makes the game incredibly interesting. The storyline is very engaging and I've often found myself chained to the chair, unable to stop playing. There are also a couple of bonus game modes which unlock after finishing the main storyline, but nothing notable story-wise. Incredibly, I didn't notice a single bug during both of my playthroughs - my respect to the developers. My only remark would be aimed at the boss fights, which are fairly scripted and sometimes tend to be annoying. I'd also like to see more story-oriented content added, but that would probably be an overkill.
I had high expectations, but this remake is really excellent. Hands down one of the best horror games ever made.

The perfect remake.

This has got to be one of the best games in the whole Resident Evil series. I've played the original, and I get where people are coming from when they say it's not exactly like the old version. But honestly, I think this game kicks it up a notch. The only bit that's a bit meh is the A/B scenarios – they could've done those better.

When it comes to the story, they've kept it mostly the same whether you pick Leon or Claire. Back in the day, playing A/B or Leon/Clair would give you totally different stuff happening. But even with that comparison aside, this game is seriously amazing.

Now, the highlight for sure is Mr. X. That guy is a total game-changer. He stalks you non-stop, amping up the tension big time. On hardcore mode, where resources are scarcer than ever, you've got to think hard about dodging him 'cause if he shows up with a bunch of zombies or lickers, it's pretty much game over.

On the flip side, the sewer part is a letdown in my book. I'm so done with sewer levels – they're just plain boring. But the lab part, now that's something different. The whole clean and sleek vibe is a fresh take compared to the usual grimy labs. And that boss fight with Birkin in the lab – that's the good stuff right there.

All the boss fights in this game are a blast, although I kinda miss the old Birkin design. It was cool seeing him change between fights in the original, especially his final dog form – that was something. In this version, his last form is just this blob thing on a train, and you're basically unloading everything you've got on it.

To wrap it up, this game rocks the Resident Evil series in a big way. Sure, it's got some differences from the OG, but honestly, they've made it better in many aspects. Mr. X amps up the fear factor, and even though the A/B stuff could've been spiced up, the game as a whole is seriously impressive. Just ignore the sewer part, enjoy the sleek lab, and relish the awesome boss fights.

[h1]Resident Evil 2 Remake - 9/10[/h1]

[h2]Positives:[/h2]

[b]Stunning Graphics:[/b] The visual fidelity of Resident Evil 2 Remake is exceptional. The attention to detail in the environment, character models, and lighting makes the game incredibly immersive.

[b]Atmospheric Sound Design:[/b] The audio design enhances the horror experience, from the eerie footsteps to the subtle groans of zombies. It adds depth to the game's atmosphere and keeps you on edge.

[b]Nostalgic Remake:[/b] The game does an excellent job of modernizing the classic while preserving the core elements that made the original Resident Evil 2 a fan-favorite. It's a nostalgic trip for long-time fans while being accessible to newcomers.

[b]Two Perspectives:[/b] Playing through both Leon and Claire's campaigns offers a fresh perspective on the events in Raccoon City. It adds replay value and encourages multiple playthroughs.

[b]Tense Survival Horror:[/b] The limited resources and the ever-present threat of Mr. X create a tense atmosphere that keeps you on your toes. Managing your ammo and health becomes a crucial aspect of the gameplay.

[b]Level Design:[/b] The intricate level design of the Raccoon City Police Department and other areas makes exploration rewarding. Finding shortcuts and hidden items adds to the sense of discovery.

[b]Strong Character Development:[/b] Leon and Claire are well-developed characters with their own motivations. Their interactions with other survivors and the unfolding story create emotional investment.

[h2]Areas for Improvement:[/h2]

[b]Limited Interactions:[/b] Despite Claire and Leon sharing similar paths, the game misses an opportunity for more meaningful interactions between them. Enhanced dialogue and collaboration could have added depth to their relationship and the overall narrative.

[h2]Conclusion:[/h2]

Resident Evil 2 Remake successfully captures the essence of the original while delivering a modernized and engaging survival horror experience. The visuals, audio design, and nostalgic elements create a truly immersive journey through Raccoon City. While the occasional bullet sponge enemy is a minor drawback and the limited interaction between Claire and Leon is noticeable, these do not significantly detract from the overall enjoyment. Fans of the series and newcomers alike will find Resident Evil 2 Remake to be a must-play title that offers both tense gameplay and a trip down memory lane. With its compelling story, well-designed puzzles, and thrilling survival horror gameplay, Resident Evil 2 Remake earns a solid 9/10 rating.

Resident Evil 2 Remake is an absolute masterpiece! It flawlessly revitalizes the classic survival horror experience with stunning graphics, intense gameplay, and nostalgic callbacks. The attention to detail and atmospheric design create an immersive world that keeps you on the edge of your seat. Whether you're a longtime fan or new to the franchise, this game is a must-play, delivering both excitement and a sense of nostalgia in equal measure.
legal
Good game but crashes a lot

TL;DR: This game needs really thick nostalgia glasses to look good. 

Long version: I haven't played the original, so I was coming into this unbiased. I was immediately drawn in by the incredibly immersive, well paced start of the game, with the terrific ambiance of the zombie attacked building; I will give credit where credit is due, this game did an amazing job in the ambiance, I felt more immersed and stressed than I did in Dead Space or in TLOU. But then, unfortunately, the gameplay happened. 

Everything about it is illogical and poorly implemented - starting from the fact that apparently shooting a zombie in the eye, into the brain, from point-blank range 4 consecutive times is not effective enough to kill it, coming through a couple of unnecessary "ticking clocks" in some situations (a big, unkillable enemy teleporting out of nowhere in a room next to you and chasing you is not a way to make the haunting atmosphere more intense, it's a way for me to uninstall in laughter at the bad design) and all the way through ALL THE RIDICULOUS PUZZLES. And they are ridiculous. 

Don't take me wrong, a well implemented, rational puzzle is a good way to provide a much needed smoothness in the pacing of a game of this kind, give some breathing room, but the puzzle must have the semblance of sense to not break any illusion of verisimilitude. Why are there multiple doors with different pretty symbols in a damn police station? How does a badge get into a bejewelled box unlocked through a crystal on a scepter held by a statue that is missing its left hand? Why do I need a knife to just remove some half-assed duct tape off a board? Why do I need to get a damn card to open a garage door to get out when literally any window would have the same function? 

This also kinda swings back to another weaksauce point, which is the plot - it's nonsensical, and any attempts to justify puzzles using the plot as an excuse somehow make both of them worse. The dialogue is cringy and unnatural. 

I really cannot stress how great the atmosphere is, and as such how tremendously worse every other aspect of the game is to manage to completely ruin that.

P.S. I could also write an essay on all the QoL improvements that are supposed to be in any modern game worth even a single buck, like a free saving system and inventory space that isn't convoluted for the sake of being convoluted, but I feel like I already overspent by buying this on a deep sale and don't want to feel like I am wasting something further on the game by writing more. But I could. 

P.S.S. After finishing the game (I.e. true ending, B run with the other character)so I can kinda feel like I am making my money's worth, no, I don't want to change my review one bit. If anything, my opinion of it is worse, there was nothing redeeming about the second run and the "different perspective" as elements that made no sense to repeat themselves repeated themselves, and everything annoying I stressed above was actually even more underlined. I don't know which is the best 3rd person action horror game, but this is definitely not even close to being there.
mantap

Although I will always believe that the Resident Evil franchise is silly (anyone who plays any of these games for long enough will be able to tell), this game has ended up meaning a lot to me.

I played this game with a person that I will never be able to explain to anyone. I always try to talk about things and express myself regarding them, yet this person has been able to make me feel things I thought were impossible. I will never forget these memories. If you are reading this, thank you for everything.

Playing through this game was complicated for me, as it was my first ever RE experience, and I played it on Hardcore, as the person I played the game with told me it was really easy. I'll have to admit, it was easy, but it was also really annoying. Its combat system feels janky and unrewarding; the saves and their placement are not always the best; its map design can be quite tedious to walk through; yet, I still really liked the game.

With this game, I've realized that our enjoyment is definitely defined by more than things such as graphics, gameplay, storyline, etc. A game is an experience, after all, and all of our experiences are specially woven into our lives by all the factors that surround them. Although we all play the same game, it's different for all of us. Isn't that the magic of life?

Regardless of the silly story, characters, events, dialogues, items, etc., I enjoyed this experience a lot. It is not always possible to enjoy experiences like these. To whoever is reading this, please try to realize the beauty of living and the world around you. Even during the worst of times, there's still going to be at least one thing to be grateful for: having the possibility of living one more day. To live one more day means having hope. One cannot lose all hope unless one wants to lose the meaning of living.

I am writing this review as an ode to hope. Watching myself play parts of this game, laughing and screaming, and ultimately loving someone, has made me realize just how much I have enjoyed my life. Although the moments in which everything seems calm and beautiful are fleeting or ephemeral, it is important to always strive to have more of them.

To whoever is reading this, if there's anything that you want to do with your life that you are scared of trying, please go out and do so immediately. It is fear that limits our capacity to live. Try living a little more every day. Get a new hobby, read a new book, try a new game, or talk to that girl or guy that you've been interested in for a long time. At the end of the day, what matters is that you tried. We always have to, and we always have to continue trying. To live is to try.

I hope that you are having a great day.
For us, the future, love, hope, and obviously, life.

Great replay value.

Loved it.  It's not often you'll get me to play through a game twice, but here we are.  I played through it with Claire first and then with Leon.  Their story branches out and the game plays out slightly different depending on who you choose.  You will do things in different orders and there is one specific mission that is unique for each character.

The devs did a fantastic job of both honoring the original AND creating a modern day experience, with fantastic visuals, acting, and action.

This game is a lot of fun, but it has its sour moments when you're out of ammo/healing and bumbling around trying to dodge boss attacks like its Dark Souls without a dodge roll. Bosses feel like you kind of have to "muscle" your way through them just by spending your saved resources which you might not have unless you know the game like the back of your hand. 

But perhaps that's part of the charm. Because resources are scarce, every action you take feels like it will have huge consequences down the line which really works to keep you engaged. 

But while it's a difficult game that can be rewarding to play, if you do learn the game really well, playing it kind of feels like just following a checklist. But up until that point, just learning the game and the layout of the map is a lot of fun.

Also, the game has a story that somehow works well even though it rides a line between being serious and silly.

WOULD be a fantastic game. Unfortunately, if you play TOO well it starts taking 10+ head-shots to kill every single standard zombie. Resident Evil apologists will say the deliberately coded and unavoidable "adaptive difficulty" enhances the experience. It doesn't. It coddles bad players and punishes good ones. It'd be fine if ammo was also adaptive, but it isn't. Still one of the stronger games in the franchise. Grab it on sale.

Resident Evil 2 (2019) is a remake of the original Resident Evil 2 released in 1998. Take the role of Leon Kennedy, a cop-in-training being transferred to the Raccoon City Police Department. As he arrives in Raccoon City, he'll notice that a violent outbreak has ravaged the city, turning citizens into infected zombies and regular animals into deadly creatures. Carefully manage your resources and navigate through the police department and other hidden aspects of Raccoon City to uncover the mysterious origin of the outbreak and put an end to it before all hope is lost.

RE2 is a survival horror game focused around inventory management and puzzle solving. Leon has a very limited inventory meaning as you traverse environments you'll have to make choices and sacrifices on what items you'll carry with you, what items you'll come back for, and what items you'll have to leave behind. You'll always carry some weapons and ammo, but not too much because you'll learn pretty quickly that these zombies are resilient, and your best path forward is often by dodging the zombies completely. Health supplies are also limited though, so risking leaving zombies alive can put your health at a risk and leave you wounded for long periods of time. RE2 is definitely difficult, as you won't be able to just sprint through and gun down anything in your path. Careful routing and resource management will be key to getting you out of your predicaments.

RE2 is pretty scary at times as well, though I would say the focus is less on scares and more on tension-building. You're constantly surrounded or being stalked by creatures whose only purpose is to turn you into  mush as you walk around these dimly-lit environments that are eerily quiet after the human population has abandoned them. While Raccoon City and the other areas you'll explore are unsettling set pieces, I couldn't help but also be fascinated by the visuals throughout. The RE Engine used to power the graphics of this game is an absolute monster and delivers some stunning details, both in cutscenes and in gameplay. 

Once you've finished the story there's a lot of reason to revisit the game. Re-play the story as Claire Redfield, the secondary main character of RE2 that Leon frequently encounters, and see what she was up to while Leon was exploring the police department. Play the New Game+ variants of their storylines to unlock the true ending. Try out the hardcore difficulties that limit how often you can save and increase the danger of enemies. Check out the extra scenarios, little side stories about how the outbreak affected other people in Raccoon City. The modding scene for RE2 is also pretty solid, I did a couple extra playthroughs of the game with mods enabled and there were some absolutely fantastic graphics and gameplay mods.

RE2 is a fantastic display of how a remake should be done. Taking the base game and completely rebuilding it as if it were released in the modern-day, while still retaining what made it special at release. It's got a great balance between horror, action, and puzzles that will make it an intense but enjoyable experience from start to finish. I highly recommend picking up RE2, especially when it goes on sale and especially in the bundle that includes the RE3 remake as well.

If you plan on buying the game or have bought it and notice stuttering or any sort of lag despite having a decent Video Card. Go to your library and right click the game , after which click on properties , betas , go in beta participations and switch to dx11_non-rt - dx11_non-rt , a new update to the game came up recently , it only adds RTX , but some players have reported that the new update makes the game run slower than usual , if your card cant run RTX anyway (like mine) you shouldn't notice any change , you should still have access to your progress after changing to the Beta. It's kind of a 50/50 , it may make your game run better , it may not. In my case it started running muuuuch smoother after i switched , im using a gtx 1660s (for reference)

Resident evil 2 remake sets the standard that all remasters should follow. Modernising the gameplay
introduced in the original. By switching to an over-the-shoulder perspective and removing the fixed camera, it plays exactly the way a modern game should, whilst not straying to far from the spirit of the original. the RE engine makes an already terrifying game even more horrifying with introduction of photorealistic textures and the re-imagining of the RPD. The game allows you to play as either Leon or Clair, letting us see their perspective and place in the story and the inclusion of a second run allows for high replay value. 

VERDICT

Game play - 10/10

Enemies - 10/10

[h1]Comentario Analítico: "Resident Evil 2 - Remake (2019)[/h1]

El primer Resident Evil fue remasterizado para la GameCube en el 2002, republicado en 2008 en la Wii y actualizado y republicado nuevamente en Steam en 2015 junto con una edición modernizada del Resident Evil Zero.

Con su secuela el tratamiento fue distinto, el Resident Evil 2 original fue publicado variedad de ocasiones en diversidad de plataformas hasta que en 2019 se estrenó su Remake, desarrollado con el novedoso RE Engine que anteriormente había dado luz a Resident Evil 7.

El trabajo realizado acá es excelente, una adaptación a los estándares de tiempos modernos totalmente fiel al concepto original sin importar los años de distancia entre uno y otro. La dinámica de exploración, backtracking y acertijos se conserva y se adapta junto a la exigencia de conservar y administrar apropiadamente la munición y los objetos, tal como el clásico del 98 pero más accesible, así como logró Resident Evil 4 en el 2005 al colocar la cámara detrás de la espalda.

Técnica y kinestésicamente tan refinado como un Resident Evil moderno; espiritualmente tan único e inexplicable como un Resident Evil clásico.

[b]¿En conclusión?[/b] Excelente remake, espero que otras franquicias como Silent Hill, Parasite Eve y Dino Crisis reciban este mismo tratamiento.
The worst Resident Evil I ever played...

Man after a two-year break, I decided to play it again, this time on HARDCORE and... EVERY MOMENT is unforgettable. You plan every move, take into account every item, every zombie, every hallway, every single bullet, every gameplay probability.  One flashbang explodes in the right place and saves your life. One head gets blown off and allows you to save your game after 2 hours of horror...

You notice and appreciate a whole new level of how this game is crafted. And its so well done I actually died only 3 times in six hours. But I was on the verge of death countless times. Just the right amount of desperation.

Amazing experience - the game really knows how to make you feel scared, not because you can hear zombies creeping around a corner or the constant threat of Mr. X, but because every encounter is a choice. You are always on limited ammo so you need to be really careful what you use it for, and it takes time to kill them too.

The police station made me feel so much dread (in a good way) and is incredibly well designed, the story kept me hooked and goes in unexpected places, whilst feeling interesting due to the various scenery changes, and the fact that there isn't a map marker for your main quest encourages you to explore and risk your life - the game really doesn't hold your hand at all.

Even if you're scared easily, I'd give this a go. It's fun to feel like you're going to get killed at any second, and the moment to moment gameplay is fantastic!

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

Graphics and Visuals:
From the moment I stepped foot into the dark, desolate streets of Raccoon City, I was spellbound by the stunning graphics and attention to detail. Every corner of the city is beautifully rendered, with eerie lighting, haunting shadows, and atmospheric effects that contribute to a palpable sense of dread. Character models are incredibly realistic, showing off the emotions of fear and exhaustion etched on their faces as they fight for survival. The grotesque and terrifying designs of the various zombies and monsters are nothing short of impressive, giving players a sense of constant unease.

Gameplay:
The gameplay in Resident Evil 2 Remake flawlessly blends classic survival horror mechanics with modern sensibilities. The third-person perspective places you right in the thick of the action, making every encounter with the undead a heart-pounding experience. The scarcity of resources forces players to make crucial decisions about when to fight and when to evade, adding a strategic layer to the gameplay. Furthermore, the puzzles scattered throughout the game are ingeniously designed, striking the perfect balance between challenge and reward.

Story and Atmosphere:
Resident Evil 2 Remake is a masterclass in crafting a gripping narrative. The story remains faithful to the original but is skillfully expanded upon to give more depth to the characters and their motivations. Claire Redfield and Leon Kennedy, the iconic protagonists, are expertly portrayed, making you genuinely care about their plight in this nightmarish setting. Additionally, the game's atmosphere is thick with tension and dread, aided by the hauntingly atmospheric soundtrack that intensifies the overall experience.

Level Design:
The level design in Resident Evil 2 Remake is a testament to the developers' creativity. Each area is meticulously crafted, offering a perfect balance of exploration and danger. The police station, in particular, is a masterpiece of architectural ingenuity, with interconnected rooms and secret passageways that keep players on their toes. Additionally, the varying environments, from the dimly lit sewers to the foreboding underground laboratories, maintain the feeling of a living, breathing nightmare.

Replayability:
Despite completing the game multiple times, I find myself eager to revisit Raccoon City again and again. The game's branching paths, multiple difficulty modes, and unlockable content provide excellent replay value. Furthermore, the introduction of the "2nd Run" feature, offering a fresh perspective on the story, encourages players to dive back into the terrifying world of Resident Evil 2 Remake.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, Resident Evil 2 Remake is a triumphant return to survival horror greatness. Capcom has revitalized a beloved classic, presenting it in a way that will both thrill longtime fans and captivate newcomers. With its top-notch graphics, pulse-pounding game play, engrossing story, and haunting atmosphere, this game stands as a prime example of how to remake a classic while preserving its soul. Whether you're a veteran of the original or new to the series, Resident Evil 2 Remake is a must-play title that will leave you breathless and begging for more.

Survival horror at its finest. Great remake that looks beautifully and plays amazingly well. Now even better on PC. Remember to conserve your ammo throughout the game and save your best stuff for the bosses. But if you have to shoot a zombie, I recommend just shooting them in one of their legs till it snaps so that they are left just crawling. When you finally meet Mr.X, he will roam around and patrol the police department essentially stalking you. Gunshots and explosives will alert him to your location so try not to make too much noise if you don't want him chasing you. The louder his footsteps are, the closer he is to you so run!! Don't waste your bullets on him, but if you must, shoot him a couple times in the head and he will be stunned for a good second. I recommend getting the OG RE2 soundtrack for this game bc it makes the experience much more intense. I also recommend playing this game with a good set of headphones bc it makes the game much more immersive.

This game is a fine wine and certainly worth your time. It was designed in 2 ways:
1) To be a slow burn, thrilling and frightening survival horror which you complete in 15 to 20 hours. OR

2) A fly by the seat of your pants speed run game that can be completed in less than 2 hours with experience and practice. 

I wholeheartedly recommend this game for fans of the original and fans of survival horror-- It certainly lives up to the originals pedigree - while being it's own game, as well. I had so much fun with it. I hope you do too.

Great Game, Great Remake

This is the title that many people use to exemplify how a remake should be done. 
Almost everything about this game it's perfectly done, like the mechanics, the story, the acting, the enemies, THE GUNS (love the variety of guns), and the one of the main antagonist: Mr. X. I've played Claire's part and like it a lot, but I grew up with Leon S. Kennedy and I have to say that Leon A is my favourite way to play and replay the game.

One of the best parts of the game is Mr. X himself. He makes you stay alert all the time, which brings a sensation of permanent danger to the player, and makes him act carefully. This detail of gameplay favours immersion at its best.

Unfortunately, the only reason I'm not saying that it's a perfect remake is because I think it lacks something that the original had, which is the variety in each scenario for each character that the original had, but this one has the same story for each character no matter which part you play first.

Apart from that, a really cool and well done game that I really love, totally recommend (also, play the original)
