[h1] BASIC THOUGHTS [/h1]
It allows us to proudly say that this franchise has returned to its good old days. The remake is an incredibly scary experience in a wonderful atmosphere and has so much valuable gameplay that we can repeat it over and over again. Add to this, fantastic graphics, sound design and its good storyline are why you shouldn't miss Resident Evil 2 Remake.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2997195264
[hr][/hr]
[h1] STORYLINES [/h1]
Before I talk about the storylines, there is an interesting thing about the Resident Evil franchise, the [url=https://game.capcom.com/residentevil/en/two.html] EVIL NET [/url] service that allows you to view your game progress with a Capcom ID and connecting it to your Steam account.
Another thing that I need to say is the Steam Cloud Service, make sure to turn it on to upload your save files on the Steam Cloud Service, the only thing you need to pay attention to is that every slot in the game for saving will be about 5 MB. I recommend using less number of slots to reduce their syncing time.

[b] Spoiler alert !!! [/b]

[spoiler]The game has two storylines, each of them can be played by two main characters in parallel ways
 [b]Leon A - Clair B
 Clair A - Leon B[/b]
 After selecting NEW GAME, you have two options, Leon's story and Clair's story (each of which leads to Leon A and Clair A) but the game is not over yet, a SECOND RUN option will be unlocked in the menu which will allow you to play the game as second character as soon as you finish A. by putting these two storylines together, you will find out to the main story.[/spoiler]

But this is not the end of the story, the game allows you to get infinite knife and ammo after completing some challenges (Hardcore S+), which can be fun.
what I am trying to say is That [b]it is not a game that you just play once and leave it out![/b]

[h1] GRAPHICS [/h1]
Resident Evil 2 is really great in terms of graphics and audio aspects.  The creators of the environments of the original version have recreated the atmosphere in this version with excellent graphics, and the appearance of various characters, from the main characters to bosses and side characters, has been designed in the best possible way.  In addition to these, we also see perfect voice acting. Considering the eighth-gen graphics, they have excellent performance on current configurations so [b]you will enjoy the game even with a mid-range PC.[/b]

this game changes lives

First RE Game. Was a ton of fun!

The puzzles are not too easy not too difficult and the game doesn't script your every move, i.e. You can search for the locker combination or just brute force it. May not be the intended way but it's great that the game isn't restricting.

In some situations, it's very obvious that the Zombies have scripted spawns. Some zombies are invulnerable until you run into them so they can then jumpscare and attack you. Little bit annoying, but ok. Would have had the same outcome but with a better atmosphere if you had significantly less ammo so you would actually be hesitant to potentially waste it on corpses.

2nd Run is not as satisfying because you have to solve puzzles and fight bosses that you fought in the 1st Run but it's not too bad. It's not a 1:1 copy. The 2nd Run ramps up a lot faster and you get the key items and weapons much quicker and already have a good idea of what you need to do. And you do get a very different POV of the story, entire new areas, and bosses.

All in all, an amazing game.

This game is arguably the perfect survival horror experience. From the disturbing enemy designs to the incredible sound design, this game is survival horror at its best. Each playthrough is the perfect length to give the game enough content, while also making replays desirable. Both Leon and Claire's stories are different enough to feel unique, but also have enough similarity to make some areas feel more familiar than others.
Each puzzle can be figured out without looking up guides, while also requiring a decent amount of thought. The guns feel, and sound like guns. 
Mr X is a fantastic tyrant, when you first come across him, you feel terrified at this unkillable beast, but as you learn the game and how to bait/get around him, he turns more into a nuisance than a hulking nightmare. 
TLDR: This game is amazing, and it is survival horror at its best. Play this game.

I recently had the opportunity to play the iconic game "Resident Evil 2," and it was an unforgettable gaming experience. As a fan of survival horror games, I had heard a lot about the title's immersive gameplay and chilling atmosphere. Needless to say, it did not disappoint.

From the moment I started the game, I was drawn into the dark and eerie world of Raccoon City. The game's graphics were incredibly realistic, and the attention to detail in the environment was astonishing. The dimly lit corridors, the haunting sound effects, and the suspenseful music created an atmosphere that kept me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire gameplay.

One of the standout aspects of the game was the well-crafted storyline and character development. I appreciated the depth of the protagonists, Leon and Claire, and their journey through the zombie-infested city. Their encounters with various mutated creatures and the sinister Umbrella Corporation added an extra layer of intrigue to the plot.

The gameplay itself was challenging but rewarding. The scarcity of resources and limited ammunition forced me to carefully plan my every move. The puzzles scattered across the game provided a welcomed break from the constant tension, making me feel like a true survivor trying to uncover the city's dark secrets.

The zombies, of course, were the most terrifying adversaries. Their eerie groans and unexpected appearances around corners kept me in a constant state of unease. I found myself holding my breath every time I had to navigate through a group of them, hoping not to attract their attention.

As I progressed, the game became more intense, and the encounters with more powerful creatures pushed my skills to the limit. I often found myself fleeing from overwhelming situations, adding an element of panic and urgency that only heightened the overall experience.

Despite the chilling atmosphere and intense gameplay, I couldn't help but admire the game's design and craftsmanship. The attention to detail in the character animations, the hauntingly beautiful visuals, and the well-crafted narrative all contributed to making "Resident Evil 2" an exceptional gaming masterpiece.

In conclusion, "Resident Evil 2" is a must-play for any survival horror enthusiast. It successfully captures the essence of fear and excitement, leaving players with a sense of accomplishment and a lasting impression. This gaming experience will undoubtedly stay with me for a long time, and I can't wait to immerse myself in the world of Raccoon City again.

A true modern classic survival horror of what everything Resident Evil is in terms of atmosphere and Aesthetic...if you have never played this game before, i'm doing you a favor if you really want the BEST true experience here....first play it on hardcore don't be a bitch...then try to go in headfirst with trying to figure things out for yourself, definitely recommend playing in dark environment or nighttime, headphones for a must, and if you don't mind it i recommend smoking a doobie  before or during your first run through it takes  the survival horror experience to another level in a way that you feel like you're looking through a window or floating over leons or claires head just watching them and controlling them in a way like they legit feel lifelike, because man i tell you these graphics in this game are groundbreaking imo physics wise as well the dismemberment on the zombies to pretty much any limb, to the detail in gore any where you shoot the zombie on its body to a point sometimes all you see anymore on the zombie is chunk of blood and flesh because you shot it so many times and sometimes they cans still be chasing you depending on how effective your shots are with your pistol, this game NAILED the zombies I can't specify it enough because that's what made RESIDENT EVIL ... RESIDENT EVIL, the way they walk growling/snarling at you at same time walking towards you, its feels unnerving, Like it wastes ZERO time letting you know these zombies WANT TO EAT YOU lol and if you slip up sucks to be you buddy git gud.. and you feel that with the ammo spread accross the game where they don't make you feel too overpowered but to the point where you need to do things timed or placed perfectly or else you just wasted all that ammo and will most likely die later on because of it, unless you are a master with the knife and grenades etc secondary items., also not to mention the few other perfectly done monsters waiting for you in the rpd station. I just feel like the zombies,for example, in this game the way they look and sound walking towards you just give you a classic zombie feel, what i mean by that is they actually feel like a true threat because it's only you, with 4 bullets in the dark with these things  and dont know wtf's going to happen next..l first time is always the best so dont rush it,

The RE2 Remake is the definitive introductory Resident Evil experience. If you've always been curious about the series, this is a phenomenal entry point. It retains the story and atmospheric dread of the original that still makes fans feel like they're experiencing it for the first time. While it has the trappings of a 3rd-person shooter, at it's core it's one big elaborate puzzle or board game. It's about resource conservation and unlocking new paths while gradually expanding the game world and discovering how its locations and plot elements are all intricately interconnected. While the remake modernizes the gameplay in nearly every conceivable way, it retains all the elements that made the original a masterpiece.

After playing through my A Run (With Leon), I was very impressed with Resident Evil 2. It is an impressive survival horror game that is a joy from start to finish. Everything from the puzzles to the exploration were excellently paced meaning there was never a dull moment. As a precursor, this is my first Resident Evil, (after a failed attempt at playing the RE 1 Remaster) so I cannot compare it to the original or any other games in the series beyond what I’ve seen others talk about. From what I have heard, there is cut content from the original RE 2, but for a newcomer, this isn’t much of a bother. I would much rather take the updated graphics and quality of life improvements at the cost of a marginally worse, but still great story. And Leon’s story was exciting. Leon is a rookie cop driven to prove his worth within the force. Upon arriving in Racoon City, he is greeted with a zombie virus that has infected the entire city. He seeks refuge within the police station where he begins to plan his escape out of the city. It is here where you spend a majority of the game, completing puzzles and unlocking rooms in order to help you escape. The puzzles strike a perfect balance between difficulties. I wouldn’t say any were unsolvable, but there were some that required thought and thorough exploration of the map. The police station itself was fun to get lost in, despite the ever present backtracking you must do in order to escape. Progression feels natural as you slowly unlock each room in the station.I would have appreciated more NPC interaction and overall world building, but I suppose the feeling of isolation was intentional in order to keep the player on edge. This was one of the few games I’ve played that really kept me in suspense throughout its entire run time. The scarcity of ammo and lack of a direct manual save meant that each encounter must be met with caution. The gore and lighting also do an incredible job at amplifying this feeling of tension. This game is beautiful and is best played on low brightness in my opinion; it is a small addition to the game that can transform the atmosphere. After you escape the Police Station, you team up with a woman named Ada and the two of you work together to find out the cause of this virus. It is an interesting story of corporate greed that is easy to follow on the surface, but you can’t help but feel like you aren’t being told the whole story. The story isn’t deep by any means, but you really do feel like you’re missing a part of the story by not playing Resident Evil 1. It expects you to know a little bit about Resident Evil 1, which to my knowledge deals with the very beginning of the outbreak. It isn’t a deal breaker, but I wish they spent more time on exposition in the form of audio logs or journals because I don’t expect them to remaster the 1st game any time soon. I enjoyed this second part of the game. It was more linear and story driven which was a nice juxtaposition to the equally entertaining exploration of the Police Station. I found the boss fights to be pretty underwhelming. There were two of them and they honestly felt pretty clunky. The movement in the game is pretty slow and realistic and in the context of fighting giant monsters, just doesn’t make sense. The movement isn’t bad by any means, I just don’t think it fit well with the high intensity of the boss fights

I am a little disappointed at the lack of replayability in this game. I am a little unmotivated to play through Claire’s run as it revisits many of the same sites of the first run. The characters and story may delineate slightly, but on the whole, it seems to be a nearly identical experience with the added hindrance of removing weapons and progress, forcing you to start over from scratch.I will update if/when I decide to do a playthrough with Claire, but as the game stands, It is still an enjoyable experience without it. It nails survival horror and from a newcomers perspective, the story is engrossing. The 2nd run seems to be redundant and some parts of the exposition remain confusing, but on the whole it’s still a strong game. 8/10

Resident Evil 2 Remake is a great showcase of how remake of classic video games can deliver the same (or even better) fun that the original had in the past. It is an excellent upgrade on every fronts.

RE engine, used since RE7, is a major factor in terms of graphics. The game looks great compared to other modern titles. From lighting to textures and animations are all good and run nicely. Even on low & old hardware such as mine (that still used DX11) can run the game fairly smooth. It’s regrettable now that Capcom decides to change the system requirements to compensate for newer hardware with Ray Tracing options.

The devs took so much care and attention with this remake. They didn’t just change everything to be more in line with modern shooting games. They pick and choose features and details taken from the original that resonate more with players. They keep most of the slow and intense horror atmosphere from the original, while also update things that didn’t age well or can be improved. Things such as slow and hard to kill zombies, scarce ammo, inventory management, save system, or even intricate puzzles are making a return. Tank controls & fixed camera angles are removed entirely. It is enjoyable even for fans who didn’t touch games from that era.

In the main campaign you can play as 2 different characters going through (almost) same events and locations. Leon & Claire each has their own stories that are worth playing in any order, much like the original. Both explore a few of the same locations while also offered different objectives, details, secrets & weapons. The remake also offered some scenarios and survival mode for players who want to enjoy more after the finish the main story. It is a complete package.

The game was enjoyable from start to finish. It didn’t frustrate you with backtracking, dead ends, missing puzzles, etc. You can progress through the story with relative ease without worrying much about getting lost or looking up online for clues & walkthrough. There are also plenty of consumables and upgrades for players. The map also features hints and indicators for items that you came across or missed during the campaign.

Overall, I really enjoyed my time with RE2 Remake. It is a solid remake of an already great title in the survival horror genre.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

The game is fantastic overall, with smooth mechanics, impressive graphics, and engaging puzzles. It effectively creates a genuinely terrifying atmosphere, particularly during encounters with the Tyrant and the constant scarcity of ammunition in Hardcore mode is a cherry on top. Yes, the game can be frustrating at times but that's the beauty of it. The story is decent, although not exceptional. One aspect that could have been improved is Claire's campaign. Rather than repeating certain scenes from Leon's playthrough, the developers could have made the two stories more interconnected. It would have been more satisfying to experience new and unique challenges as Claire, rather than revisiting familiar areas and tasks, such as encountering the Tyrant after putting off the fire from the crashed chopper or the greenhouse playthrough where we have to do everything we already have done in the first run. Nevertheless, the game is visually stunning and incredibly immersive. The incorporation of old-school linearity adds to the overall enjoyment.

This video game, and Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, were the video game icons of my youth. I had been craving this game for 21 years before I finally got to play the completely revamped version. I was so afraid that it would not live up to the expectations brought about by my youth. . .but they did it. This is a fantastic re-imagination of the first game. I was so incredibly happy with how well the did all of the Resident Evil remakes so far.

Now, that Resident Evil 4 is done and was a wild success, they should stop. It went downhill on Resident Evil 5 and 6. However, I would absolutely love a remake of Resident Evil: Code Veronica (everyone would, and I wouldn't be surprised if this was next) and the Resident Evil: Outbreak File[s]. Now, the latter game is a lesser known one, and I think the hardcore RE fans will understand.

Anyway, buy the game.

TLDR---
If you want a really good scare, but also gratification for solving puzzles with a healthy balance of strategy (don't waste that ammo) or if you just wanna look at Leon's pretty face, you'll enjoy this game.

As of writing this, i've played this for 14 hours.
this is my first time playing a horror game so as you can expect, i was pausing the game anytime i heard i creak in the floorboards, but because of how the game is structured, i was allowed to pace myself and take my time with the tasks, which felt really nice and i wasn't rushed by the action.
The sound design is FENOMINAL!! (i use a pair of Samson sr850 headphones, lovely things) God from Leons small breaths he draws when he spots a zombie to gunshots in a big, echoey room compared to a small one to the subtle ambience changes when you first visit an area, the sound mixing is the best I've heard in a game by far!
To progress in this game, you do have to grit your teeth and do a fair bit of exploring to find all the pieces to various puzzles, it can get a tad long-winded going all around the map to find a crank to open a door, but if you like that sort of thing, like i do, you'll surely enjoy yourself.
In summery, good adventure, long but gratifying gameplay and Leon. just... Leon.

Felt like the original resident evil games, but modernized. There isn't really anything negative to be said, except for how little content it has if you put aside the 4 replays & bonus content you can do.

6-9 hours of gameplay for both Leon's and Claire's route, totaling 12+ if you want to get both stories.
Clearing both isn't necessary though, since the campaign is 80% same for both. But if you liked the game it's worth to do the second route also.

These routes don't perfectly match story wise, since Leon and Claire are separated at the start of the game, yet in their respective playthroughs they're at the exact same locations & sometimes fighting the same bosses, so it feels less like playing an alternative route and more like playing an alternative timeline.

My first Resident Evil experience. Can't believe I've been sleeping on this series. Note: Turn off AMD Fidelity FX or you'll feel like you need (new) glasses.

Great game. Though it required a change in my mindset to get used to steering my character like it's an oil tanker but after I got used to that it was smooth sailing. So controls are a bit iffy, but only for the first hour or two. Once you realize you're not playing a third-person-shooter it'll be fine.

There's two campaigns. Two characters. You can complete story A on character 1 and story B on character 2. Or do both on the same character. Whatever has your preference. After that you can play a few more arcade bonus missions. So plenty of content.

If you're looking for a game to add to your completionist showcase this one is pretty fun. You may need to replay a campaign but it's so much faster the 2nd time through. Every time you beat something you unlock something that will help you on your next playthrough. The achievements aren't grindy and they're quite straight forward. Get a guide for the Mister Raccoon locations though.

[h1] Review[/h1] 
Initially I was absolutely not interested in seeing a remake of a game I already played. When I played the demo back then I was really surprised how the game turned out to be. I really liked it although I still wished that they would port the original on steam too.

[u]Gameplay[/u]
This time the perspective is switched from fixed camera angles or first-person view to a third person angle. I love change that’s neat. Especially how the controls work, your character is not moving in any way stiff anymore not that I disliked the control scheme in any RE before.

Also, the puzzle nature of the gameplay is back, you run around and find obstacles and try to overcome them, mostly by punching in codes or finding an item, like a key(card) or a valve. Although more “complex” text puzzles of the original are gone. Still this gameplay was always what I liked, coupled together with the enemies and resource management. Which fight should I pick, should I risk a health item or ammo, or reload an old save? Veteran mode is this time the only one that has limited saves via cartridges again. I like that there is a challenging but not overly difficult veteran mode, although there is no difficulty above that.

Combat is fun due to the extra challenges of manually aiming at zombies heads or other enemies that are out there.  They move unpredictable making it absolutely not an easy task. They took again the system with the personal defence weapons from RE1 remake, so the protagonist will stab someone and lose a knife if getting grabbed from the front.

You also find on your way upgrades for your weapons or completely new ones, along with a remake and improvement of the old games level design. Its very familiar but still completely different, especially in the lategame. I found the game absolutely fun from start to finish and cannot really complain much, aside maybe that the backtracking can be a bit too much and the feature that helps you highlight rooms which you completely cleared makes the game a bit too easy on the exploring. I rather wish it would only highlight either main quest items or only being on easy difficulty. S Rank will take you on highest difficulty 2 hours and 30 minutes. My first play through took me closer to 8 hours for a single character. Good length, not too short but not too long.

There are also a few challenges that unlock cosmetics (but there are barely any) or artwork and a couple of extra modes added on. Those extra modes are a minigame that brings you through mostly already seen places and is more combat focused by delivering a mini story. Neat. Sadly extra coop mode or some kind of mercenary mode the franchise is known for. Oh well.

[u]Story[/u]
As in the original you can play through the game as either Leon or Claire. They have some different story aspects but play through most of the same areas. I would say about slightly over 1/3 of their storyline and gameplay is different. You also have the A and B route again, which changes almost nothing in the whole game, I even have the assumption that it changes less than the original did. Main difference is only the new main pistol as mostly ammo for that one will spawn and the starting area of the game. Some puzzles have barely changed and just make the game a bit shorter. This is an aspect they could have just skipped and probably added only so original fanboys are not mad that it didn’t got included.

[u]Sound[/u]
A bit of a let down is the OST. They played it very save by making the OST less interesting. like the original and instead made it much more environmental, save aside a few tracks. Its definitely fine but not that memorable.

Game is available again in a ton of different dubbed languages. Also, the indoor sound design is really neat and the whole SFX they use was my highlight.

[u]Graphics[/u]
You can tweak a lot on the graphical settings. I especially love and give them kudos for actually showing pictures that resemble various effects. In literally all games I deactivate lens flares and bloom, but the pictures showed me an effect I liked so kept it. Neat stuff!

To the graphics itself, the game can run on a potato but offers scaling that you can have problems even with very modern hardware. Its great that they added this amount of customization. Its not the best looking game, but full of details and little animation quirks, like when zombies are about to grab you but you kill them in the same moment they fall against you while the protagonist pushes them off their body or they try to dodge them.

[u]Conclusion/TL;DR[/u]
I really absolutely enjoyed my playthrough. It’s a short game with lots of replay value which I absolutely like. The remake stays somewhat true to the original but offers so many new ideas and environments making it a must play for people who liked the ps1 game. The only downsides I have are a few nitpicks which are overshadowed by the fun core gameplay loop.

(Review subject to change)

Just finished my playthrough of Leon and I have to say this one was very enjoyable. For context, I never played the original so this review is unbiased in that regard.

This game functions very similar to RE:0 in terms of its puzzle layout - Central location at the start with a mix of puzzle and combat, with more action towards the end of the run. I tend to prefer the starting puzzle sections more than the combat/action but it still carried me through with story.

Characters are fun and voice actors do a good job (better than previous entries). Story is great and paced very well. However, noticeably absent is extra flavour text that you could read by inspecting point of interest in earlier entries (RE:HD and RE:0) - Perhaps this is a theme with the newer games but it was missed.

Combat and Inventory mechanics were great! This game being modern means it can learn from previous entries and do it's best to present the best of both worlds of challenge and ease of use. One thing that did stand out is the ability to perform critical shots, that wasnt present in the locked off camera games. Free aim allows for headshots, meaning that the 'lock-on' button is void. I often found myself rarely using the shotgun and just using the pistol for headshots (unlike HD or 0). The chase sections were some of the most fear inducing that I've experienced in resident evil so far! Made the puzzle solving in certain sections so much more thrilling.

The boss fights were so much more interactive and intuitive. What previous entries lacked, RE:2 makes up for! Bosses have multiple stages, well designed attacks and you can tell if you're damaging it or not. 

Overall, a solid entry in the series without much to complain about.

EDIT: SECOND RUN
The second run leaves alot to be desired. For context, I did Claire second run.

The gameplay is mostly the same, there is alot less ammo and more gun types - which does switch things up. This adds to Claires gameplay being more stealthy than Leons 'run and gun' style. This was a nice change of pace as I didnt need to expend as much ammo after knowing how to take down enemies more effectively. They condensed the intro down alot, which i feel was a bit rushed - this couldve been an opportunity to explore the same areas differently. The police station is mostly the same. Puzzles/doors are solved a bit differently, enough to keep it fresh.

Story wise its a bit of a mess. Sometimes they try to write Claires action matching up with Leons, but due to gameplay needs, you fight the same bosses and the plot becomes out of sync. I think they did a decent job, but it could have been done better. Claires story feels very barren, with alot less NPC interaction.


the 2nd last boss feels like a step down from the 3rd, and the last boss is another step down - i beat both last bosses on the first try, they felt easy. It was a decent cap-off to the story with the true ending. However, the 2nd run does fall down a bit from Leons 1st run.

6. Worth buying and playing.

Really enjoyed losing my Resident Evil virginity. I hate tank controls and never played the old titles. After hearing that it now features a third person view I was happy to try this.

And it didn't disappoint! The atmosphere and level design are great, I loved exploring the police station. I am not really a puzzle guy, but finding all the necessary items and putting them where they belong was a lot of fun. The game never felt boring and Mr. X even gave me a couple jump scares.
The game looks really nice and it runs very smoothly.

The rather slow running speed and the inventory management annoyed me a little at first, but I got used to it rather quickly. The dialogue is corny as hell of course and is to me part of the RE charm.

Replayability is also there, after I finished with Leon I jumped right back in with Claire. The challenges also seem like fun, but I only tried one of them so far.

Looking forward to RE4 when the price is right.

O jogo é muito bom, tem algumas mecanicas meio sem graça, tipo o fato de zombies morrerem com 1 ou 20 tiros e o jogo basicamente te incentivar a fugir de todos os inimigos ao invés de lutar, é mais facil simplesmente nunca atirar do que tentar combater algo, na hora do combate, escopeta se sobressai ja que um tiro mata.

Leon é estupido, não sabe se defender contra um zombie despedaçado, zombies não se decidem  entre ninjas ou mortos vivos, as vezes nunca te percebem, outras giram tão rapido pra te agarrar que a animação chega a cortar.

Gameplay, terror é otimo e tenso, puzzles são irritantes, o jogo permite descartar items de puzzles importantes antes de completa-los o que pode te fazer ficar preso pra sempre em um puzzle, alguns não tem nenhum sentido, são praticamente dedução pura.

O jogo não oferece suporte pra new game plus, simplesmente depois que zera você tem que recomeçar tudo sem nenhum item, o que torna futil se esforçar pra coletar as armas e complementos.

Graficos, cheio de problemas visuais e bugs que ainda estão presente desde o lançamento, não da pra usar o SSR e mesmo com ele off ainda tem glitchs

Independente dessas coisas, jogo é incrível 8/10.

Resident Evil 2 Remake Is So Good Great Story,Great Graphics,Great Game Play I Definitely Recommend it.

[h1] Graphics 7 of 10 [/h1]
Graphics are good, but at some points its lazy, for example you walk under dripping water, a shower for instance, and you do not get wet. Please. 

[h1] Gameplay 5 of 10 [/h1]

The gameplay suffers a lot because of the absolute AWFUL console porting. Why the hell do mouse and keyboard feel like playing with the most clumsy controller ever invented. The Joypads are NOT good, its the most awfule trash ever. 

[h1] Story 1 of 10 [/h1]

The story is absolute forgettable. The only time you feel just a little tense was when you are hunted by Mr. X, but that you can go into saferoom, and Mr X cant go in there, is the biggest fail ive ever seen in gaming. That just kill the immersion. Let him HUNT you where ever you are. Not this "SAFE, you cant touch me here even though ive just past the damn door
No its not needed.
The story is pretty awful, there is nothing really exciting in the story, so you can a forget why you are there.

[h1] Sounds 6 of 10 [/h1]

The sound is okay.  the acting is, well, its there, nothing really WAUW about it, but neither something that will make you fall asleep.

[h1] Controlling 2 of 10 [/h1]
Its absolutely awful as mentioned before. tell me, why do you run like a one legged dwarf and as slow as wheelchair gandalf and get away from being hit by a huge monster or just a fly? Or run so slow that you get hit by everything, even hits that you clearly see should NOT hit you? I wonder how my monitor survived my rage i had somethimes because the clumsyness at boss fights. You dont rage because of the intense gameplay, because that part is missing in the game. You rage because the controlling is like an AWFUL joypad. GET RID OF THE GAWD DAMM CONSOLE PORTS!!!!!!

[h1] Fun 1 of 10 [/h1]

You are somewhat entertained when you are chased by mr. X else you are just running around and solving kindergarten level puzzles. Why not add some really challenging puzzles? Why must it all be so damn easy? Make great games, dont make "in and out" games with no challenges. I remember trying to solve puzzles in the 90s where i could think for days before i found the solution. That just gives you an satisfaction you never get from games anymore. Now, what you get from todays challenges is: "Okay, was that it? move on" No satisfaction at all.

[h1] Price 1 of 10 [/h1]

the 1 of 10 for price was at release. By now the game should be max 10 euro, so that is okay for that game. But they wanted 60 bucks bck then, and its not worth  60 bucks. And dear developers, I WILL NEEEVER BUY GAMES FOR MORE THAN 60 BUCK. Take your $ 70 or 70 euro or more and shove it. the way Triple A games are today, NO GAMES are worth 70 euro, not even 60 or 50. The triple A gaming is suffering so BAD.

Its time to throw away EVERYTHING what the gaming industry have done the past 13 years, and go back to when games were good, and start making good games again.

[h1] Over all 2 of 10 [/h1]
The game is okay, but it does NOT deserve Overwhelmingly positive, that it is not. Its an okay game, the best Resident Evil in a very long time, but there is not good story, and the scary part is not even scary. 
Developers cant even make game scary anymore without the CHEAP jumpscare. Seriously, who want that sh!t. Make it scary properly or dont make a scary game at all. Outlast and the first amnesia is worth finding inspiration.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
Thank gawd i am done with this game, it is NOT a game i will replay. Its absolutely not worth another playthough.

Devs?! #MakeGamesGreatAgain And kill the console ports, its a game killer. and throw away the damn console controllings on Keyboard and mouse!!!

This is a really great update to one of my favourite Resident Evil games. There's a new over-the-shoulder control scheme that feels much more like a modern video game, and it keeps the same tense exploration and puzzle solving that made me fall in love with the original in the late 90s.

Zombies feel much more menacing and can sometimes take a handful of bullets to take down, only to get back up 20 seconds later. The way enemies react to your bullets is shockingly brutal—zombies will even crawl around without arms or legs until you eliminate them for good. Other iconic enemies like Lickers and Mr. X make their return, and I really like new, terrifying ways they’ve implemented them into the remake.

Classic locations like the Police Station and Umbrella Lab are updated with new passages and doorways that lead to other familiar sections, and I really enjoy the new altered layouts to make more logical sense. I do wish that some extended sections, like the Sewers, were a little less tedious though. But this is a great remake that Resident Evil fans are going to love playing through again, and it’s a game that newcomers will ultimately enjoy as well.

	[td] Content and Replay Value [/td]
	[td] This game sets what seems to be the standard now for how remakes should be done, and I’m here for it. RE2 has a story good enough to hold you even though it can be tongue in cheek sometimes. After you’re done playing the story, they introduce new scenarios for each playable character and the reward is the fully fleshed out ending. The best part is that each part takes about one dedicated sit down each! Therefore it doesn’t feel like you’re sacrificing much jumping back in! [/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td] Should you get it?[/td]
	[td] RE2 is great for newcomers and veterans to the series alike. Newcomer, you want a spooky puzzle game with beautiful graphics and a story? Here you go. Veteran, wanna see how the developers put a solid spin on arguably the BEST Resident Evil game? Have fun. This is solid grab; you’re essentially doing yourself a disservice as gaming hobbyist if you don’t grab it on sale. [/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td] Overall Verdict [/td]
	[td] 9/10. The game is good people. It still has the puzzles. Respectable spin on the story, Beautiful graphics. Respected my time as a gamer. And just feels good to play. I almost felt the inner speed gamer in me come out for the last two runs. I never feel that way. Plus I didn’t get to the DLCs which are just straight up fun. [/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[b] Setting & Writing: [/b]
Resident Evil 2: Remake takes place in notorious Raccoon City. You start the game as Leon Kennedy or Claire Redfield. Leon is on his way to the city to start his first day as a Raccoon City Police officer (RCPD) and Claire is on her way to find her brother Chris who is part of the RCPD. Their paths intersect just outside of the city where they witness their first encounter with the epidemic that has been spreading through Raccoon City. Chaos ensues as the protagonist find out how the epidemic started to spread, who started it, and the nightmare they’re living through to make it out alive. The game has three distinct acts, notable by location. If you’re a veteran to the game, you know the story and you know the bad guy. For newcomers, expect a exciting yet cliché story. What makes it work is that it never overstays its welcome and the story just keeps pulling you along, so you don’t have to think too long on non-sensical situations.

[b] Gameplay system & Bosses: [/b]
RE2: Remake implements the popular over the shoulder third-person view camera. The resident evil team first implemented this type of control and gameplay back in Resident Evil 4. This was such a popular design choice by the team that it stayed around up until Resident Evil 7, which was the first time the team decided to go to first-person view. Another staple to the story are the puzzles. Essentially, the Resident Evil series were escape rooms before they became a fad (fight me). To progress your way through the story you may find little trinkets and codes that will continue to open up your way forward. Sometimes there’s a little bit of backtracking, but what’s nice is that you have an unintrusive goal list that generally tells you what you need to do. On top of that, the map system marks areas that you haven’t been to yet, allowing you to do further investigation if necessary. The shooting mechanic in RE2 is very risky as you don’t know when you might get more ammo. This leans into the survival horror aspect of the game. Resources are purposefully limited, making you concentrate on each shot taken. Ammo economy is slightly more forgiving on the lighter difficulties, but you feel it none the less. Being frugal with your ammo leads to rewards such as having it for boss fights! Boss fights hurt if you make the wrong move. They hit like a ton of bricks. Granted, they move so slooowww. Having more resources at your behest makes them easier to deal with.   

[b] Quest, Mini-games & Challenges: [/b] 
There’s one main quest of the game and its simple, make it out alive. Everything you do are building block to that singular main goal. Yes, there will be little things you pick up during the story. But Leon and Claire are to make it out of Raccoon City alive. Now after playing through the game enough (because it does go by quick) you realize that this game can be speed-ran. Through speed running the game you get the most exclusive treats. This incentives learning all the puzzles, killing only what is necessary, and optimal pathing. Outside of this, RE2: Remake offers DLCs that add more story beats to the information you’ve gathered within the story.  

[b] Miscellaneous (art, music, etc.): [/b]
RE2 utilizes RE: Engine. This graphics engine has catapulted Capcom into a renaissance. Everything is beautiful, everything feels optimized, and it just works. The team knows how to set the atmosphere and utilizes the power of RE Engine to accomplish that. On top of the sound design makes your trek though survival ominous and spooky.

I was born a little too late to play the OG Resident Evil games back in the PS1 era. It wasn't until I was 12 or 13 years old that my parents bought me Resident Evil 4 for the GameCube after I wrote them an essay arguing that I was mature enough for the graphic violence and it wouldn't turn me into a poorly adjusted adult. I freaking loved that game. I never told them about the nightmares it gave me, though.

Then RE5 came out on the 360 a few years later and I was not a fan. I dabbled in other RE games after that, like Umbrella Chronicles for the Wii, but I resigned myself to having missed the true glory days of the franchise, catching it's last gasp of the brilliance that was RE4. Then Capcom stopped playing games and released this amazing remake, which just oozes with dread, squishy zombie gore, and a deliciously oppressive atmosphere. I also really enjoyed the story (which I know is intentionally campy as hell, but I was pretty lore-ignorant before playing this game).

Anyway, the game is technically polished (from my experience), looks gorgeous, and runs well. What else can I ask for?

Resident Evil 2 on the N64 was the first one I could actually play "as intended." Never got further than the police station, but you'd better believe that when I heard about the remake, I bought and got 100% on it!

PROS
+Multiple improvements over the 1998 version. Kendo's misogyny has been replaced with a tragic micro-story, Ada has a better cover story, the Tyrant is much more intimidating, and the player's interactions with other characters (especially Marvin and Ben) are far more realistic.
+I know the REngine has been praised to death, but holy cow does it deserve it! Even on low-medium graphics, pretty much everything looks incredibly realistic!
+Whereas RE2's story changed based on which character you played as first, RE2R's has a defined story for Leon and Claire. The gameplay will change based on who you play as first, but the story will largely remain the same. By the way, the story is also greatly improved over the original.
+The voice acting is phenomenal. Leon balances the line of idealistic, "happy" rookie cop in deep poop, Marvin's every breath sounds pained, Ada's disregard for Leon slowly fades over the course of the game, Annette is pretty much perfect in every one of her scenes, and Claire really brings the emotion when she needs to. Also, the hyper-scared/frustrated/angry lines for Leon and Claire are 10/10.
+The setting of Raccoon City is phenomenal. Act 1's location has an overwhelming presence, Act 2's is dirty, gross, and uncomfortable, and Act 3's takes great inspiration from the movies, which I personally prefer over the original.
+Classic pains-in-the-ass like the Lickers and Dogs remain, while more silly creatures from the 1998 version like the giant spiders were wisely removed.
+The gameplay is a great reminder of what survival horror is supposed to be. Any time I wanted to move to progress the story, I would first map out my route, identify known obstacles, predict new threats, and grab a loadout for that single step. I'd then do that step (or die trying and start planning all over again), return to a safe zone, and start planning my next step. Inventory space is just as key in this as it was in RE2, making this very difficult, but very rewarding!
+The change to an RE4-style over-the-shoulder perspective greatly improves the gameplay over the original.
+The secondary-weapon system is a great addition of weapons while forcing each successful zombie attack to be another resource decision: do I spend this knife and save some health, or do I take the hit because I'm low on knives?
+The map is familiar to its 1998 version without being an exact copy, which greatly helps return players have a good experience.
+Zombies are actually scary again! There's no feeling like desperately trying to drop one who just refuses to die while he inches closer to you!
+The Tyrant, aka Mr. X, has far exceeded Nemesis from either the original or remake of RE3 as the best ongoing antagonist of the Resident Evil franchise. His constant presence is felt no matter where you go, and has some fantastic scares throughout the game, both in jump-scares and in entrances. His character is further felt in his increasing aggression as he suffers various setbacks throughout the game, and fighting him feels like fighting The Terminator. Not to mention: his face is just disturbing.
+Reading the notes is genuinely rewarding. Between giving hints for where to go/what to do, explaining apparent inconsistencies, and telling tragic stories, they add a great deal to the atmosphere of the game.
+Fun rewards for beating the game at higher difficulties, including infinite-ammo weapons!
+The 4th Survivor returns, posing a great challenge that feels akin to a New Game+ speedrun!
+Even better: the return of the Tofu Survivor!
+Even even better: you can run through the Tofu Survivor as other wonderful Japanese delicacies!
+Mods!
+Flamethrowers!
+DLC: The Original Sounds Pack is one of my favorite DLCs of all time. While the remake has better music for the boss fights, the original soundtrack has far better atmosphere for the entire game.
+DLC: Other options are worth a mention: the costumes are great (especially the Noir costumes) and the Samurai Edges help in the early game, but are well-replaced by the late-game handguns.
+DLC: The Lost Survivors provide some great challenge runs for players who have beaten the game, ultimately unlocking a Nazi Zombies-style survival mode! Great fun!

CONS
-My first playthrough for this was as Leon on Hardcore, and no matter what I did, I would always end up soft-locked near the end of Act 2, unable to handle the five or so G-Adults without dying. After beating Claire's playthrough, I was able to barely scrape through with only a grenade left thanks to liberal use of the now-unlocked infinite knife. While Claire on Hardcore is pretty doable, Leon is pretty much impossible without using speedrunner-level dodging or bonus weapons.
-DLC: While I like the Samurai Edges, they do technically provide an early-game advantage, if you care about that sort of thing.

Easy 10/10 game, even with the cons. A must-play for all fans of horror.

I AM SO ENJOYING THIS, Never played the original Resident Evils but man this remake is fantastic, I am thoroughly invested. 100% worth if you want the resident evil experience. Conserve your supplies and only dispatch if absolutely necessary, stun with those juicy headshots, kill all those damn Lickers, and I will see you on the other side of Raccoon City friends!

Played Leon's story, absolutely could not get through the 2nd play through. Claire's weapons are trash and the inventory management in this game is just far too brutal. I don't get it, the only purpose it served was forcing me to retrace every step 5 times just because I am greedy and don't want to run back for stuff. Honestly just boring and tilting. I got an amazing deal on it now for $10, so that is the reason I am not too upset. Honestly this game to me just felt like a punishment. Also, wouldn't anyone else rather have 3 zombie per 1, opposed to one that tanks 8 head shots? Brought me out of the immersion knowing any biological thing's head would be pulverized. I am talking your basic zombie mush enemies. Obviously the mutations, sure. But these are the basic zombie forms. Zero satisfaction dumping 8 head shots and no reward. Just dissatisfied. I will admit there are 2 types of RE fans. The puzzles/mystery and the action. I am pretty down the middle with that and honestly didn't like the game.

I understand the praise and i will recommend, but what i don't understand is if you're going to remake this game why not have both characters have completely different stories that line up at the end? My biggest gripe with this game(there's 2) is that Leon and Claire have such minuscule differences. Besides the Ada/Sherry side story, there isn't too big of a difference between the two stories. And Claire is always ahead of Leon, shouldn't the secret door already be open, should't the doors using the T tool be used, and the god awful greenhouse puzzle, this shit should already be done. and the 2nd gripe will be the Tyrant. There is some massive jank with this behemoth of a man. Let's say you're running away and he's right outside a safe room, i've sat there for 10 minutes eating my lunch with the game running and as soon as i leave he's waiting for me outside the door, if i was playing on a hardcore and i got killed that way i would have uninstalled right then and there. The Tyrant can ruin someones experience and enjoyment with this game, i almost didn't finish it.

this was my first Resident evil game and this game has some serious issues ( in my opinion )


the atmosphere and sound design is great


however...

the game make you feel incredibly weak....you don't find much ammo and zombies die from 1-10 headshots...literally...the average bullet used to kill is 5 per zombie.......**with headshots only**


i first started with Leon on medium difficulty because i don't like the modern "hard mode" such as very low damage, bullet sponges and enemies hitting like tanks.....it's such an unimmersive incompetant solution to increase difficulty......Fromsoftware clearly knows how to make things difficult yet fair and rewarding...almost any other company still don't realise that's the way to go...and this game is no different.............going back to the medium difficulty Leon playthough, i gave up after 2 hours because the zombies were so annoying, taking multiple bullets in the head with too few bullets to find...and even then, reviving out of nowhere to make you look like you wasted all those shots...i then tried with Claire on easy difficulty...and even then the zombies are still tanky...however the bullets are more common, which i didn't had much complain


the inventory is also annoying to manage constantly because one time it's too full, the other you stored a key item which you now need and have to go back, etc.

I have played the classic game and I love both classic and remake. Someone told me that they applied a patch to change the game so that the enemy could access the safe room. However, if I remember correctly, Annette Birkin there are some differences in Leon and Claire's campaign. Overall, the game was just awesome.

I just finished playing as Leon. Such a good game. I thought I would hate the Tyrant (Mr. X) chasing me everywhere, but it was actually exhilarating. This is the cornerstone of the proof-of-concept that you can reimagine games from a bygone era that had unique mechanics that could ONLY work for the time. The team somehow managed to make a game while keeping the feeling of the old and modernizing it with this ingenious way that shows how you can take old games and remake them in ways previously thought possible. RE 2 Remake has shown the evolution of remasters as an old game is made into something entirely different in a good way. I am thoroughly convinced titles such as MGS 3 or other old games which could not work as modern games can be remade with similar spirit and I can't sing praises enough on how this game will be the grandfather of remakes.

RE2R was my first dive into the RE universe and I could not have been happier with that decision. Since then the RE universe has become one of my favourite franchises.

The stories in this game are great; storytelling is excellent and the acting is exceptional. There is very good replayability with RE2R, as there are lots of different weapons for both Leon and Claire to use as well as having two different scenarios for both characters opens up a lot of different opportunities for different playstyles and loadout variety. Speaking of, as with all RE games since RE7, the weapons feel amazing to use and their modifications definitely feel noticeable.

My only "gripe" with the game is how scenario A for one character and scenario B for the other character don't really intertwine as they probably should; there are a lot of points in the game where it feels like Leon and Claire should meet (excluding the beginning and end of the stories) and locked doors would already have been opened when the scenario B stories start.

Overall though, an excellent game and an excellent entryway into the franchise.

I don't even know where to start with this. 
If you are new to the horror genre and want something that can grasp you into horror, this would be the perfect game to start off with. heck even if you are one, you'd be missing out on an experience. But why? 

Well, first off this is an remake of the original classic RE2, however in this remake, they expand the maps and gameplay further than what they imagined back then. Personally, i wasn't alive at the time when this game came out so i don't have much to say about that, however i would love the play the classic to compare these 2 and see how much technology and game development came so far. 

But the reason why this game is so fantastic and flawless is because the gameplay, inventory system, and its simplicity is what makes this game so fun and it successfully illustrates what a survival horror should be. its brilliant. especially on harder difficulties where it feels realistic and need to tread carefully. 
If you havent played this game yet, you need too now.

Amazing mix between puzzles and combat. Shooting on mouse is a little difficult if you use a low sens like I do.

Enemies are challenging but not overly difficult on Standard Mode, and you get unlimited saves which is extremely helpful.

The story is not the most unique thing in the world, but it is engaging and fun to play through. Overall I had a great experience, and would recommend this to anyone.

THIS GAME IS A MASTERPIECE! I was a not a fan of resident evil but this game AMAZED me. The combat-ammo system is amazing, the story is perfect, same with the map and characters. Also, this game has huge replayability, since when u finish the stroy with 1 character you can choose <the second run> with the other where everything is different ( puzzles,codes,guns,ammo, item locations and DIFFERENT ENDING). I suggest you start ith Leon, an amazing character with very cool and fast ( if you unlock the attachments) weapons, with an amazing story (including romance) and an exclusive final boss fight. After you finish the story with him you should do the second run with Claire, where the guns arent as strong ( except from the grenade launcher) but there is  a lot of variety. Things are more challenging but you get to play and see so much extra content along with the <true ending> ( which is BEAUTIFUL). In conclusion, I think you should definitely buy this game since I cant find one single bad thing about it, while I should also mention that there are some short challenges/storylines for after you finish the story.

Absolutely fantastic game. Really well done, and it gets way better when you play the story again on the second run and you are much more familiar with how to handle situations. Keeps you on your toes, and really well done as far as gameplay and story are concerned.

I've played it 100+ times on my Xbox since its release and it will never, ever get old. Since the release of RE4R, I bought this masterpiece for PC since it was only $10. Something about it just reels me back in just when I think I've had enough of the game entirely.  It's almost relaxing and very nostalgic (in a way lol), I love the story mode so much - both Claire AND Leon - and I think that may be part of the reason as to why I still come back to play it too. Super fun, love the endings when you finish both stories, and love the extra modes too! The costumes also add more fun to the game if you purchase them.

REmake 2 perhaps is the best form of remakes. Whilst REmake 3 lacked either vision, or funds, or time, or motivation - REmake 2 felt like a bona fide attempt to bring the classic game to modern computers. And it largely succeeds. Largely, because it cuts down on a lot of things that makes the RE2 unique. The trade off is that the game feels more straightforward on a single run. You can check off most of the story boxes and have a good idea what's going on in a single run, then play the 2nd Run just to see what minor story beat you missed. But because REmake 2's idea of a second run is quite literally the same game with not much added in sans different variables of engagement, it's hard to really convince oneself to do it. The option is there, so that's value, but whether it's done right is subjective. 

But I think most of the value is in the 1st run anyway. I loved that Capcom could marry in the puzzle-heavy gameplay of the old REs whilst retaining a modern feel and layout. RPD has been made well here, which makes me wish I could explore Spencer's Mansion in REmake 2 as a DLC. I'm rambling. Cut it short, good game. Play it. Then play REmake 4.

I'm going to straight up say that this remake is amazing, but there are some questionable design decisions which do lower its overall quality.

The good:[list]
[*]Incomparably more atmospheric that the original. By default there's almost no music, aside from safe rooms, not even ambient tracks, just sounds of the surroundings, and it works really well. I'd say it's the most atmospheric RE next to RE7. 
[*]Storywise it's a bit more down to earth, realistic, dramatic, and has a bit more sense. Dialogues are more natural. The building layouts are more logical and realistic.
[*]Much harder than the original. The zombies are more dangerous and bullet spongy. In RE2 you had so much ammo you could clear entire groups of zombies without much trouble. Here, not so much.
[*]Mr. X is probably the largest improvement. Instead of being relegated to scripted appearances during which he was barely a thread and easy to ignore, here he wanders around the entire RPD, patrolling it looking for you. His loud *thump thump* stomping sounds are fantastic.[/list]

Many QoL features are taken straight out of RE1 Remake and improved, as well as other additions:[list]
[*]Rooms with/without items are marked on the map. 
[*]Defensive Items return, now called Sub Weapons, and can be used offensively.
[*]You can enable the original RE2 soundtrack if you so please.
[*]An orphanage chapter was added. The orphanage was only briefly touched upon in a document found in the original game.[/list]

These changes show the dedication and love of the developers towards the source material.

The mid:[list]
[*]Character movement speed is painfully slow. Almost as bad as Fatal Frame/Project Zero. It's more shuffling than moving.
[*]Leon and Claire are moaning so much when """running""" you'd think they're """running""" a marathon.
[*]Leon and Claire's comments during combat can be grating at times.[/list]

The bad:
The design decisions I wrote about earlier.[list]
[*]The game is pulling wool over the player’s eyes in regards to some of the mechanics, i.e. it's easier than it appears. Other RE games also have them, but not to this extent: in RE2 Remake having the knowledge of its inner workings massively improves your gameplay potential. For example, you cannot die on any difficulty if you’re not in Danger state, not counting instant death attacks. The knowledge of this alone helps you save a ton of herbs for the future. It also makes the R+B mix, which reduces damage taken by half for 3 minutes, much more valuable than a full heal R+G on Hardcore difficulty. What’s more, some weapons deal either reduced or increased damage against specific enemies, e.g. Leon’s shotgun is great against zombies and dogs, but is pretty crap against anything else. Furthermore, there are 2 boss fights [spoiler](G2 and Super Tyrant)[/spoiler] which seem cheap and frustrating, but which become very simple once you know the mechanics behind them.
[*]The inconsistency in zombie durability. I get it, they want you to kill zombies only in high traffic areas, and shoot to stagger to avoid others. Except attempting to stagger sometimes takes 3 head/leg shots, sometimes 10, sometimes even more. You’re still wasting a lot of ammo. Trying to avoid entirely is extremely risky, since corridors can be tight and zombies can double lunge at you. Yes, you have Sub Weapons, but there aren’t that many of them and you want to save grenades for bosses or large groups of zombies, instead of lone ones. On the other hand, for Leon, once you get the shotgun, zombies stop being a threat almost entirely, since he can decapitate them 100% of the time with it. The balance is really weird and ruins the resource management part. People complain about RE3 Remake, but at least it's more consistent there.[/list]

The above forces players to metagame almost to extreme levels on Hardcore difficulty.

Last, but not least: the biggest bone of contention among fans is the A/B scenario system. It was the best feature of the original, but in RE2R they neutered it rather significantly:[list]
[*]You do not have any impact on B scenario via A.
[*]All the puzzles are the same, some of them have slightly different solutions.
[*]Bosses are the same with the exception of last two.
[*]Storywise it’s almost the same like in the original. Claire meets Leon only twice, at the beginning and at the end.
[*]The biggest gameplay difference are that each scenario has access to a few different areas which the other has not.[/list]

Other stuff:[list]
[*]I tried 4th Survivor/Ghost Survivors and didn't bother finishing it. A trial & error speedrun mode. These kind of modes are a mistake of nature, a complete anti-thesis to what the game is about. Same with RE7's Ethan Must Die. At best they are a get-achievement-never-touch-again deal. It could work in RE4, 5, or 6, but not here.
[*]I don’t care about them cutting the giant spiders or moths, for me they never felt like they belonged in RE2.[/list]

TLDR: I don't like the combat mechanics, but it's worth buying.

It is amazing how flexible in general RE games can be, considering that the narrative is so linear. It all comes down to the game challenging you to beat it better every time, of course. The RE2R challenging system is awesome in that aspect, the combat system is great (not so much with secondary weapons tbh but it is still awesome). All well packed along the most glamorous gloomy visuals, an oppressive atmosphere tainted with a genius sound design and crawling, nasty foes. What is there not to like? It is all you crave in a survival horror. Go for it, either if you're familiar with the franchise or not.

RE2 is a great game. That being said I found the replay value on this game to be a bit lackluster, not to mention the story never really felt catching to me in at least Clair's story line, I found her story to be more tedious than fun. One of the main reasons why I probably wont 100% this game ever. Leon's story is really good and it makes up for Clair's boring ass story. However even then I find myself being not very interested in the narrative after the second play-through. Also all of the extra bonus game modes are really fun and challenging but in my opinion way too challenging. I have raged more times over the stupid bonus content than I have playing Getting Over It. It really sucks in my opinion that this is apart of the 100% completion for the game, I still have no idea how to beat the 4th survivor. Overall though the game presented some fun game-play and good boss fights that I did enjoy. Leon is definitely my fav character in the RE franchise.

Grabbed this during a Capcom sale in a bundle with Re3.  Had never planned any Resident Evil games before and was happy to try out a graphically updated version.

So far, I have finished Leon's story and am part way through Claire's.  Good game.  Challenging at times.  I've never been so careful about conserving ammo before in a video game ... lol.  This game has taunt me avoidance of enemies vs. clearance; most games I have played a strategy of careful clearance of enemies works great whereas here there isn't enough ammo to get every last baddy (and have them stay down).

Anyway, worth the purchase and fun to finally play a series I had enjoyed seeing in film & TV.

I do think the A/B runs were handled far better in the original, which is a frustrating point for the remake as there are certains scenes that were cut in the remake that were amazing in the original, such as Ada sacrificing herself for Leon against mr X, Claire throwing sherrys pendant to get MR X to get submerged in Lava, etc.

Definitely wish the proper B scenarios were added in, even as DLC, rather than what we got.

Still, outside of this the game is fantastic.
